title: The Book of Longings
author: Kidd, Sue Monk*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of those books that I liked and also did not like. If it had been about any other subject matter than Jesus Christ, I probably would have This is one of those books that I liked and also did not like. If it had been about any other subject matter than Jesus Christ, I probably would have liked it more and rated it 4 stars. The weaving of fiction with history was done quite well and I liked recognizing well known stories from the Bible with believable backstory and personality. I also liked Sue Monk Kidd's deliberate feminist angle about women and their unrecognized ambitions and abilities and how a society, the ancient Jewish and Roman society in this case, perceives and treats women who do not fit into their accepted traditional roles. I've often wished for more history from a woman's perspective and what lessons we would have had they been written down and preserved. Kidd gives us an idea about what some of those stories may have been through her protagonist, Ana, who she writes as the fictional wife of Jesus Christ. While Kidd never degrades or demeans Jesus Christ as one of her characters, she admits to focusing solely on his humanity and none of his divinity. I can understand her motivation to write him that way but by doing so, she actually reduces Christ to a weak character. He is not well developed. His motivations are murky and actions, specifically in his role as Messiah, often unintentional. Because he is not the main character, this all happens in the background of Ana's story and I could forgive it if the character were anybody other than Jesus Christ. But, it is Jesus Christ and I have strong opinions and beliefs about him that I can't lay aside for the sake of her story. Still, it's such an interesting premise and lots of things worked well. I happen to believe Jesus WAS probably married and his wife's story silenced in the aftermath and establishment of Christianity. So, I enjoyed most of Ana's story. I did get pretty bored when she left the Galilee for Alexandria for a couple of years and lots and lots and lots of details were written about Alexandrian society and the library and papyri. Kidd explained in the author's note that all of those historical details were true and...I could tell. It read like a documentary instead of a story and didn't blend very well with the rest of the book. Fiction is fiction and I love it and learn so much from it so I get that none of this has to be true but it can still be true. That's fiction, right? But, my deep and unwavering belief in the divinity AND humanity of Jesus Christ can't shrug off a book that lessens him. Ana lessened him. Not as his wife but as someone who never recognized who she was married to. And, for a book about a woman who longs to be known and seen in her  fullness, it seems tragic that the book didn't account for her knowing and seeing her husband in his fullness....more

title: The Beekeeper of Aleppo
author: Lefteri, Christy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "People are not like bees. We do not work together, we have no real sense of a greater good - I've come to realize this now." - MustafaIn pre war-torn"People are not like bees. We do not work together, we have no real sense of a greater good - I've come to realize this now." - MustafaIn pre war-torn Syria, cousins Mustafa and Nuri work as beekeepers in the city of Aleppo. As death and danger close in on the characters due to a civil war that author Christy Lefteri never explains to her readers, they must choose when and how to flee their homes. I found this literary technique both frustrating and fascinating. It's effective as a reader to feel the confusion about not understanding why the chaos is happening. Why are bombs dropping and destroying homes? Why are people being shot execution style on the side of a river? Why are people's livelihoods being looted and burned? If Lefteri's aim in omitting any explanation was to get her readers to research the Syrian War conflict, she succeeded because I spent about 2 hours last night googling all about it when I finished the book. I just couldn't be that sad and not know why Nuri and Afra and Mustafa and Sami and so many others were forced to embark on the dangerous journey of a refugee. I still don't really understand. It's very, very tangled and this will be the 10th year of conflict with some estimating half of the Syrian population displaced over this time. Half of a country. Wow. Without a doubt, this is a sad book. This is not historical fiction. It is contemporary fiction. This is what is happening in Syria right now and in many other parts of the world where governments do not work together and have no real sense of a greater good. As I started reading this book soon after our own national shock of mobs raiding the capitol building, I couldn't help but think, "Is this what's coming to the U.S.? Will civil unrest turn to war because those in power refuse to compromise? To work together? To care about a greater good more than personal pride?" What is even sadder to me is that, unlike one of my favorite quotes by Fred Rogers, about "looking for the helpers" when scary things are going on, the helpers seem few and far between in the world. At least in this story. There are a few workers at camps and such in Turkey and Greece and Britain that seem to genuinely want to help these poor, miserable, unlucky humans who just want to feel safe but most of the helpers seem tired, suspicious, corrupt or bureaucratic. You can't even fault them, even though you want to because you know that Nuri is good and Afra is grieving and all Mustafa wants to do is keep bees. But they have to wonder...are they dangerous? Are their stories true? So the help is slow or given grudgingly or, worse, with horrible strings attached. There is a lyrical quality to Lefteri's writing that I quite enjoyed. She uses a dangling word to connect past to present, dream to memory and it had a powerful anticipatory effect for me. I looked forward to it each time it happened. I also really liked the emphasis on the psychological trauma of the refugee. Getting somewhere safe is so fraught with danger that you can document and account for the obvious physical threats. Bribery. Robbery. Rape. Kidnapping. Assault. Murder. But what does that do to the soul? Survival is the basic, pressing, constant need for way too long and the brain does what it must to cope after experiencing and witnessing these horrors. We see how each character copes emotionally and the toll their mechanisms take on their relationships. One thing I didn't particularly like is there is quite a bit of narration dedicated to secondary characters and their journeys that don't progress the story in the best way, in my opinion. After reading the author's notes at the end, I can understand why she included them. Lefteri worked as a volunteer at a refugee camp in Athens, Greece and was, herself, the daughter of refugees. I'm sure she has notebooks full of stories she wanted to include because of what she saw but at times, I felt like I was just getting these stories as a bit of a tangent and they didn't necessarily belong in Nuri, Afra and Mustafa's story. Not that they didn't belong at all. Refugees will meet other refugees and those relationships and interactions are part of the story but sometimes, particularly with Diomande, it seemed tangental. Just my opinion. We chose this book as our sister's bookclub pick this month and I'm looking forward to discussing it with my sisters. I think this book has plenty to discuss and plenty of chances for reflection and introspection about how similar or dissimilar we are to the bees....more

title: This Tender Land
author: Krueger, William Kent*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think I would have given this book 4 stars had I written my  immediately after finishing, but two days later, the glow has dimmed and I'm leftI think I would have given this book 4 stars had I written my  immediately after finishing, but two days later, the glow has dimmed and I'm left remembering that I liked this book but really liking it feels overly generous. First of all, I didn't enjoy the prologue or the epilogue at all. Both reminded me (when it was easily forgettable due to the real time emotions and descriptive detail in the main portion of the book) that the story was being told with hindsight by a man old enough to be a great grand-father. When I was given that reminder, the story seemed less likely to be really true and more, "when I was young we had to walk uphill to school both ways!" kind of true. I'm not sure why they were included. I also think the story's ties to the land and river could have been stronger. With the title being what it is, this was way more a story about Odie, Albert, Mose and Emmy and their relationships with each other than any of their relationship and experiences with the land. Having never traveled to Minnesota or any of the other places the characters went, I never got a sense of the land. Was it humid? Was the soil soft? Did the wind blow all the time? Actually, I liked the emphasis on the relationships more than I would have liked more description of the land so maybe it just needs a different title. As for the story itself, it was a very good coming-of-age/Disney/Grimms fairy tale type saga. There were orphans and cruel adults and tons of adventure and danger. Set during the Great Depression, it was also heartbreaking and eye-opening about how, less than a century ago, there weren't many safety nets for the poor and downtrodden. Perhaps due to its focus on these downtrodden, the story contains lots of characters from the outskirts of society: a mute Sioux boy whose tongue had been cut out, bootleggers, a German with a finger cut off, a one-eyed rancher whose wife and daughter left him, jews, lesbians, prostitutes, alcoholics, a snake charmer and other misfits and marginalized. The weirdest characters are the one that can see your past and what you want most by simply holding your hand and the one that can change the outcome of the future during one of her seizures. There is also a truly horrible villain that stops at nothing to ruin the lives of everyone and she appropriately wears only black. It's a colorful cast and crew.The main protagonist is a 12 year-old boy named Odie O'Banion, who travels alongside his 16 year-old brother, Albert, as well as their friend Mose and a young six year-old girl named Emmy. They are all orphans and escape from the Lincoln Indian Training School and the evil clutch of the school's superintendent, Mrs. Brickman (the Black Witch). After their escape by canoe on the nearby Gilead river, the majority of the story takes place in a hodgepodge of stops on their journey along the Gilead, Minnesota and Mississippi rivers to St. Louis. Each stop introduces new characters, new problems and an opportunity to include social commentary of the times. Many people compare the story to the likes of Mark Twain's Huckleberry Finn or even Steinbeck's Grapes of Wrath and I can see the similarities, because there is a river and it is the Great Depression, but I didn't every feel like the moral of the story got close to the depths of those classics. The writing was good and very readable but I'm not sure what the point was. Perhaps that life is unfair or that money corrupts or that native Americans were treated horribly or that survival makes people do desperate things or that God doesn't exist or that he's a tornado or a river or an energy that can heal. My take away is that there once was a boy whose parents and guardians own poor choices provided a difficult childhood for him. And through that difficult childhood, he learned some survival skills that also led to some poor choices that provided difficult circumstances for others. But, ultimately, good can overpower evil and humans can choose to help others because love and light exist in even the darkest of circumstances. It's a good take away, I think. I liked it....more

title: The Answer Is…: Reflections on My Life
author: Trebek, Alex
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I grew up in a Jeopardy household. My parents, who I consider to be very intelligent, watched it and Wheel of Fortune most nights. Once we all moved oI grew up in a Jeopardy household. My parents, who I consider to be very intelligent, watched it and Wheel of Fortune most nights. Once we all moved out and left them as empty nesters, I think it was one of the few scheduled parts of their day. 6:00-7:00 pm. Even with the DVR! I have always loved that a good, wholesome, smart game was enjoyable for them and that it never changed so much in television's frenzied need to always be current and drawing in new demographics to leave them behind. I'm the kind of Jeopardy fan that only watches it when somebody else has it on but I've always liked Alex Trebek's hosting style. On television, he always seems smart and sincere...likable without making the show all about him. Sometimes, he came off a little bit snobby and I always smiled when he made sure to pronounce everything as it should be, with foreign words said in the style and accent of a native speaker because him doing so reminded me of my high school government teacher who did the same thing. Immature teenagers think it's hilarious when they hear their teacher say "Ha-vi-ee" for "Hawaii" and "koo-bah" for Cuba and I can't even phonetically go there with Niccolo Machiavelli but suffice it to say it was very dramatic and spit producing. Thankfully, I'm way more mature now and when Alex Trebek pronounces things correctly during Jeopardy, it makes me smile, particularly when the clues are in French! Je l'aime!With all of that good-feeling prefacing done, I wish I had liked this book more. I definitely didn't dislike it. There is nothing to dislike. Trebek is exactly who his TV personna claimed to be over the past 36 years. Likable. Smart. Kind. Humble. I guess what I wished for in his memoir, especially one he only decided to do after being given a terminal pancreatic cancer diagnosis, was more of the why. More philosophy. More connecting of life dots. He does it occasionally but never in a way that the story preceding it doesn't obviously go. There was never, ever any "huh" or "aah" moments for me. The book is formatted with each chapter titled, "The Answer is...." and something. Then he would write about that. Some were short. Some are longer. It's pretty chronological but more interesting antidotes than anything developmental. There isn't much of a beginning, middle and end so very little arc to follow and get invested in. It was very, very simple writing and pretty simple reflections. He admits to that in the book's preface. He is a simple man who never felt like he was interesting enough to write a memoir. He loves his wife. His kids. His job. Working hard. He never had to overcome any great debacle in his life or addiction and never seemed to suffer any major life blows or crushing heartache, at least that he's willing to share with the public. Even his cancer diagnosis is written about with great acceptance and grace. I listened to the audio of this book and probably 80% of it is narrated by Ken Jennings. I love that they are friends and respect Jennings as a part of Trebek's life and his Jeopardy career but his voice isn't Alex Trebek's and since this is all in first person narrative, I liked the parts Trebek narrated more. He was in radio and television for a reason. His voice is awesome and easy to listen to. I wish he could have done more of it. I'm sure there are reasons why he didn't narrate more and I respect them but I might have enjoyed reading the book more instead of listening to it as Jenning's voice and my enjoyment of it, swayed my response. If Alex Trebek and his years hosting Jeopardy are something you enjoy, you will like this book if you read it. The colorful language surprised me but it's mostly in the beginning of the book and he explains why he cusses. It did make me wonder if my dad would like it but, in the end, it's not a big deal. On the other hand, if you are ambivalent about Alex Trebek and Jeopardy, there really isn't any reason TO read this book. There just aren't many amazing insights and the kind of introspection that might compel a reader or a thinking and not just a fan of the show to read and recommend this book. It's a nice book about a very nice man who seems to have had a very nice life. Rest In Peace, Alex Trebek. ...more

title: All Adults Here
author: Straub, Emma*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Normally, I really enjoy family dynamic books. Normally, I really enjoy character driven books whose flaws and growth are the engine of the plot. All Normally, I really enjoy family dynamic books. Normally, I really enjoy character driven books whose flaws and growth are the engine of the plot. All Adults Here was just that kind of book and I really didn't enjoy it. The book's description make it seem like this is a book about parenting adult children and realizing the mistakes you've made in hindsight. Without a doubt, the book tells you repeatedly that is what it is about in each chapter as the various narrators, mainly Astrid, the matriarch and her grown children, Elliot, Porter and Nicky all recollect various memories and express current bad behavior that seems to stem from their past experiences. However, I found a, perhaps more subtle, but more determined storyline that clouded over all of that adult-parenting-is-hard-but-I-can-still-change-and-have-new-relationships-with-my-children-feel-good-schtick.. Straub uses several of her characters to highlight the risks and fears of living a non heteronormative lifestyle, which I could appreciate more if she didn't simultaneously use every ancillary character to progress what I consider a dangerous, anti-male rhetoric. The two male narrators who have voices (Astrid's sons) are both weak, selfish and bad partners and parents and the other male characters are even worse. They range from infantile to criminally predatory. There is actually one more male narrator but his voice falls into the non-heteronormative category but I won't spoil it here to say how but it doesn't soften the male character voice or add any balance at all. As a mother of 4 boys, I worry about the current shift in who is to blame for all the ills in society. For generations, it has been erroneously dumped on minority races and the marginalized. Rather than learning from history's mistakes and making progress about the use and abuse of power and the unfairness of those actions and rhetoric, it seems that many just want to change the name of the bad guy to "man" or, more specifically, "white man." It's their turn to sit in the back of the bus, if you will. But, that's not progress, in my opinion. That's linear movement. Someone is still being forced to sit in the back of the bus based not on their own personal behavior but on what they look like on the outside. It's subtle in this book but it's definitely present. I don't even know if Straub did it intentionally but when I finished the book last night, that was definitely what my brain took away. Emma Straub is a good writer. The writing is the redeeming star for me. While All Adults Here was never riveting reading for me and I could always easily put it down, every few pages, there is an excellently written line with just the right amount of wit. I have no doubt she could (and maybe already has) write a book that I do really enjoy but there was too much manipulation, bad behavior and unhelpful stereotypes for this to be that book. ...more

title: The Underground Railroad
author: Whitehead, Colson*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A few days ago, I came across an interview with the author of The Underground Railroad, Colson Whitehead, and although this is not a direct quote of eA few days ago, I came across an interview with the author of The Underground Railroad, Colson Whitehead, and although this is not a direct quote of either question or answer (because I can no longer find the source) I remember reading his response to the question, "How do you handle the rage and feelings of injustice you feel when researching the mistreatment of black lives in America for so long?" Whitehead responded, "I write." That stuck with me. One man, albeit a very intelligent and articulate man, has been given the opportunity to influence the views of millions throughout the world because he used his experience, values, education, talent and perspective to craft a lesson about slavery and how to escape from its horrific, historical chains. It was his response that motivated me to not only pick up his words and read but then to also pick up my pen (in the form of a laptop keyboard) and write. Because I think that's how I handle my confusion, anger, worry and rage too. In the second chapter titled, "Georgia," Whitehead first embeds some...fantasy? magical realism? really straightforward metaphor? by having Cora and Caesar, two fugitive slaves on the run from the Randall Plantation in Georgia, get on a boxcar train that is actually underground. I was so confused. By no means an expert about the Underground Railroad, I still felt that I had at least a decent, adult understanding about what it was, who helped run it and who used it in American history. But then Cora and Caesar were being led down steep stairs underneath a barn and feeling the cool mist of a tunnel and getting on a train that stayed underground until they got to another state. No kidding, I googled, "Was the underground railroad actually underground?" because I wondered if my admitted white privilege was so profound that I didn't know there were actual underground railroads. My google searched led to Whitehead's own explanation of his literary technique: he mixed fact with fantasy to create a sort of Gulliver's Travels/Alice in Wonderland experience to share the experience of the fugitive slave as well as those involved in helping and hunting them. Historically, no, there were no actual underground railroads There were no actual railroads either. Rather, individuals with courage, wits, perseverance, trust, help, the art of deception, kindness and, truthfully, luck made up the stations, agents, conductors, locomotives, rails and tunnels that moved human beings from the bowels of bondage in the south to fugitives with fragile freedom in the north. I've wondered if Whitehead's choice of storytelling had a purpose beyond technique or whimsy. He included a conversation between Caesar, Cora and Lumbly, a station agent in Georgia, about the building of the railroad, which is interesting since it didn't exist. Why take up pages, perhaps taking attention away from the real to describe the fantasy? When Caesar and Cora see the tunnel, Caesar asks, "How far does the tunnel extend? Lumbly shrugged. "Far enough for you." "It must have taken years." "More than you know. Solving the problem of ventilation, that took a bit of time.""Who built it?""Who builds anything in this country?" Caesar said, "But how?""With their hands, how else?"Because I was still caught up in the confusion of what I thought I knew and what the author was describing, my mind went there. Picturing miles and miles of underground tunneling that couldn't possibly have been created without the aid of blasting powder, tools and equipment. It would have been...impossible. However, Whitehead lets it be possible in his story. Not easy. Not trifling. And not magical. Instead he describes the sacrifice, time and individual effort it required. I think that imagery helped me better understand the incredible difficulty of escape. Because escape...true, real, meaningful escape, from whatever binds us, will also take a lot of sacrifice, time and all of our combined individual effort. Another interesting conversation happened between Lumbly and Cora during the time she is getting on the underground railroad for the first time. Lumbly, apparently joking as they were underground, tells Cora, "Look outside as you speed through and you'll find the true face of America." If taken literally or even as a joke, we readers would simply think, "Well...she'll see nothing. Nothing but darkness." But, at the end of the book, when Cora is on her last leg of the underground railroad, she remembers Lumbly's advice as she "ran her hand along the wall of the tunnel, the ridges and pockets. Her fingers danced over valleys, rivers, the peaks of mountains, the contours of a new nation hidden beneath the old."Once again, I believe Whitehead is using the imagery of an actual tunnel for an actual railroad used for escape by those in bondage to show us that the old can disappear beneath the new. We can escape the darkness of the past and come into the light of the new. Light and beauty can be the face of America. As the story develops, Whitehead takes us through stops in South Carolina, North Carolina, Tennessee and Indiana all experienced through Cora's viewpoint. Each stop is filled with glimmers of hope and gut-wrenching despair. Interspersed between stops is the perspective of six secondary characters. Cora's grandmother. A slave hunter. A doctor. A reluctant white abetter. Caesar. And Cora's mother, Mabel, who escaped Randall Plantation herself when Cora was only 10, leaving her alone there to fend for herself. The different voices were interesting because their points of view were so very different from Cora's own, which was mostly harsh, cold and aloof. Truthfully, this technique not my favorite form of narration, because I find it jarring to switch from story to story, but it fleshed out a wide variety of attitudes, rationale and the flawed thinking of the time period. When I try to understand or imagine how there ever could have been so many who believed that people with a different skin color weren't actually people, these various voices don't ever justify but they do explain how ambition, glut, fear, desire, ability, mob mentality, ignorance, religious fervor and...yes...white privilege can turn a blind eye to outright wrong. In all but Dr. Steven's chapter, which seemed to "jump the tracks" so Whitehead could describe the horrors of grave digging in pursuit of medical knowledge, I felt like the side perspectives added a lot of depth to Cora's own story and the underground railroad. My ultimate takeaway from this book is that while the railroad, both the literal literary and the figurative historical, required the hands and hearts of many, true escape from bondage requires Herculean individual effort. At each underground station on Cora's route, there are always others in charge of the particulars of her arrivals and departures. With her very limited experience and knowledge, she is dependent upon others as a condition of her freedom. And yet, at the last stop of her journey on the underground railroad, it is solely Cora's decision, determination and daring that take her from darkness to light, from chains to freedom."The mouth of the tunnel started as a tiny hole in the dark. Her strides made it a circle and then the mouth of a cave, hidden by brush and vines.  She pushed  aside the brambles and entered the air. In this day, when it has become clear that there is still systemic racism in America, and we seek for real and lasting escape from whatever binds us from lasting change, I hope that we, collectively with many hands, can build whatever structure is necessary to help those who are under valued and mistreated out of the current systems of bondage. Most importantly, I hope that we can take whatever individual strides are necessary to push aside the brush and vines that keep us staring at the old, dark face of America and into the light and air of a new and hopeful present. ...more

title: The Line Becomes a River: Dispatches from the Border
author: Cantú, Francisco
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked this up after reading a blurb by NPR that this was a "must read" about immigration. If anyone can help shed some light on why immigration aloI picked this up after reading a blurb by NPR that this was a "must read" about immigration. If anyone can help shed some light on why immigration along the Mexican border has become such a polarizing issue, I figured a person working as a border patrol agent would be a good and helpful source. Unfortunately, Cantú's book only reinforced what I already knew: the border is a mess. But, why? Why has building a wall and having the perceived ability to control immigration from Mexico become a reason a president willingly alienates and hurts hundreds of thousands of American citizens? Cantú attempts but fails (in my opinion) to establish the why by tracing the trajectory from when the current border was created after treaties and wars, a time in between when citizens from both the United States and Mexico easily crossed the river or desert to trade, visit or shop at nearby towns and villages to our current situation where its become Big Business to traffic humans illegally across the border. The reason Cantú's book fails to successfully explain this trajectory is because this book frequently shifts between a book about the border and his own personal memoir. It doesn't work. My brain couldn't keep up with the rapid fire shifts from subjects in both parts 1 and 2. I'd be reading a story about his childhood or a dialogue between him and his fellow agents, detailing a scene of capturing and transporting those who have crossed illegally in the desert and then, with only a paragraph change to announce the shift in thought, I'm reading about genetics and the aggression gene or an interview with an assassin from the drug cartels. It's very, very disjointed. However, it is also all interesting information. I only wish Cantú found a way to write so that all of it flowed better. That way, readers can process and assimilate the information into their own values and viewpoints better instead of trying to figure out what the heck is going on. I enjoyed Part 3 the best. In it, Cantú shares the story of his friendship with Jose and what happens when Jose travels back to Mexico to visit his dying mother only to find that he can't reenter the United States because he isn't a citizen. His several attempts to cross illegally become the narrative for the motive and the heartbreaking reality that the current policy of immigration and path to citizenship doesn't work. Jose is a good man, with a good job and sons who are citizens because they were born in the United States. He claims to have crossed illegally 30 years ago to escape the violence and poverty in Mexico but never attempted to become a citizen of the United States legally. I know it's complicated. I know it's hard. But addressing THAT hard seems more humane and effective than spending billions on a wall that will never work. Jose's story explains why. They do it for family and they do it for love. There has got to be a better way. Still, the reality is there is terrorism. There are drug cartels and horrifying violence from which the citizens in the southern United States need and deserve protection. I think it is super naive to think the only people who want to come to America are those wanting opportunities for a better life. So...I don't know what the answer is. Either, apparently, does Cantú. ...more

title: Endurance: Shackleton's Incredible Voyage
author: Lansing, Alfred
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My first  of 2019. My first  in a while, honestly. I think I've forgotten how to write them. I was motivated to pick up this classic afterMy first  of 2019. My first  in a while, honestly. I think I've forgotten how to write them. I was motivated to pick up this classic after finishing Esi Edugyan's Washington Black and the brief part of the book where the characters spend time in the arctic north. Why do people want to explore and survive in the poles?The early 1900s was still a time of exploration and discovery. The south pole had never knowingly been reached and there was a race, of sorts, to get there first. After the Norwegians won in 1911, Shackleton changed his goal to being the first to cross the entire antarctic continent from sea to sea going through the south pole. The expedition barely got started when the ship he was on, with a team of 27 others, got stuck in an ice drift. The story follows the man vs. nature showdown when their boat is eventually crushed by the ice and the men are left to escape their certain death in three smaller life boats.It really is an incredible journey and tale of survival. My frustration lies in that I couldn't connect to any of the characters and was thus less grateful than I should have been, that they were able to do or "endure" the things they did. Yes, the author introduced the characters and spends a bit of time describing most in distinct and charming ways but I couldn't keep most of them straight as only a few were ever quoted or singled out regularly. Instead, it was a story of the group and groups are much harder to attach to. Attached or not, the way these men survived and persevered in truly extreme conditions gets a slow clap from me. I cannot fathom going through anything like what these men went through. Like Unbroken and other books of survival, the quality of some to stave off death is...well...book worthy. This story is book worthy. I'm glad I know it now. It did nothing to entice me to the antarctic but I have a very healthy respect for it and for anyone who has been there and gotten back. ...more

review: It may seem odd to mention the book, Endurance: Shackleton's Incredible Voyage in a book  for Lianne Moriarty's chick-lit Nine Perfect StrangersIt may seem odd to mention the book, Endurance: Shackleton's Incredible Voyage in a book  for Lianne Moriarty's chick-lit Nine Perfect Strangers, but I read it Nine Perfect Strangers right afterward and couldn't help comparing the difference between the two narration styles and why I prefer a better blend of the two. Endurance was all story. My fault with it was that because it actually happened (I suppose even if it was fiction and just fictionally happened), I needed to care more about the people it happened to. In Nine Perfect Strangers, Moriarty seems to bet it all on caring about ANYTHING that happens because she spends the first two-thirds of the book developing the characters. Nothing happens. They are at a health resort but the chapters bounce back and forth between the nine and who they are and what their background is and it's all very interesting but...something needs to happen before the book is almost over. When the action finally starts, it is interesting but....it's all tell. Something happens and it happens to all of them and....it's weird. Maybe that's my problem with it. It's just too weird. I also thought the ending was a bit too campy. I like her writing though and have enjoyed most of her other books. I enjoyed this one but it's too character development heavy to be great. ...more

The second half is all over the place with weird long winded descriptions of many unnecessary tangents. But, overall, I have never read this story before: a free-ish scarred slave who is educated and gifted but haunted and insecure. It’s a story of friendship, loyalty, love and freedom. It’s a story about a human whose life experience is nothing like my own. I love these kinds of stories. ...more

title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
author: Skloot, Rebecca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks takes a Google Earth's perspective at the woman responsible for giving science the first human immortal cell lineThe Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks takes a Google Earth's perspective at the woman responsible for giving science the first human immortal cell line. For analogy's sake, imagine a cell is...say...the country of Portugal. Why Portugal, you ask? No reason, other than it's something you probably know a little bit about, like maybe how you think about a cell, but you haven't really bothered exploring much further. Now, imagine you had the power to zoom out of Portugal, understanding its relation to its neighboring countries in Europe. Zoom out a little further and, wow, now you see where it fits in with the Middle East, Africa, how it borders the Atlantic Ocean and how those colonists might have made their way to Brazil. In short, you see the part Portugal plays in the world. Next, zoom in. Zoom in to see the mountains and valleys, its rivers and inlets, cities and even hospital locations (so easily spotted with their red crosses). It looks like a really interesting country that I'd like to visit. Huh. You're probably thinking, "That's a lot of information about Portugal for a book about Henrietta Lacks." You're right. It was totally unnecessary to include such a long-winded and not very interesting analogy, but that's what I thought about when I considered the angle Skloot took when deciding how to tell Henrietta Lacks's story. To begin with, all she had was the name of a cell line she heard while attending a community college biology class: HeLa. Her professor briefly mentions that HeLa stands for (He)nrietta (La)cks and Skloot wonders, "Who is she?" Years and years worth of research later, she zooms out to answer that very question.Henrietta Lacks was a poor and uneducated African American woman who happened to have an extremely aggressive form of cervical cancer in her thirties. During a treatment session at the famed Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland, her doctor removed a sample of tissue from her cancerous tumor and gave it to a scientist working on establishing the first human immortal cell line, or a cell line that continues to divide indefinitely. This was done without Lack's knowledge and without her consent. She died less than a year later but her cells continue to live today. The story about what happened to her family when they discovered that their mother's cells had become famous twenty years later, as well as what advances in science have come about because of these immortal cells is fascinating.Most of the book's point of view is written while zoomed out and is easily understood. The family's plight and general information about vaccines, gene therapy and other scientific discoveries are all written with human interest details and never get bogged down with boring histories or complicated procedures. Occasionally, Skloot zooms in specifically on the HeLa cell and when she does, the microbiologist in me was fascinated. I worked for two years in a diagnostic virology laboratory and one of my duties was to regularly make more tissue for culture. Without any real thought, I'd take my bottles of culture, go into a sterile room, and perform each necessary step to take living cells and divide them into eight more bottles. Not once did I wonder where these cells had come from. Now, years later, I'm wondering. Were they HeLa cells? This is the part of the book I'm not sure is as easily digestible as the rest, but I find the cell and its parts an absolute wonder. I loved reading about what made Henrietta's cervical cells so virile and how that virility has caused havoc throughout the science community. I loved every single detail about its rapid mitosis and self-generating telomeres. I think Skloot's journalistic style to bring cell biology to the masses is commendable. In the end, I think this book addresses the real Machiavellian issue when it comes to science. Do the ends of scientific discovery justify the means? The world has made innumerable advances to understanding our bodies and every single one of us has somehow benefited, in one way or another, to having HeLa cells available to study. But, as the author points out by referencing the historical Tuskegee Syphilis studies and the atrocities committed by Nazi's to Jews at Nuremberg, human rights should trump science. Whether or not that line was crossed in regards to Henrietta's story and the family she left behind, is what would make this a really great book to discuss with others....more

review: I would have loved it had there been a bit more nuance to these characters. The angst. conflict and motivation to make the decisions they made and be I would have loved it had there been a bit more nuance to these characters. The angst. conflict and motivation to make the decisions they made and be the kind of mother/father/sister/brother they were was well developed but only their most lonely, most embarrassing, most traumatic moments were written. Enough time passed with reflection and memory that there had to be some good mixed in to survive that long...to love that much. I was told by the author that Lydia loved her mother, that Marilyn loved James, that Nath loved Lydia but why? Were they ever funny or a good listener? What made them so loyal to each other for so long in spite of the dysfunction and lack of healthy communication This is such a sad book but also very thought provoking. I thought about the expectations I place upon my own children, both verbal and non-verbal and wondered if it's too much. Not enough. What are the things they have never told me? ...more

title: A Man Called Ove
author: Backman, Fredrik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Pretty sure I'm the last person I know to read this book. It just had too much hype to appeal to me for a very long time but when I saw it was availabPretty sure I'm the last person I know to read this book. It just had too much hype to appeal to me for a very long time but when I saw it was available on Scribd as part of my monthly subscription, I decided to finally see what the fuss was about. I've always believed that it's hard, maybe even impossible, to hate people you really know. The human experience tells us time and time again that we humans are more alike than different and when we understand the backstory...the history and experiences and perspectives and values that shape a person...we are capable of great love. Fredrik Backman showcases this phenomenon of humanity through a grumpy old man named Ove (pronounced /u-vuh/) who has decided to end his life but keeps getting sidetracked and interrupted by annoying neighbors needing his help. Backman used a similar narration technique of describing characters with labels and then transitioning into names as they become better known in his more recent novel, Anxious People, which I really enjoyed, and have come to realize that he used it first in A Man Called Ove. I think it's effective narration. Pregnant woman becomes Parvaneh. Overweight man becomes Jimmy. The Young Man With Dark Stuff Around His Eyes become Mirsad. And all of these people who Ove dislikes or who he finds irritating or who he judges based on what he can see from an initial look or an initial encounter lose their labels when they become known to him. Interesting then that the man in the white shirt and the blond weed, both permanent antagonists of Ove, who never get to have redeeming qualities, also never get named. So, how do the labeled get names? How do they become known? By both needing help from Ove and by helping Ove. Ahhh....the great answer to humanity. To help and need each other. We can't and shouldn't do it all alone, as frustrating and disappointing that is to Ove. Sure, he can remodel his own home, back up a trailer without backup cameras and radar, fix a bike and brew his own coffee, unlike all of the other idiots around him, but when he realizes he can't buy an iPad, (because where is the keyboard?), and he can't stop all the men in white shirts from their bureaucratic tyranny and he can't see in color anymore without his beloved Sonja...he finally gets the help he needs and deserves from these same idiots. The dry humor, the hilarious and emotional symbolism of Saabs and Volvos and the onion-like layers that get peeled away from Ove's crusty persona through flashbacks all add up to a memorable and heartwarming story about what it means to be human. ...more

title: The Royal We        (Royal We, #1)
author: Cocks, Heather*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When Goodreads posted the nominees for all of its "Best of 2015" categories, I was shocked and dismayed that I hadn't read any of the books listed in When Goodreads posted the nominees for all of its "Best of 2015" categories, I was shocked and dismayed that I hadn't read any of the books listed in literature and fiction. Because when people ask what kind of books I like to read, I tell them, "Fiction and literature." I promptly got online and reserved every nominated book from my library and The Royal We was the first to come to my hold shelf. First of all, this is a pretty fluffy piece of fiction and literature. I know this because I have been unable to read anything with even a hint of seriousness or depth for months and I breezed through this. As the famous wedding kiss cover suggests, The Royal We is about a handsome and dutiful prince falling in love with a pretty commoner at college. I know. It sounds like a Disney movie. But, the writing is WAY above disney level and the characters are so much more than a Hillary Duff/Zac Efron (I don't think this Disney romance exists but you know what I mean) ensemble. Although the story line is not likely to be discussed by many English Lit classes anytime soon, it does have merit. It could happen. Ummm...it did happen?So, this is when I need to confess that I am a hypocrite. Once it was clear that this was a fictionalized version of the Prince William/Kate Middleton relationship, I had to pause and reflect about why I was enjoying it so much. Because I kind of condemned another book that did a similar thing. I ed American Wife by Curtis Sittenfield 7 years ago and blasted the author for taking such license with obviously recognizable characters: George and Laura Bush. I'm not particular fans of the Bushes but it seemed unfair at best and libelous at worst to write characters that were clearly recognizable figures, write salacious details about their relationship and lifestyle and then say, "No foul! It's all fiction!" I had no such reaction to The Royal We. Maybe the details were less scandalous, or perhaps the ocean that separates us desensitized me from their right to privacy and truth that much more but I thought this was a fun, thoughtful book. It's better than chick-lit because the writing is good and the characters and their choices are more complicated and nuanced but it's still something that could easily and happily be read on a beach. As glamorous and famous as the royal couple are, I sure don't envy them their lives. Even if it's only fiction, Cocks highlighted in her book just how tiresome and confusing it would be to be in a relationship with royalty. She had a picture perfect couple for inspiration and writes about a real couple, and not the oft-told fairytale. It would never get my vote for best fiction but it's an enjoyable book. ...more

title: Girl at War
author: Nović, Sara*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As a lover of fiction, I am quite fascinated by the length of time and distance required to produce compelling perspectives of historical events in a As a lover of fiction, I am quite fascinated by the length of time and distance required to produce compelling perspectives of historical events in a story driven format. I remember reading Suite Francaise years ago and being flabbergasted and impressed that the author was able to write THAT while simultaneously experiencing it. I think it would be incredibly difficult to be reasonable and write with structure instead of pure emotion. It seems that kind of immediate access to fiction is more rare. Perhaps 20-25 years is a good length of time because Girl at War nails what I appreciate about fiction. I grew up looking at maps that included a country called Yugoslavia. During the 1990s, when then news reported horrors of ethnic cleansing and genocide during The Yugoslavian War, or the breakup of Yugoslavia into Croatia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia, Slovenia, Kosovo, and Sprska, it all seemed too difficult to follow. Why were these people killing each other? Sara Novic doesn't use her novel to explain the whys but her protagonist, Ana, and her quiet suffering led me to search out more. Even after a bit of research, it is incredibly difficult to grasp that so much prejudice, cruelty and hate can exist within such a small border. But, I digress. Girl at War really is about a girl who lived through a war. It might seem insensitive of me to write this, but at the conclusion of this novel, I found myself thinking, "Ana only experienced a few weeks of terror and confusion at 10 years old and her life was still so messed up." I won't spoil the plot about those horrible weeks but she was loved by many before and after and it was frighting to think about how much damage fear and violence can inflict upon our psyches. I think about the millions of boys and girls who lives currently are surrounded by war and wonder how they will cope? What are we doing to each other? Considering the current refuge crisis as a result of civil wars in Syria, the seemingly never ending conflicts in the Middle East, the hate between Israel and Palestine, the violence in Mexico, the power grabs in the Ukraine, unstable tribal areas in Africa and so many more that for some reason or another, don't merit a mention in the news, the world is creating a generation of people who are affected. And, of course, none of this horror is new. It's the cyclical story of mankind since the story of mankind has been told. One difference is poignantly noted by Ana, "As a side effect of modern warfare, we had the peculiar privilege of watching the destruction of our country on television"This simply written, accessible, not-too-long novel, had me thinking about all of this. Girl at War by Sara Novic is incredibly timely and an important work of fiction about war and all of its damage. ...more

title: Station Eleven
author: Mandel, Emily St. John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I remember being in sixth grade and a friend smuggling her dad's copy of Stephen King's It into her bedroom so she could read to me a particularly gruI remember being in sixth grade and a friend smuggling her dad's copy of Stephen King's It into her bedroom so she could read to me a particularly gruesome and terrifying part (my memory only remembers something coming up out of a city sewage gate) and making the decision then, "No. This feeling is optional. I will avoid this book and books like it forever." Horror books are easy for me to avoid but when I read post apocalyptical books, I frequently wonder why I'm reading it and if I'm not just scaring myself on purpose. There are so many lately and I'm not even sure what led me to this book but it starts so innocently: an actor playing King Lear in Toronto having a heart attack and a former paparazzo now trying to be a paramedic with a bad girlfriend rushes up on stage to try and save him with CPR. It was just the kind of introduction that sucked me in...interesting characters doing something interesting but not out-of-this-world-so and before I knew it, everyone was dying of the flu and the survival meant luck and traveling in bands foraging for food in a dreary new world order with no order at all and in my soul, it was as uncomfortable as a scary clown monster coming up out of a sewer. More so, really, because I happen to think a pandemic (Or nuclear showdown. Or major natural disaster) are a little more likely to be my horrible than an "It." Nevertheless, I did read it and now I can't stop thinking about it. Because, as devastating as a pandemic that wipes out 99% of the population could ever possibly be, something comes after. It's not the end of the story. At least, our imaginations always allow this to be the case because there's no point in thinking or writing about the alternative (never mind. I can imagine words stopping mid page and hundreds of blank pages following it unto the back cover ends the theoretical nothingness. It would probably win an award). Although my mind likes to organize this story into the pre-outbreak, outbreak, and post-outbreak periods, the author, Emily St. John Mandel presents her world and characters non-linearly. It's quite artful how she threads all of these stories and characters together. If there is a main character, it has to be the actor Arthur Leander playing King Lear even though we know by the first few pages that he dies from a heart attack and not the flu. His location, his friends, his fame, his colleagues, his failed relationships...even the part he was playing when he died all eventually matter to this story and then when, why and how is what compelled me to keep reading through my nervous discomfort. It also helped that the setting of the book frequently returns to the more comfortable pre-outbreak time. There were times when I thought it would help to be from the midwest or familiar with the Toronto area and a lover of Shakespeare because his plays get significant weight but I enjoyed this book a lot even though I have never lived or traveled in this area, have only read Romeo and Juliet (which isn't mentioned at all) and don't particularly like to think about my world without any of its comforts that we take for granted. It is descriptive without being obnoxious about it, disturbing without being ridiculous and cautiously hopefully without being unrealistic. Mostly, I'd love to discuss this with someone and that's always a sign of a good book. Recommended. ...more

review: I really liked the end. I like that John Green writes novels that teens like to read. I like that he chooses to include important themes about living I really liked the end. I like that John Green writes novels that teens like to read. I like that he chooses to include important themes about living and decision making and consequences. I like that he doesn't gratuitiously embellish the issues that every parent of a teen dreads: sex, drugs, depression, disrespect and possible hatred of parent, etc. etc. etc. Still, those things are in all of his books and so it makes me squeamish to admit liking anything of his...even though I do. But, I don't love it. Not this book. I'm far too mature and comfortable with my belief in what living and dying means. And yet, I can see how an emerging independent teen would gobble up this disguised as a rebel-without-a-cause-but-what-have-we-here-moral-tale. It's crafty. So, even though it is full of foul language and uncomfortable-for-me images of teen sexuality, I liked it. Especially the end. ...more

review: Listened to this with my boys on a long road trip. I am forever in search of good audiobooks that we can all enjoy listening to in the car together. NListened to this with my boys on a long road trip. I am forever in search of good audiobooks that we can all enjoy listening to in the car together. Noting that this was written by a BYU professor (who is my age. Sigh), I figured it would be ok. I was definitely uncomfortable at times having my 8 year old listening when the narration veered towards the attraction between characters and the violence. The made up cuss words turned into an interesting discussion about what is swearing and how words become vulgar when used in certain ways. My older kids would easily give this 5 stars but I found the plot development very plodding at times. Much time is spent on the characters talking and planning and theorizing and it was tedious for me to listen to at times. But, overall, it was a good experience to listen to this with my boys. ...more

review: Can I "like" a book it took me over a year to finish? I'm feeling all sorts of ADD with books of late and it's embarrassing the number of books I've cCan I "like" a book it took me over a year to finish? I'm feeling all sorts of ADD with books of late and it's embarrassing the number of books I've checked out from the library and never read, started and returned unfinished, bought and shelved unopened and stacked with a bookmark placed somewhere in the first half of the book upon my nightstand. Of Human Bondage suffered from the Audiobook of 24 hour length, which always seemed too daunting to start unless I had several hours to devote to wearing headphones and the mood to follow the life of a pretty whiny, insecure man. That being said, this really is an excellent book that, I've no doubt, would have received more stars from me had I been able to listen to it in a more timely manner. Maugham, with a distinguished subtly, reveals a man's tendency to both limit his own experiences due to fear and prejudice as well as succumb to tempting and addicting vices, both physically and emotionally. These human flaws that each of us possess, create a restricted life: a situation of human bondage. The protagonist, Phillip Carey, is an orphan born with a clubfoot. Because the book spans Phillip's life until early adulthood, the only real continued arc that I perceived was his intense sensitivity about his foot and noticeable limp. It is his largest chain. Underneath that arc are several other subplots: Phillips's professional struggles, romantic entanglements, financial stress and tendency to be influenced by his friends. Maugham masterfully develops this character into a believable and universal human. Like I said, if it hadn't taken me over a year to finish, I'm sure I would be gushing more because it is so well done. I didn't know much about this book before I started it. I loved Maugham's A Painted Veil and heard this book was better and considered his masterpiece so my expectations were perhaps a tad high. Although well written, the story often fails to get traction due to its long timeline and many tangents about art and literature. Although Philip was a very flawed character, his kindness, even when reluctantly given, redeemed him. Being inside his head was very tiring at times but it was also....well...kind of incredible. Philip Carey and I have little in common on the surface but knowing him as well as I got to know him, it's impossible not to recognize a bit of myself in his struggles and triumphs. Fear, guilt, pride, ambition, lust - they chain us all. ...more

title: All the Light We Cannot See
author: Doerr, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am always somewhat surprised and amazed when I read a WWII novel that feels totally fresh. Most aren't. Sometimes, when a book describes a scary/cruI am always somewhat surprised and amazed when I read a WWII novel that feels totally fresh. Most aren't. Sometimes, when a book describes a scary/cruel/racist/ignorant/complacent Nazi/facist/Japanese soldier/offficer/citizen that treats a Jew/woman/artist/communist/child/POW horribly but, somehow, kindness and love rise above it, I cringe and cheer and ache for a better human race but also think, “I’ve read this story before.” I know the dangers of history repeating itself without learning from and remembering the mistakes from the past, and I do believe fiction can help spread a word of warning, so I’m not saying that this story isn’t worth telling. But, personally, I have read quite a bit WWII fiction and have started to avoid books that seem to be a remix of this oft told story (which IS an excellent story. Many of my favorite books have been this story). When I started to see multiple five star ratings of this book on my Goodread feed, I marked it as one I wanted “to read” but worried when I realized it was a WWII novel set in France and Germany. How could this possibly be something I haven't already read? While there are elements of familiar in it, like priceless art from museums being seized and stolen, brutal Russians taking their revenge on the innocent and the horrors of the Nazis conditioning the German youth with propaganda and jaw-dropping abuse, I had never read about the siege of Saint-Malo, France on August 6th, 1944. It is fascinating.Anthony Doerr takes this historically significant event and creates characters that happen to be there on that fateful and devastating day. Sixteen year-old Marie Laure is French and blind but incredibly independent thanks to her loving father who created perfect scale models of their neighborhood that she could touch and memorize in order to navigate around on her own. Eighteen year-old Werner is German and so good with radios that even though he is an orphan and poor, the Nazis place him in an elite school to train him to triangulate the position of anyone using a radio to transmit messages. Although Werner and Marie’s paths do not cross until nearly the end of the book, All The Light We Cannot See is about these two humans who love and lose and wish and want and regret and fear and although they are on opposite sides of the war, they both want to do the right thing....if only they knew for sure what that is. The writing will please any lover of language. The title (so good!) has layers and layers of meaning. The characters are perfectly imperfect, with flaws that don’t seem to be there just for the sake of having them but because they can’t seem to avoid having them. The plot builds fearsomely with some mystery shrouded in what appears to be fantasy and myth but still safely within the more logical borders of greed and luck. There is even a wistful and sad epilogue that sort of feels out of place in both time and feeling but also necessary because it adds meaning to the characters and the decisions they made in impossible circumstances. All The Light We Cannot See is a WWII novel but I have never read this story before. I have never been this fascinated by radios and trigonometry and descriptions of blindness and Saint-Malo and narrow houses with 6 floors and 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea and legends surrounding priceless diamonds. Truly, this is a five star book. ...more

Did I like it? No. I didn't. I thought the characters were unlikable and bleak. Sure, the setting had them in Italy during the end of World War II, when things were most likely the least hopeful and actions were the most desperate, but the war only partially influences these characters' motives and choices. They are, generally, a selfish, self-absorbed and unsympathetic bunch. I also don't really think the format of mixing a first person anonymous psychopath confessional, family saga set in 1944 and police investigation in 1955 worked well. I kept waiting to care more - about the horrible murders and the hidden motive and the back story of the female detective who was clearly suffering from the memories of her own past. So, why 3 stars? I didn't like it, even though my 3 stars claims that I did, but 2 stars, for me, is a book that is poorly written (I reserve 1 stars for books that I hate) and Bohjalian has talent. title: I Am Livia
author: Smith, Phyllis T.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was a surprise for me. I have become a bit into reading books on my ipad. I held out on having an ereader for so long because I love books..This book was a surprise for me. I have become a bit into reading books on my ipad. I held out on having an ereader for so long because I love books...love the way they feel in my hand...love they way they stack on my nightstand. But, I also know this about myself: I am a homebody. Ebooks and the kindle deals make it easy for me to avoid the library, a place I love but a place that requires me driving through traffic to get there and dealing with a toddler who doesn't seem to sympathize with my desire to stand next to a shelf of books, tilt my neck sideways and read the titles of thousands of book bindings. This path of least resistance has led to me reading a number of books I don't think I would have checked out at the library or bought a physical copy of from a bookseller. I Am Livia is the perfect example. The subject matter, a historical fiction rendering of the wife of Cesar Augustus, Livia Drusilla, isn't something I knew anything about or figured I was very interested in. Turns out, I really learned quite a lot about this time period and the major characters involved in the assassination of Julius Ceasar, his heir and his rivals. I've never been to Italy so the closest I've ever come to studying or carrying about the ancient Roman Empire is when I visited Israel last year and saw so many ruins testifying of their ingenuity, ambition and cruelty. This book definitely has a much more sympathetic opinion of the Romans and their building projects, defense of slavery and conquests, although those things were never the focus of the book. This was much more about the possible love story between a powerful leader and a woman whose own history is molded much more by rumors and speculation than known facts. She was, after all, a woman. Perhaps that's why I enjoyed it so much. The writing doesn't stand out as amazing, nor does the plot or characters, but it isn't void of compliments. I believe the author did a good job weaving her fiction into an actual history. I don't feel like I've been on a fool's errand and although I certainly can't claim any sort of expertise about the Roman Empire and these major historical figures, I no longer feel as ignorant. I like that. ...more

title: The Handmaid’s Tale        (The Handmaid's Tale, #1)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I just got on to the computer to finish this book  that I started writing three weeks ago and it was gone. A window closed by someone other thanI just got on to the computer to finish this book  that I started writing three weeks ago and it was gone. A window closed by someone other than me....erasing thoughts that I don’t really want to rethink. I have lost my habit of writing book s but I wanted to jot down my thoughts about this stunning book and be as articulate as I could because this story really affected me. I’m annoyed that I have to try and remember passionate reactions that have dimmed each passing day but hope that by writing this, I will be able to converse about this book in the future - a feat I am only able to do if I take the time to write about it. Here’s my take two!First of all, I think this book qualifies as amazing. That is why I gave it five stars on Goodreads. Not because I loved it and not because I learned something I didn’t know before but because the plot caused me to reflect on my gender, my religion, my politics, my government, my beliefs and my world. Furthermore, I believe my experience with The Handmaid’s Tale was enhanced by listening to the audio version narrated by Claire Danes. I just so happen to also be watching Season 2 of Homeland on Netflix and Claire Danes’ character in that series is brilliant but also suffers from bipolar disorder. Her voice, not a soothing one but filled with panic and confusion, absolutely lent credence to Offred, the handmaid in this tale, and her fear and paranoia about who she could trust in her instinct for survival. In addition to the effectiveness of Danes’ voice was the fact that, essentially, this story was given orally. Most of the book is narrated in first person until the very last chapter, which is an epilogue of sorts. In this final thought, the narration switches to third person where an academic lectures to an audience about his study of a collection of cassette tapes discovered and believed to have been reordered during what was known as “The Gilead Era.” The cassettes were transcribed into “The Handmaid’s Tale” and he added context, history and theories about who might have made them and what might have been her fate. So, I felt like I was actually listening to those recovered audiocassettes. It worked really well. I’ve wanted to read something by Margaret Atwood for years as she is a favorite author of a highly esteemed friend but I didn’t really know anything about her books or style other than I’ve seen The Handmaid’s Tale and Blind Assassin on several modern classic lists. Luck of the draw or fate or what have you led me to this book at just the right time. You see, I’ve been thinking a lot about women lately- our roles, our rights, our responsibilities - and Atwood’s dystopic look at how bad things could become as well as the conditions that existed in the society before it got to that point blew me away. Because more than any other book I’ve read that warns or imagines the way life could be....if....Atwood’s tale of subjugation based on ideology seems so possible. At least, it doesn’t seem so science-fiction-y or futuristic that it’s too difficult to glean the here and now similarities. That doesn’t mean I think women are eventually going to wear red habits or winged hats that limit their vision to straight ahead or even that I think Christian fundamentals are a dangerous threat to America but if Atwood’s Republic of Gilead could be placed in other parts of the globe, then it’s already happening. There are places, particularly those places in the news right now, where a woman’s right to education, personal style, marriage, economic independence and belief is dictated by someone else, usually a man. I just read an article yesterday about Boko Haram’s announcement that the more than 200 school girls his radical group kidnapped in Nigera back in April are now all converted to Islam and married to soldiers. I want to cry. These women are not valued beyond their gender and reproductive capabilities. As a woman who is grateful for my uterus, respectful of its powers and disturbed by so many’s casual disregard of it, still, I know that I am not my uterus. I am me. Influenced by my gender, certainly, but not contained by it.Segregation between the roles of women and men was certainly a major theme in Atwood’s novel but it wasn’t exclusive. Women were further segregated into “Aunts” (trainers and enforcers of other women - a governmental role), “Marys” (cleaners and cooks of households), “Wives” (elite but infertile) “Handmaids” (undecorated women given to a husband and wife for the purpose of conceiving a child) and the even less fortunate who were sent out to an area known as the colonies to clean radioactive waste and die. It was interesting to me that one of the tools to successfully isolate women was to pit them against each other. Don’t we do that a bit now?Another major theme in the book was the time it takes to transition between lifestyles and how this particular generation of handmaids felt sad because they could remember their former lives but that the next generation, conditioned to believe what they were doing was noble and best and not having knowledge of anything different, would have no regrets. I wonder if that is true. Certainly we can be conditioned to believe certain things but history has shown time and time again that there is an innate hunger for personal liberty and emancipation from oppression. Indeed, from the perspective of the epilogue, we see that this extreme society of Gilead did not last. It’s still shocking to me that there are some who would want to try. If I had any disappointment with the book it is that towards the end, the story got a little too caught up in the sexual needs, corruption and dysfunction within the society. But, who is to say that that actually wouldn’t happen when it is so unnaturally regulated? I suppose what I missed was Offred’s earlier voice that was used so effectively to explain the past to present. By the end, I felt like the story was hyper focused on her relationships with Nick and the commander. That disappointment, however, felt minor compared to the big picture ideas presented within Atwood’s storytelling. The slippery slope of governmental control. Personal rights vs. what is best for society. Religious persecution and perversion. What it means to be a woman. What it means to be human. All masterfully and accessibly told by Atwood. My immediate comment upon finishing this book was that I was “gasping with amazement and fear.” A month’s passing has stopped the gasping but I’m still amazed. And I still fear....more

title: The Rosie Project        (Don Tillman, #1)
author: Simsion, Graeme*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Rosie Project is a lighthearted romantic comedy that, in spite of itself, asks an interesting and emotional question: can someone on the autism spThe Rosie Project is a lighthearted romantic comedy that, in spite of itself, asks an interesting and emotional question: can someone on the autism spectrum (Aspergers) love and be loved in a romantic way? Don Tillman is a brilliant professor of genetics and enjoys his organized and structured lifestyle but would like a wife. Because dates usually go so poorly for him, he devises a way to sift through potential candidates through a detailed questionnaire. His requirements are impossible to fulfill for any one woman (and should there be that one woman, Don's own suitability would probably be in question) and, most likely as a joke or a dare or some other unkind motivation, his one adult friend, Gene, a professor of Psychology at the same university, sends Rosie over to Don's apartment. Rosie, unaware of the wife project, shares with Don her frustration of not knowing who her biological father is. Even though Rosie doesn’t fit his what-i-want-in-a-wife criteria, he likes her and offers his help in identifying her father through his ability to test DNA samples and their complicated friendship develops. Because of Don's inability to follow social norms, this development is filled with comedy. Intellectually, it feels mean to me to find amusement in another person's lack of awareness but Don is so smart and so unaffected by being considered weird that the book comes off as very fun. I doubt whether that is always the reality for those who live, love and work with people with Aspergers. I think the thing that was the hardest thing for me to admit was that there was no way I could ever fall in love with a man like Don. Interestingly, even though we are reminded through Don's character that he has few friends and has never be involved with anyone romantically, the ultimate question becomes can Don love someone in return? I appreciated the author's answer to the question and thought about Don and Rosie for days afterwards. That's good work for a romcom!...more

Not frothy light but light enough to allow me to escape into the history, action and romance without weariness. The best part of the story is set in Scotland in the 1700s and highlights the Scottish people known as Jacobites trying to plot the return of their exiled King James from France to rebel against the newly formed union of Great Britain. There is also a modern storm which alternates but it not nearly as enjoyable or believable because it involves an author who discovers that she is able to chanel memories from her ancestor who lived during the time and at the location she has moved to write her book. She throws in some medical terms to try and make it less hokey-pokey than it is (memories being passed along in the DNA much like nose shape and temperament) but I never believed in her trances that allowed her to write a perfectly accurate history in stream of conscious form. title: 4:09:43: Boston 2013 Through the Eyes of the Runners
author: Higdon, Hal
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My husband, a Boston Marathon runner, handed me this book to read while on a flight to Boston for this year’s marathon. He said it would give me a greMy husband, a Boston Marathon runner, handed me this book to read while on a flight to Boston for this year’s marathon. He said it would give me a great feel for what it is like to run the race. After reading, I agree with his assessment but can’t match his excitement because details like leg cramps, stomach pains, bloody toenails and “shredded” quads from running downhill don’t interest me that much and those kinds of details actually make up about 3/4ths of this book. Hal Higdon, a man I’ve never heard of but who assures me several times throughout the book that he is a big deal among runners (gag. But my husband did verify Higdon’s own importance and said most runners would know who he is) was not at the 2013 Boston Marathon but decided after reading blogs and Facebook posts and other statements from runners and volunteers who were there that he would recreate the race through the eyes of 75 different participants. I think it’s a pretty cool idea and reading about the race in short quick blurbs like that made for a much more interesting and complete picture than had he focused on just one person’s account or a generic historical account. He never claimed to be writing a book about the bombings and so I can’t really fault him for leaving out what I deem are important details, but it bothered me that when he mentioned the 3 spectators who died, he didn’t give their names but, instead, only a perfunctuary description of them. A 9 year-old boy. A Chinese woman studying at Boston University. A young woman who came to cheer on her friend’s boyfriend. Even though this was a book about the race and its runners, I wish he would have include the names: Martin Richard, Lu Lingzi, Krystal Campbell. There. Not so hard and so much more respectful, I think. If you are interested in the Boston Marathon and what it’s like to run it, whether you are an elite runner who plans on running or just someone who dreams of what it might be like to be cheered along those famous streets, it’s a quick and interesting read. ...more
