title: The Impossible Knife of Memory
author: Anderson, Laurie Halse*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the first book by Laurie Halse Anderson I've read and I'm not sure what I was expecting but it surpassed whatever those undefined expectationsThis is the first book by Laurie Halse Anderson I've read and I'm not sure what I was expecting but it surpassed whatever those undefined expectations were. The Impossible Knife of Memory is a YA story whose protagonist, Hayley, is going to high school for the first time after 5 years of being "homeschooled" or taught on the road by her trucker dad, an Iraq war vet suffering from PTSD. Like a lot of teens who have to prematurely shoulder adult burdens, Hayley lives in survival mode, enabling her delicate world to continue as is. Frustrations arise when the attention of a cute, likeable and aggressively successful boy, Finn, gives her first taste of what normal teenagehood might feel like. Like a fish out of water, she goes to her first high school football game, eats lunch with other kids her age and half-heartedly agrees to help with the school newspaper. As much as I enjoyed Finn's character (and he was delightful), his interest in Hayley lacked motive. He is so determined to win her over and she is so often unresponsive or dismissive back...I just don't know many teen boys whose egos can take such a beating. Still, their relationship and his support for Hayley is what drives Hayley to push for change in her own dysfunctional life. Her dad is a mess. I don't personally know any veterns who suffer from this disabling disease but the author describes his ups and downs in pretty bleak detail. In addition to helping her dad handle his minefield of memories, Hayley has to deal with her own haunting feelings of abandonment and loss, both from her mother who died when she was young and her dad's ex-girlfriend, who helped raise her but left when the going got tough. Although it deals with the darker side of teen life through secondary characters (drugs, promiscuity, divorce, co-dependency), I think the writing and issues presented make this a worthy choice for mature teens and interested adults....more

title: The Invention of Wings
author: Kidd, Sue Monk*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had no idea until the author’s note at the end of the book that this was based on the real life of the Grimke sisters from Charleston, South CarolinI had no idea until the author’s note at the end of the book that this was based on the real life of the Grimke sisters from Charleston, South Carolina. Knowing much of the story is based on fact helped me forgive the book for some of its unlikable loose ends and unproductive tangents. I see now that Sue Monk Kidd was painting a complete picture of these brave women pioneers and not just the parts that moved the story best. For the first few chapters, I really resisted liking this book. I didn’t know what it was about at all when starting and when I realized it would be about slavery, I had the weary thought, “I don’t know if I can read another book about slavery!” Such a juvenile thought because soon thereafter, I was completely drawn into the world of Charlotte, Hetty, Sarah and Angelina. While very definitely a book about slavery and its injustices and history, this is more a book about women. Charlotte and her daughter, Hetty, are slaves and while their bodies belong to a master, their minds are never chained to their situation. Sarah and her younger sister, Angelina, however, are born into wealth and privilege. All they have to do is marry into another respectable family for that life of ease and prestige to continue. Both eventually feel “chained” by their gender, never being allowed to follow the path of their own choosing. I had this thought while immersed in this book: Sarah, from a very early age, seemed to have an automatic and natural hatred towards slavery. I found that interesting. Her entire family enjoyed the benefits of slavery and her other siblings, even those of decent character, accepted slavery as the will of God. No one taught her to think the way she did. In fact, she had to constantly fight against her parents, siblings, clergy and others to protect her own proclivities. Angelina, on the other hand, was essentially raised by her older sister, Sarah, and I felt like her attitudes towards slavery was much more of the “nurture” type: learned. I often compared the two and their abilities to act on their beliefs. I wondered why it was so much easier for Angelina to be rash and daring in her abolitionist views. Was it because she never felt alone in her beliefs but always knew she had support from her sister? Is it simply temperament? I don’t know. Regardless, I think this is impressive historical fiction and I’m ashamed that I didn’t know anything about the Grimkes. I wonder why their courageous stances aren’t more well known? ...more

title: The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian
author: Alexie, Sherman
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Although this book can be crass at times, I really liked it. It is the story of a teenage boy living on the Spokane Indian reservation and realizing tAlthough this book can be crass at times, I really liked it. It is the story of a teenage boy living on the Spokane Indian reservation and realizing that he wants more out of life than what is being offered to him. That means changing high schools and being ostracized by members of his tribe who think his ambition translates into a personal insult. I loved the setting on a reservation and the unique humor and culture it highlights but this is the timeless story that those trying to break out of the box they are expected to stay in write. I think books like these are important for teens to read; they gain empathy for the great struggle fought by some and can learn the recipe of how it can be done should they need courage and insight. I chose to read this because of its consistently high s from other book lovers but, according to my sister, this is required reading for some high school students. Predictably, there are parents that are opposed to it. Are there other, less crude, less proud of masturbation, less full of alcohol alternatives teachers could choose to expose students to worlds beyond their own? Probably. But, this book is full of teenage humor, courage, spunk and has a very accessible protagonist to believe in and root for that I wouldn't be opposed to my own teenage children reading it. More importantly, it is deceptively well written. Filled with funny drawings, I bet a lot of "non readers" can enjoy a book with important and thoughtful themes that they might ignore or miss in another cleaner or classic book. Recommended!...more

title: The Map of Lost Memories
author: Fay, Kim*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was lured into reading this by the ease of the e-book digital library. Seriously, I think I love this system. As much as I love going to the libraryI was lured into reading this by the ease of the e-book digital library. Seriously, I think I love this system. As much as I love going to the library, there are times when it is isn’t convenient and I don’t have anything to read! That happened last week, so I got online and found this and downloaded it because it sounded promising. After the first 100 pages, I admit I sped read and skimmed. I had to get out of this book fast. Because, an interesting thing happened. I have a toddler and it just so happens that Sprout is his favorite channel. For a reason I truly cannot understand, this 2 year-old of mine particularly loves Caillou who I think is the whiniest, most irritating hypothetical 4 year-old that ever existed. Have you seen Caillou? First of all, there are the blurred corners. Like the animators are too lazy to actually finish the drawings. Then, there are the 1990s color scheme. Everything, from the houses to the clothes to the kitchen appliances are blue and red and yellow. I also don’t appreciate how frumpy they make Caillou’s mother. And the dad…oh my word. Does the guy have a real job? Just once, I’d like the show to highlight some real parenting and have either parent say, “I’m too busy to take you to that construction site you find so fascinating” or “I’m just going to tie your shoe for you” because there are teaching moments and then there we-have-to-go-right-now moments and not be at Caillou’s beck and call. Maybe I need to start the grumpy Sprout channel or something. Anyway, I mention Caillou because in addition to all these other annoying things, there is this obnoxious to me narrator who explains to us watchers (I try not to but what can you do when your 2 year-old needs to snuggle? Ack! I am just like Caillou’s parents! (frumpy mother included)) what Caillou is feeling in every situation. Seriously, as if the crease marks around his eyes and bald forehead aren’t enough, we get to hear things like, “Caillou felt frustrated that that cat wouldn’t come to him. He wanted the cat to go on a walk with him,’ in this weird, needs a lozenge voice. This is truly my worst, most snarky side that I try to contain to the realm of sprout cartoons but when I was reading The Map of Lost Memories by Kim Fay, there were sentences…many sentences…that were written in the exact voice of the Caillous narrator. Once the voice was there, every time the author told me how her smart, woman-before-her-time adventurer Irene Blum felt about anything, which was way too often, I visualized everything happening in primary colors with fuzzy edges. Not really but I shouldn’t connect Caillou to a grown-up book. And I did. Which is why I didn’t like this. It’s not terrible but I will forever have a negative association with reading it. Sorry to Kim Fay. If this book doesn’t take off, she might look into getting a job over at Sprout. ...more

review: This book shouldn’t have taken me as long to read as it did but I found the narration style incredibly hard to get into. Written like a fairy-tale thaThis book shouldn’t have taken me as long to read as it did but I found the narration style incredibly hard to get into. Written like a fairy-tale that’s just out reach, The Golem and the Jinni is part fantasy, part history, part romance, part adventure. Some of the parts I liked better than others but I can honestly say that this book is unique and unlike anything I have ever read. I ended up really enjoying both Chava, the golem, and Ahmed, the jinni (genie). I was fascinated by the folk history of these two mythological creatures and while the back story and friendship between the two created an interesting plot, the real beauty of this book is the moral weight Helene Wecker gives the stories by having these two non-humans question what it means to be human. What are our best attributes? What are our worst weaknesses? I can see this being added to reading lists everywhere because the compromises these two characters make, both to fit into their societies as well as for each other, not to mention the rich descriptions immigrant life in New York City at the end of the 19th century are great fodder for discussion. ...more

Maybe the flashy “Nobel Prize” winning emblem on her books finally made me take notice. I didn’t read the fine print, however, because I was surprised when I realized Dear Life is a collection of short store and not a novel. I honestly felt a bit broken hearted when the first story ended and I knew I wasn’t going to get any more of those characters. I have no doubt that I would prefer Munro to write novels because that is the format I enjoy best and because she is an absolute genius when it comes to writing nuance and that which can’t be seen. To pack so much feeling and personality into a short story is pretty incredible. I shouldn’t begrudge her her preference but I do wonder why and wish I could read something she wrote that could develop more plot, because everything else - her characters, settings, point of view, is perfect. title: Masterminds and Wingmen: Helping Our Boys Cope with Schoolyard Power, Locker-Room Tests, Girlfriends, and the New Rules of Boy World
author: Wiseman, Rosalind*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Rosalind Wiseman wrote the well known book Queen Bees and Wannabes, a book that I haven’t read but have heard about. When I saw this at my library andRosalind Wiseman wrote the well known book Queen Bees and Wannabes, a book that I haven’t read but have heard about. When I saw this at my library and read that its purpose was to inform parents about the new rules and realities of Boy World, like her Queen Bee book did for girls, I checked it out. Then, I missed two nights of sleep due to anxiety. Seriously. I’m sure the many boys she refers to as her “editors” and whose opinions and experiences she used as proof for what boys’ lives are like through middle school and high school are being honest and forthright about what their lives are like. I’m sure Wiseman uses these specific boys and their truths to create her generalities about how they communicate, why they torment, who they accept and what parents need to know with the best possible motives. In a lot of ways, this was every John Hughes film/Friday Nigh Lights/Glee episode I’ve ever seen (which isn’t a lot. Well…I’m pretty sure I’ve watched all the john Hughes films). In a nutshell, boys are told from a very young age that Batman, a mono-emotion superhero, is the ideal and straying from this model affects their standing among friends, girls and even adults. We expect boys to be boys: tough, clever, athletic and cool. In addition to exposing this Boy World, she explains to parents when and how to ask questions, when and how to be concerned about social media/videogames/pornography and what we’re all doing wrong by worrying about the wrong things. Queue sleepless nights. My overall feeling upon finishing this book is that, according to her and her helpful editors, I’m doing everything wrong. I ask too many questions, demand too much and pretty much live a hypocritical life. To summarize some of her points, I put him at a social disadvantage by not allowing violent video games (Rated M) and shows (TV-MA) because those are the things his friends are watching and playing and being able to discuss these things with their peers is vital to them feeling like they have a place in boys world and there has been no proof that exposure to violent media makes kids become violent. Girls are going to sext them so I should provide a smart phone, stop checking it after 9th grade and leave them with the advice that when those girls send them naked pictures of themselves, look at it for a minute and then delete it. I find all of this crazy! But, I checked this book out for a reason. My oldest child, an eighth grader, struggles to talk to me and after reading the “What kind of parent are you?” chapter, I think I fit into the “Dictator” mold which is pretty much the worst type of parent to be. The disparity between what I want for my children and what I’m probably doing for them is harrowing. I don’t know how to be cool or perfect. It sucks. I don’t think that’s the point of the book but….it kind of is. I found her writing style to be annoying close to arrogant (she admitted her own problems with her kids but very frequently uses her own parenting as a model). There was quite a bit of good information and I appreciate her advice but with my religious perspective and my own common sense, there are some parenting suggestions that I think goes beyond bad advice and is harmful. Does that mean my own bias is getting in the way? I don’t know. I tried reading with an open mind and I have stopped asking so many questions when my middle schooler gets in my car after school and I have a plan about how to handle homophobic jabs (boys are particularly prone to using them) and potential bad coaching. But, there is an entire chapter about boys playing Lacrosse. Lacrosse! It took that chapter, towards the end, for me to realize that her information is not universal. Still, her book is very eye opening and I’m not going to be naive about the possibilities and probabilities of what my children are facing and are going to face being active, sports-playing, boys. It’s going to be tough. ...more

title: Night Film
author: Pessl, Marisha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book felt extremely uneven to me. Part mystery, part horror film in print, part tour of New York City and upstate New York, and part “how to undeThis book felt extremely uneven to me. Part mystery, part horror film in print, part tour of New York City and upstate New York, and part “how to understand” black magic and the occult, I didn’t particularly enjoy the sum of all its parts. I love mysteries and this is a mystery, for sure. Scott McGrath is a disgraced and eager-for-redemption investigative journalist whose reputable career was ruined when he attempted an expose on cult horror film maker Stanlisas Cordova (think Stephen King but worse because Cordova’s films were so debased and horrible that they had been banned and watching them was only possible with bootleg copies or secret underground screenings). When Cordovos’s daughter dies from an apparent suicide, McGrath sees it as an opportunity to finally redeem himself and prove that, somehow, Cordova and his twisted lifestyle were responsible for her death. His discovery of the “whodunit” and, more complicated, the why, are actually quite scary. At least, I felt very nervous and tense at times. When it left the mystery and delved in depth into the horror film references, I wondered why I was still reading. I avoid horror films at all costs because I don’t enjoy scaring myself. I don’t want to know about torture scenes and absolutely terrified women. Remarkably, in the midst of all this tension and worry, I often felt bored by McGrath constant defense of his investigation as well as uninterested about the various plots and purposes of the made-up horror films he felt like we needed to know all about to truly understand the setting. Sometimes, I’ll ask my son about something he read or a movie and, instead of summarizing, he proceeds to retell me the story in as much detail as he can remember until I can’t take it anymore. I wanted to cut McGrath/Pessi off and shout, “Summarize the important point!” There is also a lack of cohesiveness between the known world and this occultist world surrounding Cordova and his uber-fans. The chapter that isn’t a chapter (all the other chapters get numbered but there is an entire section nestled between black pages) is hard to read. I’m sure it’s supposed to be but between the history of the past Cordova films and the surreal telling of McGrath’s journey, is so confusing that I ended up skimming. It didn’t seem to matter all that much. The ending, or endings, were very unsatisfying to me. I didn’t care for the conclusions about belief in occult or magic and I didn’t care for any of the characters’ journeys anymore. I did enjoy this as an ebook. It is my first time checking out an ebook from my library and I was surprised I lucked out choosing something so obviously made for the digital format. The story is filled with screen shots of web pages and newspaper clippings and those, in color and looking like actual web sites, looked perfect on my iPad. There was also something to download for an even more interactive experience but I was less invested by the time that capability was revealed. So…good stuff. Bad stuff. Boring stuff. Techie stuff. It’s a mixed bag for me. Good but not great. ...more

review: Why is it that some of the best humor is found embedded in the most unfortunate circumstances? Jonathan Evison writes a truly funny book about a man, Why is it that some of the best humor is found embedded in the most unfortunate circumstances? Jonathan Evison writes a truly funny book about a man, Ben Benjaman, who has lost everything. His wife. His children. His hope for anything good to ever happen again. Weaving his tragic backstory into his current job, caring for a young man, Trev, with advanced muscular dystrophy, Evison exposes something raw about us humans and why and how we love and care about others when it is so messy to do so.Besides the laugh out loud moments, I almost clapped for joy when I realized that Ben Benjamin was going on my favorite road trip. He describes a journey I have done so many times (travel on I-90 between Washington State and Montana and then south to Utah with a detour to Yellowstone) that I could see it almost perfectly. It’s all very accurate. Even the aptly described C’mon Inn in Missoula. It’s not always believable, not always clean (language and rude talk about sex) but Ben Benjamin broke my heart and made me laugh. I loved him. Definitely recommended if you’re not going to be offended by a rightfully angry 19 year-old stuck in a wheel chair with a huge chip on his shoulder. ...more

title: The Goldfinch
author: Tartt, Donna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Reading a book with as much hype as The Goldfinch is an interesting experience. Every sentence carries the burden of great expectation and each page iReading a book with as much hype as The Goldfinch is an interesting experience. Every sentence carries the burden of great expectation and each page is weighted with anticipated excellence. I certainly bought into the hype and, mostly, I was not disappointed. Until the end. I really disliked the ending.Donna Tartt has us readers invest in her flawed and well-crafted protagonist, Theo Decker, who from the very first page is clearly in some sort of trouble. After briefly being introduced to adult Theo, who explains that a dream he had about his mother is the impetus for the story to come, we are taken back to witness how an injured and traumatized 13 year-old Theo, disoriented and separated from his beloved mother amidst the mayhem of a museum bombing, innocently take a priceless and famous painting from the wreckage. Not knowing how to explain to the authorities or his quasi foster family (he goes to live with a wealthy friend from his school after his grandparents refused him) why he took it, and despondent upon learning about the death of his mother in the attack, he secretly keeps it, more out of fear than greed, turning a tragic moment of confusion into a soul-crushing crime that influences every future decision he makes. Just like Fabritius’s famous goldfinch, his life becomes chained to that painting.One part of the story that confused me a bit was the time span. 13 year-old Theo possessed an iPod and the setting seemed to be present day. But his future, older story-telling self also seemed to be set in present day. At least as far as I could judged based on how people communicated with technology. I couldn’t figure out if the explosion that set Theo’s tragic trajectory in motion was set in the past, like the late 1990s to early 2000s, or if his older, more ruined self existed in the future and it was sort of science-fiction-y without the science fiction. I pointed out my confusion to my mother, who had finished my copy from the library right before me, but she didn’t notice it (or care) so perhaps it doesn’t matter, but I often found myself troubled about the progression of time without any obvious progress in time. Not too troubled though, because the writing is so engrossing that I was mostly absorbed in whatever scene Tartt threw Theo into, whether it was in a ghost town, foreclosed neighborhood in suburban Las Vegas drinking Vodka with his Russian and equally neglected by his father friend, Boris, selling antique furniture with his rescuing guardian, Hobie, in lower Manhattan, or hiding from the Dutch police and Russian mafia in Amsterdam. Every shift in Theo’s world was fully developed and his guilt and obsession with The Goldfinch prominently staged as the major contributor to his mental decline. In that regard, I kept comparing this complex book to Poe’s The Tell Tale Heart or Dostoyevesky’s Crime and Punishment. For most of the 700 plus pages, I actually thought I was reading a modern retelling of either of those great accounts of obsession and guilt.Until I got to the last 60 or so pages. Everything was going along swimmingly…depressing, for sure, but good, well-developed depressing, when Tartt decided to go with the bad ending. I had forgotten, but the book did begin with Theo stating he was telling his story. Still, even with the first person narration, I never felt that meant that Theo was actually writing a story. Novels often use flashbacks or first person recollections, and Theo’s recollection, once started, proceeded in an orderly, chronological retelling. When the past caught up to present day and Theo began to refer to me as his reader, I felt jolted. The change in tone from recollective to persuasive irritated me for some reason. Suddenly, there was an intimacy in the story, a confessional conversation between Theo and me and I felt like the purpose and direction of the story changed. Instead of me neutrally observing Theo and the chaos his drug dependency and PTSD gave to his life, I was now required to sympathetically agree with Theo and his philosophies about right and wrong, good and evil, God and fate and agency and death. To be honest, I got annoyed. I wanted to get there by myself, if that was where the story directed me. It bordered on being spoon fed the moral of the story, as if the author didn’t trust me enough to figure it out, if there was anything to figure out, on my own. In my opinion, I would have loved for the story to end where it started, in Amsterdam, with Theo’s personal Road to Damascus experience. I would have loved to have wondered what he did after that.Can an ending I dislike ruin an otherwise incredible book? A little bit. I think this book is stock full of wonder and literary gold. But, like the cliche goes, that last bite left a bad taste in my mouth....more

review: Sarah M. Eden writes regency romances with enough pain or conflict or strife that they avoid being categorized as foofy, in my book. That isn't to saySarah M. Eden writes regency romances with enough pain or conflict or strife that they avoid being categorized as foofy, in my book. That isn't to say that her characters are very nuanced or even believable, but she gives them enough stress that I root for them to find relief. Drops of Gold follows a pretty self-reliant orphan who goes to work for a lonely and unhappy widow and his young daughter. Their attraction to each other is almost immediate as he is physically gorgeous and she is ridiculously cheerful. That sounds more obnoxious than it is but I do think Eden could have toned down those qualities just a bit and still had a fine romance. What didn't work and what I don't understand is the dead-end development of some of her plot points. Why mention the high number of nursemaid turnover or the petty treatment from the rest of the house staff if those things weren't going to impact anything later on. It didn't fit but I'm not going to spend too much time on this . Overall, it was a pleasant few hours of reading for me. ...more

title: Attachments
author: Rowell, Rainbow*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love books that make me stay up way too late because I don't want to let the story go. Attachments, by Rainbow Rowell, is a very sweet story. It's nI love books that make me stay up way too late because I don't want to let the story go. Attachments, by Rainbow Rowell, is a very sweet story. It's not saccharine sweet because the characters are all desperate and flawed enough to understand how their lives could easily not be awesome and yet, they are all funny and romantic and self-aware enough to seriously root for. I read Eleanor and Park earlier this year and loved the way it made me feel about first love as well as the nostalgic look at the 80s. Attachments feels very different in that while the heartache is there, the brutality of bullying, abuse and fear is absent and so the entire book has a very lighthearted, hopefully vibe. It is set in the late nineties, when Y2K was in the worrisome future and using the internet at work was still new and confusing to bosses and employees alike. As I stopped working in April of 2000, after the birth of my first child, the whole setting - lengthy email conversations (now people text or facebook message or snapchat or whatever), wardrobe descriptions, pop culture references, - it was like pushing play after a lengthy work break. I don't know how work places have really changed! The protagonists is male and the book is written in his POV, which is easy to forget as many chapters are copies of email exchanges between two women: Jennifer and Beth. My only complaint about this entire book is that I truly struggled to differentiate between these two women. Their voices were incredibly similar. I enjoyed that singular voice, because they were funny and self deprecating and definitely produced the laugh-out-loud humor of the book but I had to look at the name inside the <...>s or else I wouldn't know who was speaking unless they were referring to their significant others (who were very different). The conflict is so very fun. How do you strike up a real relationship with someone you have been stalking and the backstories that flesh out the characters through memories and conversations give weight to a sweet and fun romance. Definitely a fun book that is worth the yawns today!!...more

title: The Sound of Things Falling
author: Vásquez, Juan Gabriel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Just a few months ago, I had the thought, "Why isn't there more South American settings for contemporary fiction?" I love getting both a historical anJust a few months ago, I had the thought, "Why isn't there more South American settings for contemporary fiction?" I love getting both a historical and modern day look at what it means to be human but feel like I read a lot more books set in Africa, the Middle East, Europe and Asia if I'm not reading about the good ol' U.S of A (and Canada. They are similar). But, whether by choice or neglect, my image of South America isn't very well rounded. I've read a few magical realism books, which aren't my favorite, but figured that most women from the south don't solve their problems with a mortar and pestal, nor do the majority of the men wear white button-down linen shirts and sell drugs. You see the problem with my literature stereo-types. That's why I was excited when I read a  about this book set in Colombia. Yes, it is about drugs but it is not about the white-shirted men. At least not directly. Instead, this beautifully written book (it is translated from its original spanish and very, very good), is about living in Colombia during the drug wars and what it means to be human in an area that is plagued by random violence, political corruptness and dangerously powerful drug lords. Immediately, I was impressed by the author's introduction to Antonio Yammara and his very modern-feeling life. He drinks coffee at a sidewalk cafe. He teaches law at college. He could be living in Seattle but, no, he's living in Bogota, Colombia, a capital city I didn't realize was so cold and remote, and when he describes his new friendship with a quiet and mysterious man named Ricardo Leverde, who is rumored to have spent time in prison for "something bad" I could see between these men the effect of mixing the notorious and the modern Bogota. The attempt of living in the present in spite of and because of a weary past. By the book's end, through memories shared, letters written, and a desperate search to make sense of the senseless, I was treated to a vibrant and interesting look at what happens in the background of a violent and unstable place. I expected a book about Colombia, a country that has never even crossed my radar to visit because of its association with drugs, to be about its violence and cartels. Those things are there but not the focus of the story. If anything, there is a notable lack of either. Instead, this is a look at love, loss, reconciliation and change. The title kept me thinking of the unanswerable question,"If a tree falls in a forest, and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound?Antonio Yammara and Ricardo Leverde could be those trees - falling in a forest that lacks listeners - and the sounds they make to those who love them is quite heartbreaking....more

title: The Last Letter from Your Lover
author: Moyes, Jojo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After completing my third Jojo Moyes book in a short period of time (all motivated by my interest and response after reading Me Before You), I think IAfter completing my third Jojo Moyes book in a short period of time (all motivated by my interest and response after reading Me Before You), I think I have figured out Moyes style and I love it! Although I haven't liked The Girl You Left Behind or this one as well as Me Before You, I do commend the author and her versatility and use of fiction to engage thoughtful debate about a topic of morality. The Last Letter from Your Lover takes on infidelity, a topic that should have an automatic negative response but Moyes manages to explore it in a way that doesn't make you automatically hate the guilty characters. The setting alternates between the male-dominated world of the 1960s and present day. A woman wakes up from a car accident with a shattered memory, and doesn't understand her reaction to her unfeeling husband and lifestyle until she discovers a letter from someone who only addresses himself as "B". She realizes she must have had an affair before her accident and with painful self-discovery, tries to figure out the details. This entire story line is very Mad Men-esque. The second story line follows a woman-of-the-world journalist, in a frustrating affair with a married man, who discovers one of the letters between the 1960s lovers. It's desperate feeling, along with the threat of losing her job from her unimpressed editor, moves her to discover who the lovers are and if they got a happy ending. The ending is a little too neat but I still liked it. I appreciated the characters' growth and admissions of wrong, as well as their drive to love and be loved. ...more

title: Rose Under Fire
author: Wein, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Last year, I read and enjoyed Code Name Verity but never got around to ing it. It is an intriguing look at the lives of female pilots and femaleLast year, I read and enjoyed Code Name Verity but never got around to ing it. It is an intriguing look at the lives of female pilots and female spies during World War II. With two protagonists telling their stories in similar voices, I admit to being confused a time or two about who was who and who was where but the twist at the end and heartfelt climax won me over. I was excited to learn that Elizabeth Wein had released a second book, Rose Under Fire, that contains some cross over characters from CNV. As in Code Name Verity, female pilots are once again on display. Rose, the single protagonist of this story, has been flying since she was twelve. She deems herself as worthy and experienced as any male pilot and feels restless going on her never-ending plane delivering services. She is also tired of living in fear of being bombed, as London and military bases around England were constant targets of pilotless bombs sent from the Germans. When she hears a rumor of how to bring these bombs down, just by messing with their air dynamics with some daring flight maneuvers, she imagines playing the hero and doing just that. During one of her delivery responsibilities, she gets her chance. Unfortunately, her extracurricular pilot activities catches the attention of patrolling Nazi pilots and she escorted via plane across the front and into Germany. From there, she is sent to Ravensbruck, a work camp for women. The conditions there are every bit as horrible as described at other concentration camps, but Wein reined in her focus to a small group of women held at the camp. Rose, through mistaken identity, finds herself in the company of a detainees known as "Rabbits" because they were victims of cruel medical experiments. Mostly Polish by nationality, their stories, mixed together with Rose's poetry about their and her experiences make for some powerful story telling. The deprivation these women experienced is highlighted with Rose's quick demise from confident curly-haired-blond-and-lipstick-wearing-pilot to a sickly, shorn, scared and fearful prisoner in just six months. I wonder what criteria has to be met for books to be categorized the way they are. Is it up to the author? Publisher? Are the librarians all in cahoots as to where they want to shelve these books? Because, I really can't figure out why this book is cataloged as Young Adult Fiction. I suppose the main character, Rose, is only eighteen at the start of the novel but she isn't in high school and there are no parents' thumbs anywhere near any of her decision making. She is an adult in very adult situations. I remember thinking this same thing with Code Name Verity. They are great books for adults. Definitely OK for mature teens but I think there is a significant portion of fiction reading adults who dismiss YA because it brings books like Twilight to the masses. This should be brought to the masses. Wein mixes her fictional Rose with real history and actual heroes and villains at Ravensbruck (also a real camp) and allows their stories to be unlocked from history with her quite spunky writing. I really enjoyed this heartbreaking and hopeful tale. ...more

title: My Story
author: Smart, Elizabeth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Before I write a single thing about this book, I want to make it clear that Elizabeth Smart gets ten stars for being an incredible human being. She isBefore I write a single thing about this book, I want to make it clear that Elizabeth Smart gets ten stars for being an incredible human being. She is strong and resilient and articulate and heroic. The work she is doing to help other victims of abuse is commendable and awe-inspiring. Her story is definitely five stars. I am giving her book, My Story, three stars because as a memoir, it is lacking some essential elements. For starters, I felt like this was a one emotion story. Smart experiences terror, humiliation, hunger, hope, despair, fear, pain, embarrassment, anger, gratitude, relief, love and more and yet, all of those emotions had to be experienced through Smart's 26 year-old disdain. She really, really doesn't like Brian David Mitchell and Wanda Barzee. Obviously, that is an understatement. She no longer fears the pair who kidnapped her and kept her hostage for 9 months when she was only 14 years old, and she claims to have forgiven both as far as not holding on to any anger but, instead, moving on with a happy life, but there is definitely a tone throughout the entire book that sees them both as ridiculous, evil, narcissistic and manipulative and her attitude is felt throughout the entire book. I certainly give her every right to feel those things but my issue is that it made her 14 year old self less accessible. She explains her terror at being awoken in bed by a black-clothed and bearded man holding a knife to her throat but the terror is missing. Likewise, she never sidesteps the horrible fact that she was raped daily by a delusional and disgusting man but, again, her 26 year-old hind sight and determination to escape that psychological damage changes the horror of the act to an almost cursory sidenote. There is an interesting display of LDS theology throughout the book. One doesn't need to be a member of the LDS faith to understand it but I think the dichotomy of his warped faith and her powerful belief shows the fruits of both. One could easily pick up one without the other and say, "See what this faith does?" and have equal ammunition to attack and compliment. Something happened in the lives of Brian David Mitchell and Wanda Barzee to see some of the less understood and more sacred theology and justify seriously hurting a 14 year-old girl. Elizabeth describes it as pure evil. She dismisses and repeatedly reproves any other justification, including mental illness on their parts. She certainly makes her case as Mitchell/Emmanuel is portrayed as the worst kind of hypocrite and abuser. Likewise, there is no doubt in my mind that Elizabeth's faith, and the love and acceptance of her family, in particular, her mother, are what allow this woman to not just survive but thrive. She believes that Christ and God's love can heal and she proves it to be true. It is amazing. I guess what I'm saying is that this book, My Story, her story, is told with the weight/blessing/presence of hindsight and it affects it. It does. I'm so glad Elizabeth gets a happy ending and even happier that she recognizes that her and all of our happiness is a choice but wish, from a reading perspective, that I could have experienced a little bit more of her story with her. Regardless, this is a powerful story about perseverance and the extraordinary strength of the human spirit. ...more

title: The Girl You Left Behind
author: Moyes, Jojo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The more time that passes, the better I like Jojo Moyes's Me Before You. Moyes combination of humor, romance, morality, conflict, development and remoThe more time that passes, the better I like Jojo Moyes's Me Before You. Moyes combination of humor, romance, morality, conflict, development and removed judgment in that book impelled me to search out more of her books. I picked up The Girl You Left Behind and was struck by how different it was. Usually, an author's doesn't stray very far from their comfort zone and I can pleasantly say that I don't know what Moyes's schtick is. The Girl You Left Behind  deals with two women, a century apart, who find solace in a painting with that very title (convenient, but it works). Sophie, a young french woman whose artist husband has left to fight at the front during World War I, looks at her own portrait and the provocative and challenging eyes that stare back at her gives her the courage to withstand and even stand up to the German soldiers who occupy her town. When the German Kommandant takes an interest in the painting, Sophie hopes the painting will be her ticket for survival. A hundred years later, the painting is a beloved honeymoon gift from her husband to Liv, a depressed widow much too young to be left dealing with the loneliness and financial strain left by her brilliant architect husband's death. When an architectural magazine features a story on her husband and includes a picture of the room where the painting hangs, a legal battle ensues when the heirs of the artist claim it is rightfully theirs and must have been looted during the war years. Liv, like Sophie a hundred years before her, sees the painting as the source of her strength and as a symbol of what once was and the story of its provenance and ultimately what happened to Sophie, is slowly revealed. I enjoyed both women's' stories but really think Moyes shined best developing Sophie in her provincial French town. The purpose of the title is felt throughout the book, something I always appreciate, but Sophie's pluck made her more endearing than Liv's desperation. Another feat of brilliance is including so much information about art and personal property restitution. Moyes made the issue even more complex by placing the art loss in World War I instead of the much more infamous and obvious looting by the Nazi's during World War II. That confusion is addressed in the book and greed, rights, and ownership are all investigated. Smart writing that will have me searching for even more Moyes work and I hope she comes out with more soon!...more

title: Blackmoore
author: Donaldson, Julianne*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Fluff" is sometimes used as a descriptor of books. When I think of fluff, I think of pillows, clouds and marshmallows. I sleep on a pretty firm pillo"Fluff" is sometimes used as a descriptor of books. When I think of fluff, I think of pillows, clouds and marshmallows. I sleep on a pretty firm pillow but I always, always hug a really fluffy down pillow while I do so. I don't know much about clouds but the fluffy cumulus type are probably my favorite because I can find shapes in them. And while I never crave marshmallows, they make a drink of hot chocolate, rice krispie treats and those chocolate Easter eggs delightful. In other words, fluff has its place in the good world. Blackmoore, written by Edenbrooke's Julianne Donaldson, falls into the enjoyable fluff category. That isn't an insult. I've been reading a lot for the past few months (it always seems to come in spurts like this) and this was the first book I read in one sitting. It was easy, romantic, and written well enough to be able to admit to reading without embarrassment. Thoroughly predictable and sorely lacking in real conflict, Kate, not Kitty, is a likable protagonist who is in love with an even more likable romantic interest, Henry. I didn't find either's behavior very believable but that's ok. I liked that they were kind, thoughtful people who didn't want to hurt the other, bucking the more callous and selfish behavior traits displayed by both of their other family members. My only complaint, really, is that because the conflict didn't really exist, none of the book's drama matters much. (view spoiler)[ Kate runs away and goes to India without any consequence and Henry chooses his own bride and loses his estate and is totally fine! What's with all the imagined stress? Oh, that's right. Because not all would really be fine in a real 1820s world with a male and a female in the gentleman/lady class who made decisions like these two did, but it works in the name of romance!  (hide spoiler)]. It would have been more interesting to have a bit more confusion or competition on either or both of their paths to romantic enlightenment. Donaldson tried but it is clear throughout the book that there is no way either of these characters would/could/should end up with anyone but each other. Couldn't Henry go through a brooding and less appealing phase as he tries to transition to the gentleman of Blackmoore? Perhaps Miss St. Claire could have been more likable and less of a puppet or Mr. Barrows, a completely inessential character, it turns out, less eager or more appealing? Take away Eleanor's scandalous story and allow Kate, who is described as beautiful, to be pursued at Blackmoore, forcing Henry to decide if he'll actually let his childhood friend slip through his adult fingers. At the very first mentioning of Henry being "The Giver of Your Heart's Desire" in reference to a cat, it was beyond obvious that that very line would be used to wrap things up nicely at the end. I like the happy ending but, please, let my heart break a little in the middle so that I can be happy for the happy ending! A perfectly acceptable, clean, proper read that won't really matter much in terms of literature or fiction, but like its fluffy buddies, it makes life a little more sweet the day you read it. ...more

title: Push
author: Sapphire*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm horrified that the kind of existence this young girl, Precious, experiences can happen in a country like the United States. A girl who is impregnaI'm horrified that the kind of existence this young girl, Precious, experiences can happen in a country like the United States. A girl who is impregnated, by her own father, at the age of 12, who lets authorities at the hospital know, who can't read or write or speak without using the most profane kind of language because it is all she has ever heard or known, should send up a red flag...to someone. Anyone. A teacher. A principle A social worker. A nurse. The neglect, abuse and treatment she receives is as bad as any girl/woman in any book I have ever read. The fact that there was no war going on, no vacuum of power that typically brings out the very worst in humans, but simply that a girl was born to parents who never, ever should have been parents and raised in a place that must be almost immune to sad life stories makes the alarms go off in my head. Not fair! Help her! Save her! Stop whatever cycle of human depravity these people exist in!It seems to stop. At least, we readers are led to hope that the potential is there for it to stop. It took a principle who, unlike the movies, wasn't some kind of pure-hearted hero but someone who realized she made a mistake in kicking Precious out of her school for being pregnant at 16 and set up an opportunity for Precious to attend an alternative school. She had to shout her information through an apartment intercom over the cursing and belittling of both Precious and her horrible mother, but some of the information stuck and because some part of Precious's soul must have realized this could be an out, she went. And a life began to change. This isn't an easy book to read. Sapphire, the author, writes as Precious would speak. During the narrative when Precious would write in her journal, the writing becomes nearly unreadable (thankfully, there is an italicized translation underneath it). As the story progresses, the writing becomes better, never great, but we can literally see the improvements made by Precious. I'm not sure I loved the structure. As important as the women in her alternative school were to her, this was not their story and the inclusion of their journal entries/stories at the end was distracting and subtracted a bit from Precious's own push to improve. I think had this been non-fiction, I would have been a bit more forgiving of both these first person accounts as well as of the repetitive memory loop Precious could not seem to escape reliving the moments of abuse by the hands of both her mother and father. Even as her writing and reading improved, her emotional stability seemed as fragile as ever. When it is revealed at the end just how young Precious was when the abuse began, I can't help but wonder if she could ever really be better. Can anyone survive that kind of life? I don't know. Even after finishing, I still don't know. Hard, hard book to read. ...more

review: Ugh. This book had so much going for it until Sarah McCoy decided she needed to make this book, which originally had characters rooted in situations rUgh. This book had so much going for it until Sarah McCoy decided she needed to make this book, which originally had characters rooted in situations requiring compromise and murky moral decisions, and turn it into a rah-rah happy ending epilogue. I honestly thought I was going to read a real effort to compare the difficulty most not insane or racist but patriotic Germans faced during the horrors of World War II and the current mess of illegal immigration and border control. In other words, what not insane or racist but patriotic Americans are now deciding what side of history they want to be on. With delicious imagery of warm baked goods and pretty German names laced throughout it all, I was enjoying the weaving and connecting of two women, a generation apart, who witnessed horrible things but still tried to reinvent themselves as they wanted to be. Then, McCoy took on too much and needed to put a pretty ribbon on the end of every story and character introduced and I didn't believe any of it anymore. Worse, she totally abandoned her modern moral dilemma: the border crisis. Disappointing!...more

review: I should have like this more but I found it all so heavy and depressing and ultimately, uninspired or unique. A family had a past that seems to screw I should have like this more but I found it all so heavy and depressing and ultimately, uninspired or unique. A family had a past that seems to screw them all up and the subsequent generation suffers too. Throw in a east coast sensibilities and a really underwhelming social commentary about modern day immigration (not Hispanics since it takes place in Maine, but, rather Somalis escaping from their war-torn country) and in spite of the talented writing, I felt tired all the time. I wondered for more than half of the book if I was going to get an actual plot or just reactions to an occurrence from a list of characters. There was a plot. It involved two brothers with the last name Burgess, hence the title, but that title is misleading because a lot of the book is about the Burgess boy's sister, Susan, and her son, Zach, who throws a frozen pig head into a mosque in the tired town of Shirley Falls, Maine where all three siblings were raised by their single mother. A tragic accident that killed their father in their youth haunts all three and affects them all in different ways. Jim and Bob have both become lawyers and it is they who Susan desperately turns to when charges are filed against her son. It's all very heavy and messed up and although the characterization is good, I totally bought that these three adults were as messed up as they were, it wasn't enlightening or purposeful or entertaining or new. I suppose every person's psychology should be worth a story but...after two days of reading, I'm not sorry I'm finished with this book. ...more

title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: Salinger, J.D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Embarrassing admission. I have heard about the angry Holden Caulfield for decades. I also knew this was a banned book and blamed by some for having beEmbarrassing admission. I have heard about the angry Holden Caulfield for decades. I also knew this was a banned book and blamed by some for having been used as inspiration or motivation or...whatever, for various crimes. After all, isn't The Catcher in the Rye considered THE angry teenage boy book? That's what I thought, anyhow. Those bits of second hand knowledge learned along the way convinced my brain that Holden Caulfield and The Catcher in the Rye were synonymous with horror novels. Classic horror novels, but horror novels nonetheless. I don't do horror. I think my aversion to being scared on purpose kept me from discovering what this book is really about all this time. Turns out, Salinger is not a pre Stephen King. Perhaps I was thinking of that movie Children of the Corn. Rye...Corn. Both crops grown in midwest fields. An innocent mistake. In actuality, this is quite a tame book. Sure, we are exposed to the manic stream of consciousness narrative of Holden, a rich, neglected, traumatized and mentally ill teenage boy, and his thoughts do sometimes verge on disturbing. But, most of the time, he's thinking about girls or food or smoking. His manic state takes him to some dangerous situations but, luckily, his money and connections keep him from any real danger. And yet, it is a classic. A beloved and life changing classic for many and so, in my underwhelmed and relieved I wasn't reading about a slasher in a rye field state, I kept asking myself, "Why is it?" Because it wasn't for me, I can only surmise that perhaps it resonates more with teenage boys and not a middle aged woman. I tried to remember my own angst as a teen but I was never that melancholy or judgmental of my world. Maybe I can say that because my parents would have realized I was missing for several days and maybe that is because I never associated with the wealthy and pretentious schools Holden kept being forced to attend but it is probably mostly because I didn't self-medicate a mental illness possibly triggered by a sibling's death or sexual abuse with alcohol. I also think its likely immortality may be due to when it was written. Nowadays, teenage dramas are very popular and it is not uncommon to read about teens in various states of self-discovery, depression, school rebellion, romantic awakenings or shifts into adulthood. It would be interesting to know how many authors of these types of book think about Salinger's classic when creating their tales. Years ago, I wrote a  about Pearl Buck's The Good Earth and I had similar thoughts after finishing that book as I did upon finishing this one. Is it a classic because it was the first? The Good Earth brought the orient and its mysterious to the masses but many more have been written since with greater accuracy, detail and, frankly, in my opinion, better stories. I wonder if this is equally beloved because it took us into the mind of a troubled boy before anyone else bothered. I'm no historian, so I don't really know. Besides The Good Earth, I was reminded of another classic while reading: Sylvia Plath's The Bell Jar. While reading the beginning of the book, I did not recognize any great feeling within the book. If anything, the scattering of thoughts and quick shifts between subjects kept me from feeling anything at all. I wondered if the writing was somehow superb but all of the old fashioned language of "grand" and "phony" didn't convince me. I thought, "Maybe Salinger just really nailed the lazy and disjoined grammar of a teenager," but, then, certain phrases started to appear out of the blue and poor Caulfield's extreme mental fragility startled me. By the end of the book, I felt quite down. I was supposed to, right? I remember reading The Bell Jar and feeling as suffocated as the character Esther and appreciating the author taking me to a place mentally I wouldn't naturally go. Although I never felt like Holden Caulfield and only recognized his great pain, I think I did catch the mood of the book. Perhaps those more permeable to his specific situation are the ones who go on to commit these crimes I have heard about that, in turn, make others wish to ban this book. Finally, I loved the title. I wish I knew the tune of the song referenced as its inspiration. I have never heard of a fable or song or folklore where someone catches someone in a dangerous situation but I think it is clear that Holden both wanted to be caught and realized that some personal healing could come from helping others and forgetting himself. I think Salinger wrote a bit of brilliance in framing his main character with having this desire, and thus the meaning behind it, but really giving it to another, lesser known character in a simple outing at the end. So, what's a lover of books supposed to think about a book that she did not particularly like or love but can recognize as original and powerful? Lump it with other three star books that are poorly written and historically forgettable? It's books like this that make me don't love the rating system but, there you go. I liked it. ...more

title: Proof of Heaven: A Neurosurgeon's Journey into the Afterlife
author: Alexander, Eben
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not sure how to rate this book. In terms of sincerity and courage, I would give Dr Alexander's account of his spiritual journey while in a coma fiI'm not sure how to rate this book. In terms of sincerity and courage, I would give Dr Alexander's account of his spiritual journey while in a coma five stars. Considering his profession, his reputation and the cynicism ever present in today's society, it really is a marvel that a man with no financial motive and not seeking a spiritual following would make the effort to share something so personal and hard to explain. In terms of readability, however, it really is more of a three star book. Alexander repeatedly fell into the trap of telling instead of showing and the telling too often veered from what he stated he was going to tell. A double whammy. I am a believer in the after life. Reading about NDEs (Near Death Experiences) don't really add or detract from my faith. I actually haven't read many personal accounts but have heard lots of stories about bright lights and loving feelings and meeting up with loved ones who have previously died. The argument against theses experiences usually stem from the very medical field wherein Dr. Alexander specializes: neurology or neurosurgery. These phenomena of awareness outside of the body or memories of consciousness when considered medically dead are explained as delayed neuron firings; a chicken running around with its head cut off, if you will. Possible but not live movement. A reflex. Alexander does a decent job of explaining why his experience was different. First of all, he teaches the important difference between "heart attack dead" and "brain dead" and how the latter is really the only kind that counts in medicine. Apparently, almost all of our consciousness comes from an area of the brain called the neocortex and his was essentially dead. The coma that came from a bacterial meningitis infection shut this part of his brain down, and his proof (which he never shoed. I suppose it is too complex to include in a diagram in a paperback book) was the plethora of imaging done on his brain during his intensive illness. He was in this coma for a week, a very long time to survive this type of meningitis, and describes a journey during that time to a place that is full of love, learning, and futuristic abilities to communicate, travel and understand. He never describes himself as a body but more as an identity. He was who he is. The companion with whom he traveled he did describe in bodily form so I suppose he makes his case for a body-like existence in the after life as well. Obviously, I can't get into his descriptions as they are hard enough for him to describe. I don't feel like he did a very good job explaining his experience in this afterlife, even though that is both the title and description of his book. Instead, the majority of pages are dedicated to taking the reader through his background, his family life, his medical training, his illness and what others were doing during his illness. It was a bit tiring, to be honest. I'm sure his family is lovely and all backstory helps to understand the larger picture, but in this case, I felt like it robbed me of more knowledge of what he experienced comes after. He claims that he remembers everything perfectly and it is merely the limitations of his bodily brain that keep him from translating his experiences more clearly. I certainly didn't feel like he made things very clear. I'll give him the benefit of my doubt, however, because I think that the afterlife must have a much different vocabulary than our earth life. At least he tried. There wasn't much about his account that felt silly or wrong to me. His knowledge and feeling that because of his medical background, he had a scientific responsibility to tell his story, felt almost prophetic to me. As a believer in prophets, it does make me curious why he was given this knowledge and so little instruction on what to do with it. I don't think it would make a believer out of a non-believer or really change someone's mind who already believed in an afterlife into thinking his experience is exactly what our own post death moments will be like, but I am glad this man told his story. I think it is life affirming and full of hope: two things that add much to our present life experience. ...more

title: Me Before You        (Me Before You, #1)
author: Moyes, Jojo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really liked this. I almost loved it. My bias steals a star from an emotional and well-told story. I didn't read anything about this book before staI really liked this. I almost loved it. My bias steals a star from an emotional and well-told story. I didn't read anything about this book before starting it. I only saw favorable ratings from a few friends and added it to my list without so much as reading the blurb on goodreads, something I never do. When I visited my library and saw it available on the very day I heard about it, I checked it out and kept my ignorance intact by forgoing reading the book jacket. The librarian then said, "Ooooh. A book about (view spoiler)[assisted suicide. (hide spoiler)] How do you feel about that?" which annoyed me greatly. With my pathetic passive-agressive response on full display, I shrugged and didn't reply. That'll teach her to stick to what should be known by every librarian and book seller: that if I don't ask...then don't tell!!!! Seriously, I could have slapped her. And by could have, I mean I would never ever do something like that. I feel like that pre-ejaculated knowledge from big mouth librarian kept me from getting the point of the book until a day or so after I finished. I always contemplate the meaning and reason for a book's title and kept thinking it was such a weird way of summarizing selfishness. In other words, I thought that both of the main characters in the story, Lou, a woman with no personal ambition who takes a job as caretaker for a quadriplegic to help pay her parents' bills, and Will, a former big shot now suffering from pain and indignity in a wheelchair, struggled to be motivated to act beyond their own wishes and goals. They both had much different views about how life should be lived. In spite of the change that happens to both Lou and Will when their worlds collide, each kept putting their "me" before the other's "You." But, after logging on to write this  and finally reading the goodreads blurb, I see that the title is clearly intended to reflect the changes that happen to both characters upon meeting. I totally get it now. They do both change. In beautiful ways. Just not enough for me, in the end. I thought Jojo Moyes treated this heavy subject brilliantly and left enough ambiguity to challenge anyone's preconceived views about choice and what constitutes a worthy life. While there is a bit of rah-rah attached to the story, thanks to Will's views, that life needs to be lived extremely and boldly, I don't think that is what the author is telling her readers. I dismiss that moral because I think it is both wrong and over reaching. There is a poignant conversation during the book between Lou and Will when she asks Will if he thinks his inability to adapt to his new situation is because of how he lived before. He rejects her theory and I suppose it's possible that with his reply, we are also to reject that idea, but I don't. I have studied happy people and unhappy people and I guarantee that bungee jumping and climbing Mt. Kilamanjaro, impressive as they are, aren't the key to happiness. Neither is having lots of sex or making millions of dollars. Again, I stress that I don't believe Moyes is trying to sell that kind of life. By using her two chracter's contrasting lives, I think she effectively shows that happiness is a state of mind. It is not our jobs or even our relationships. The fact that I stayed up until 2 am to finish reading and then had horrible dreams and fragmented sleep illustrated just how much affected I was by reading this. It disturbed me. I liked it but cannot quite resolve my anger towards one of the characters to love it. I hope I was a bit more ambiguous than that librarian. Perhaps I should forgive her. It is hard to do. ...more

I like shopping at Old Navy. I tap my toes to most top 40 songs. Halloween tries my patience with its weirdness. So, I wasn't really expecting to enjoy my second Neil Gaiman book as much as I did. The Ocean at The End of the Lane reminds me of Roald Dahl's book. While I tend to appreciate Dahl's books, rather than like them, Gaiman got past my preference for normal by sandwiching his bizarre with brilliant meaning. In spite of my inability to imagine some of his more intangible descriptions, like the ratty fabric in the sky with teeth, I absolutely engaged in both the fear felt by the memories of a 7 year old child and protection provided by the wise and calm Hempstock sisters. How it all came to be, hinging on memories rekindled by setting, with my comfortable normal just within reach in the background, is believable, even though I know it can't be. review: A good book. A heavy book. A sad book. There is no happily ever after for some people and that cycle of violence, drugs, poverty and ignorance is highA good book. A heavy book. A sad book. There is no happily ever after for some people and that cycle of violence, drugs, poverty and ignorance is highlighted through Ree's struggle to provide for her family at only 16 years old. The stunted emotional opportunities that result from her dark and paranoid world filled with clan loyalty, drug dependence and all sorts of abuse is as unfamiliar to me as the book I just read about the war in Sudan, Africa. I feel outraged that some live like this. It feels strange that the writing is so lyrical. Although I haven't seen the movie based on this book, I saw the p (which is what compelled me to read the book first) and I can understand why some think the movie adaptation is better. I think film has an advantage in storytelling hard living than literature. The fancy language and poetic tone didn't match the education level or aesthetic preferences of the characters and its hard to invest in Ree's journey, beautiful as Woodrell's descriptions are. A good book, but I didn't love it. ...more

title: The Cuckoo's Calling        (Cormoran Strike, #1)
author: Galbraith, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Without a doubt, Rowling is a gifted writer. One can understand her desire to release a novel without the she-wrote-Harry-Potter fanfare and to get siWithout a doubt, Rowling is a gifted writer. One can understand her desire to release a novel without the she-wrote-Harry-Potter fanfare and to get sincere, unbiased s. I wish I had read this without knowing Galbraith was a pseudonym. I can't pinpoint exactly why, as I feel neither starstruck nor overly critical with my , but it would have been fun to believe that this impeccable writing came from a first time author. Since it comes from her...well...it should be good. There should probably have been a semi-colon somewhere in the first paragraph. Heaven knows, Rowling would have found a place to use one. I have never, ever read a book before where the use of a semi-colon appears so freely and assuredly. I'm certain most authors understand how and when to use a semi-colon so I'm very curious what a grammarian or author thinks about Rowling's frequent choice of pausing without a period. I'm sure she used it correctly. Not being a semi-colon user myself (it takes me too long to figure out if I'm using it properly), its appearance sometimes slowed me down as I would pause and wonder why she chose that form of punctuation in that sentence. I'm a bit embarrassed to admit how often I stopped to think about this. More than an author of a whodunit novel, where there is usually an element of urgency, would like, I'm sure. Overabundant usage of a lesser-understood punctuation mark is not a deal-breaker, however. Obviously. It's just something I noticed and then couldn't stop noticing. Perhaps she's like Justin Timberlake and "bringing the semi-colon back." Now that my own neurosis has been addressed, I'll get to the book at hand. It is decidedly good. I'd even go beyond my reigned-in praise and say it would be great except for the jack-hammering use of the F-bomb and her sometimes out-of-place show-off vocabulary. Both felt unnecessary. I am pretty forgiving when reading characters who would swear, swear. Not everyone has the ability, temperament or education to use good language. It bugs me when those who have all three still do. This book is filled with characters like that. They are vulgar because they choose to be and that wears on me. Fashion designers, actors, models, producers, and the rich and vapid all swear like soldiers. Then, in the same sentence, Rowling would reach deep into her thesaurus and use beautiful and obscure descriptive language. it was an odd and unsettling combination, to me. What did work brilliantly was Rowlings pacing of The Cuckoo's Calling. Never frenetic, and never veering into a hard-to-follow tangent, I was totally absorbed into Cormoron Strike's detective work. The clues and interviews and piecing all kept my interest and the big reveal was neither impossible to figure out or obvious from the start. I also really liked the characters. Not the yucky ones, although they were interesting when they weren't embarrassing me with their gutter-language, but the main protaganist, Strike, and his temp secretary, Robin, were nuanced, believable and well developed. I don't know if Rowling sketched out the arc of Strike's story on a restaurant napkin, like she did for Harry Potter, but you can see that she intends to take this detective and his relationships with Robin and ex-fiancee, Charlotte, somewhere in books to come. I can't wait to read what comes next. ...more
