title: Heft
author: Moore, Liz*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For most of this summer, I have unwittingly been selecting what can only be described as anti-beach reads. In an attempt to add some levity and relaxaFor most of this summer, I have unwittingly been selecting what can only be described as anti-beach reads. In an attempt to add some levity and relaxation into my reading, I read a fluffy "beach" read last week and felt a bit exasperated at its stupidness and general falseness. Then, I picked up Heft, by Liz Moore sort of desperate for a good book. Alternative titles could be "Heavy" or "Burdened" or "A Boulder of Sadness on my Back" but I think Moore was wise with her choice of Heft. The book is narrated by two characters: Arthur Opp, an obese 58 year-old recluse and Kel Keller, a popular 17 year-old boy who lives in poverty in Yonkers but attends a posh high school where he does his best to hide his real life. The author connects them through Kel's alcoholic mother, Charlene, who was once a student of Arthur's when he still taught, but their stories never intersect. That might be giving too much away but the way Moore unfolds their stories, parallel but relevant to each other, is really well done. I look at her picture on the book jacket and she seems young and pretty and successful and I wonder how she nailed the absolute loneliness these poor souls experience. In one description of Arthur's shame and remorse and obsession with food, I got teary. I want every person who ever says, "Fat people just need to eat less!" to read it and understand the complex psychological issues that come with overeating. Mostly, I loved the glimmers of hope at the end. As determined to be alone as both Kel and Arthur seemed to be, their only refuge from despair was to connect with another person. After reading, I feel determined to greet strangers with a smile and show kindness wherever I can. And when I see someone who is so overweight or a teenager that is acting out a bit, I want to remember that that person is possibly walking around with a huge boulder of sadness on their back. Quite possible the saddest book I've read this year. But, it's also one of the best. ...more

title: A Constellation of Vital Phenomena
author: Marra, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Last night, I went to dinner with some friends and told them about this book and how much I was enjoying reading it. Of course, thy asked what the titLast night, I went to dinner with some friends and told them about this book and how much I was enjoying reading it. Of course, thy asked what the title was and when I said, "A Constellation of Vital Phenomena," they both said that it was too confusing to remember. I agree with them. It is odd and seemingly senseless. The beauty and perfection of this hard-on-the-tongue title revealed itself on page 184, however, when Natasha, the beautiful but left behind sister, who is holed up in her Chechen communist apartment block, trying to escape the cruel and lawless civil war that uprooted her entire life, reads this banal statement in The Medical Dictionary of the Union of Soviet Physicians, the biggest and heaviest book she could find on her surgeon sister's bookshelf: Life: a constellation of vital phenomena - organization irritability, movement, growth, reproduction, adaptation..Even though I had been enjoying the story thus far, because and in spite of the non-linear storytelling, when I reached that proclamation of purpose, my brain did this zoom-out thing and the pieces of the story, which are a lot like some of the complicated and advanced quilts I saw on display at the county fair a few weeks ago, started to take form. Using the author's constellation metaphor, it was like all of these different patterned and various hued yellow fabrics, which have no business being together except for their general yellow-ness, became a star. A really interesting and important star. A work of art, really.The rest of the novel went much quicker as my brain zoomed in and out when necessary. The individual fabrics of motivation, background, family life, disappointments, abilities, aversions and hope from Dokka, Akhmed, Havaa, Sonja, Natasha, Khassan and Ramzen pieced together to educate me, a protected and blessed woman in the peaceful Rocky Mountains of the United States about modern civil war, specifically the one in Chechnya between the years of 1994 to 2004. To be fair, "modern" is probably an exaggeration for the villages, cities and hospitals built in the former Soviet Union, but phones went from working to not working. Gas went from available to a black market commodity. Safe drinking water was for the lucky and rich. Employers and employees disappeared and all that was left to fill that great vacuum of energy and productivity were mobs and the military. Even though it is historical and not dystopian, I kept acknowledging the warnings given: this could happen anywhere. This could happen to me and my loved ones. The educated were not exempt from suffering. The beautiful were not exempt from suffering. The loyal, the traitorous, the young and the old - all suffered. For what? Sovereignty? Maybe. A religious movement? At first. Like all wars, eventually, all that was left to fight for was power. The power to live and not be tortured, sold, or "disappeared" for information. Horrible.Using well known biblical stories of struggle and purpose, the question of responsibility to family, to other generations, weaves through it all. Abraham, and God's commandment to sacrifice his son as well as the sacrifice of parents to orphan their children in hopes of saving them (Moses are repeatedly asked. What are we to learn from these recurring lessons on life? That it is sacred? That it is fleeting? Frequently, the author would pause a story briefly to share a glimpse of a character's future. It felt like a gentler handling of a technique used in action movies when the shot freezes with a certain character on screen so that important information can be given. That little stretchy pause added both to the beauty and intricacy of this artful novel. It had the effect of filling in the dark sky with distant stars. This is what great fiction can do:make the lessons from different life experience available to all who read. I pray and hope that I never find myself and my family making the kinds of sacrifices or decisions that are required when at war. Should I be so lucky, I need to remember that every day, millions of people throughout the world are not. The Syrians and Egyptians are in the midst of this very kind of conflict right now and the world watches when convenient or if an atrocity is vicious enough. It is a story on constant repeat. And yet, in that definition given in the medical dictionary for Soviet physicians, there is also growth...adaptation...reproduction...movement as part of it all too. it seems there is no government, mob or military that has been able to control or drive out the human acts of generosity and kindness with their brutality. Fathers and mothers continue to love their children. Friends die for each other and people give up glory and comfort to do the right thing. These were the shades of yellow I liked best. It gave this beautiful constellation of stars depth and comfort and tenderness. I loved Dokka and Ahkmed and Sonja and Natasha and Havaa and Khassan and I pitied Ramzen, even though none were perfect and most did unforgivable things. How tender were their brutal lives. Highly recommended. It is not an easy read but it is so, so worth the effort. ...more

title: The End of the Affair
author: Greene, Graham
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you prefer optimistic love stories, stay far, far away from this Graham Greene novel. Set during and a few years after World War II in England, a lIf you prefer optimistic love stories, stay far, far away from this Graham Greene novel. Set during and a few years after World War II in England, a love affair occurs between an author, Maurice, and a married woman, Sarah, and Maurice, with his bitter, depressed and unforgiving point of view, tells the story of how their relationship ended, began and wilted. At first, I thought this story served to highlight the obsessive and jealous nature of man and, ultimately, to convince that emotions of hating and loving need each other to exist. It certainly never felt romantic, even when Maurice describes his infatuation with Sarah and their passion for each other. In fact, it reminded me a bit of Wuthering Heights: more a display of obsession than love. Then, it rolled and despaired into the question of God's existence and forgiveness and miracles and prayer during war. I actually preferred this plot trajectory over the embittered memories of Maurice and by the book's end, really felt like I had thought and wondered and realized. Plus, it didn't hurt AT ALL that I listened to this and Colin Firth was the narrator. He has a fabulously proud and bitter and sexy voice and it was very easy to imagine him loving and ruining a woman. Not uplifting but really good writing and, ultimatly, very thought provoking. ...more

review: The Unlikely Pilgrimage of Harold Fry is actually a very sweet book that gets weighted down by unnecessary side stories. An unhappy man in an unhappy The Unlikely Pilgrimage of Harold Fry is actually a very sweet book that gets weighted down by unnecessary side stories. An unhappy man in an unhappy marriage, but much too stiff upper lip to acknowledge the emotion in either case, decides to hand deliver a letter to an old associate. This requires him to walk across the whole of England and, like Forrest Gump's cross-country run, he picks up strays, fans, and wannabes along the way. I liked the soul searching and resourcefulness this pilgrimage required from Harold but didn't actually believe a man his age, with his life experiences, emotional tendencies and in his physical condition would find the kind of outcome Joyce gave him. So, while I liked this book and thought she did a nice job examining depression, nothing that happened seemed very likely or necessary. And that is a bit depressing. ...more

review: If you're a fan of romances and the story of Romeo and Juliet, this story is probably right up your alley. It's mostly clean although there is a bit oIf you're a fan of romances and the story of Romeo and Juliet, this story is probably right up your alley. It's mostly clean although there is a bit of totally unnecessary language that doesn't belong at all. I am pretty tolerant of language in books if its use fits the circumstance or character and neither criteria was met here.The author attempts to showcase the historical lore behind the classic Romeo and Juliet story. I enjoyed learning that Shakespeare was most likely not the creator of the star-crossed lovers tale but merely produced the most famous rendition. I also enjoyed being taken back to medieval times, even if the speech and actions of the main characters didn't seem very authentic.The modern day romance is what really annoyed me. I have found this to be the case in a lot of stories set up like this. Coming immediately to mind is Sarah's Key and Possession (although it works better in Possession) but I did not believe or care about the romance between the discoverers of the historical mystery. In fact, their conversations were torture for me. I felt like I was reading a very novice author (think high school level) writing dialogue. Oh, she definitely had a thesaurus at hand for the word "said" and used "whispered" "gloated" "hissed" "moaned"....just about any word other than "said" but if felt terribly trite and juvenile to me. When I finished the book and learned that the author grew up and only moved to the US in 2002, it almost explained the irritating use of English. It just didn't feel natural.Like I said, if unbelievable dialogue doesn't bother you and you really do like Romeo and Juliet but want to learn about some different twists to the well-known tale, you might like this. Unfortunately to this book snob, all that "hissing" and "moaning" ruined it for me....more

author: Atkinson, Kate
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Another unfortunate victim of my expectations being too high before reading. I'm not sure what I missed but reading Life After Life felt a bit like drAnother unfortunate victim of my expectations being too high before reading. I'm not sure what I missed but reading Life After Life felt a bit like drudgery instead of bliss. I think I get the concept. A character, Ursula, dies repeatedly but then gets chance after chance to live her life again. She experiences feelings of extreme deja-vu and sometimes, but not every time, makes a different decision than in a previous life that leads to a much different outcome. Sometimes, that outcome is better than the life before but most of the time, it just places her along a parallel but equally miserable trajectory. Did Ursula know what was happening to her? In a few chapters, it seemed like she was fully aware of her reincarnated state, particularly at the end (and beginning because the author repeats the opening scene that, with context, means something) but, most of the time, it seemed as if life was just happening again and only after a strong premonition, usually an overwhelming feeling of terror when approaching the scenario in which she previously died, but not actual knowledge, did Ursula do something different that changed her history. And that's another thing that bugged me. She really only ever changed her own history. Oh, she saved a couple of different lives a few times, but usually, the same unfortunate end came to most of the background characters. It was like this unspoken and really unsatisfying argument about the supposed butterfly affect (could one person's decision change the course of history?) and fate (if it's meant to happen, it will no matter what). Both occurred so...which theory wins? The writing was vivid, characters were enjoyably fleshy and the concept pretty imaginative, although Groundhog's Day and Sliding Doors can both claim to have come up with it first, but, overall, I feel disappointed that I didn't like it more. ...more

title: When Women Were Birds: Fifty-four Variations on Voice
author: Williams, Terry Tempest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A mother gives her daughter her journals, requesting that they only be read after her death. When posthumously opened, the curious daughter discovers A mother gives her daughter her journals, requesting that they only be read after her death. When posthumously opened, the curious daughter discovers multiple journals are all filled with blank pages. Why?Terry Tempest Williams uses 54 chapters to wonder. I loved the concept and execution of this book more than I loved William's voice and edgy opinions. Partly, that is due to her dismissal and bias against a church she has left and to which I still belong to. All I can say it is akin to having a cousin bad mouth your own family. Yes, they know them and those might be their opinions of things that happened once upon a time, but it doesn't make them true or current or fair. This referencing of the LDS (Mormon) church certainly is not the focus of the book, but as her mother was a faithful member and the daughter is an unbeliever, Williams' wonderings can't help but delve into the spiritual motives, longings, grudges and aspirations of her mother, many laden with LDS dogma. This quote at the beginning of one of the chapters had me snort out loud. I can't recall it exactly as the book is no longer in my possession but it says something along the lines that all LDS women hold two things sacred: their responsibility to procreate and have offspring and to keep a journal. There certainly is a sacred responsibility and reverence towards motherhood but I have never, ever been told it is part of my job, because I have a uterus, to keep a journal. Certainly, some women do. Lots of LDS women blog, which is sort of modern day journal keeping (plus bragging and showing off) but part of that has to be attributed to a high percentage of them (us) finding a creative outlet and purpose beyond laundry and taxiing. I know that's why I started to write. But, her flippant, know-it-all-because-I-grew-up-in-Utah-and-went-to-BYU attitude towards the church is more self-serving than true. At the very most, it is outdated. Perhaps some of the attitudes and traditions that she saw a child in Utah growing up in the 60s and 70s were present, but she has to give her mother more credit than being a brainwashed LDS woman as a reason for a blank journal. Defense of my religion aside, Williams is a beautiful writer who really evokes strong images and feelings in her poetic phrasing. An environmentalist who knows a lot about birds, she draws images of life and movement from birds and attaches them to human experience and the result is moving and life affirming. We are our world and our surroundings and I liked thinking with her about women: our strengths, passions, limitations and voices. An interesting read for me and one I'm glad I picked up. ...more

title: Eleanor & Park
author: Rowell, Rainbow*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At my children's "country" elementary school, the library there also serves as a branch library to the rural community. It is small but does usually hAt my children's "country" elementary school, the library there also serves as a branch library to the rural community. It is small but does usually have a copy of the hard to get a hold of new release so, if I'm picking up one of my boys, I often go in and find something to read. The librarian working is always the same woman and we have gotten to know each other during check-out and return times. How much do I love that she had a book I had never heard of reserved for me just because she thought I might like it? A lot. She had just finished reading it and said, "I kept thinking you'd like it as I read it." This is so strange because we really don't know each other but maybe she knows me better than I know her since she knows what I read. She was right. I really liked it. I was a pretty normal teenager. Honestly, I think every teen feels like a big freak but I usually don't relate to books like Perks of Being A Wallflower because I was involved and had friends and did sports and all that "uncool" stuff to those who rebuff the mainstream either by choice or by force. I couldn't finish Perks because of all of the sex and drugs but this book was able to highlight the difficulties of kids who don't fit in without making either of the characters degenerates. I adored Eleanor. I loved her thoughts and her insecurities and her coping skills. I hated her family. I wondered which kids I ignored because of their clothes or weirdness might have had home lives like Eleanor. Park was a little less believable to me because his isolation seemed more self-imposed. Still, there is a moment in the plot when Eleanor and Park are in an English class and studying Romeo and Juliet and the teacher is trying to engage the students to think why such a sad story has survived the test of time as well as it has. Predictable answers are given until Eleanor suggests that it reminds people what it feels like to be young and in love. This book does just that. I never had a high school romance as intense as the one experienced between Eleanor and Park but I have fallen in love and the description and progression of that magical discovery that someone likes you just as much as you like them is perfect. The nuanced secondary characters, awesome 80s references, tragic backgrounds and formidable odds to overcome made this read that much more sweet. ...more

review: Having only read Erdich's book, Shadow Tag, previously, my expectations were low and cautious as I began her National Book Award winner The Round HousHaving only read Erdich's book, Shadow Tag, previously, my expectations were low and cautious as I began her National Book Award winner The Round House.  I'm glad I tried again because The Round House is pretty worthy of its hype. I didn't love it because I felt it unnecessarily crude at times as well as curiously infuriating but there is no denying the craftsmanship of the writing - from the weaving of a mystery, coming of age and folklore - to its scope of highlighting the unique problems of the Native American tribal justice. Even though it fell short of becoming a favorite of mine, reading this book brought light to ignorance and made me care about fictitious characters, hallmarks of worthy books, in my opinion.As for my gripes, the protaganist, Joe, is a 13 year old boy who sometimes seems 13, sometimes 8 and sometimes 20. I know that age can be difficult to capture.  Heck, I have a 13 year old so I get it. But his behavior was so peculiar and unpredictable. Still, his world was ripped apart with the violent crime against his mother and the stress and tension it created within his once peaceful home. There were many times throughout the novel that I felt irritated and impatient with Erdich for taking me on another teenage escapade filled with all the language and crassness of boys in groups. Those events eventually contribute to the heartbreaking finale but it was not very pleasant to be repeatedly treated to what a boy thinks about breasts, dirt bikes, beer and food. Maybe I'd have given this book five stars had Erdich's 13 year old been a bit more virtuous:-)This is compelling literature about contemporary Native American life. It corrected more than one stereotype of mine. Rich with symbolism, this is the kind of book that should be read....more

I went to Israel last year and upon returning and hoping to extend my memories and thoughts for as long as possible, I picked up this wonderful book written by someone who has spent a great deal of time studying the life of Christ and has lived for an extended time in the land where he lived. What makes this belated  unfortunate is that this is an Easter book. Huntsman breaks apart Holy Week and dissects what happened and when according to the four Gospels in the Bible as well as what scholarly research supports. In addition to just facts and information, Huntsman also includes helpful ideas on how to make the sacred week truly celebratory such as beautiful music about certain days or miracles as well as scriptures and hymns to focus on and enjoy during the week. He lays out a well-defended argument that this holiday should be as celebrated and revered as Christmas and families can do a lot to make it more than day of new dresses and candy. He does share my LDS belief but I do think any believer of Christ will appreciate his research and organization in presenting the last week of Jesus Christ’s earthly life. ...more

title: The Wednesday Wars
author: Schmidt, Gary D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am so glad I picked this up on a whim at the library. Actually, I picked up Gary Schmidt's Okay For Now on a whim and when I saw that he had a NewbeI am so glad I picked this up on a whim at the library. Actually, I picked up Gary Schmidt's Okay For Now on a whim and when I saw that he had a Newberry Winner called The Wednesday Wars and the blurbs on the back said it was just as good as his award winning The Wednesday Wars, I went back and got that book instead. It is adorable and funny and tender and insightful and historic and frustrating and well written! I have only ever read Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet and it just about kicked my tail (I find the movie adaptations easier on my brain) and my only eyebrow raise is how easily a seventh grader seemed to digest and comprehend that old English style. Regardless, his enjoyment of Shakespeare and his subsequent application and interpretation of his famous plays exposed the very motivation and connection I feel with reading: that art imitates life, or vice versa, and we can gleam the human experience through any generation with books. I can only imagine how delightful a well-versed Shakespeare love would find this book. It's more than the smart use of Shakespeare, however, that make this so much fun to read. Holling Hoodhood's relationships with his friends, he teachers, his family, as well as his embarrassments and triumphs make this a compelling read. As a warning, it is juvenile literature. The shenanigans and conflict feel young, even younger than a current-day seventh grade boy might experience, because it is set in 1968 when schools were run differently and polite society had a much different emphasis. However, I actually found that innocence and conservativeness a much more effective story telling method than the crassness and shocking nature of todays young adult literature. Whether a seventh grader finds is as relevant will soon be discovered as I've already passed it on to my own almost thirteen year old son. I can't wait for him to read it!I heartily recommend this book to all readers of any age. It was really, really good....more

title: The Secret Keeper
author: Morton, Kate*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Kate Morton is one of those authors that found a successful niche in literature and has been reaping the rewards from writing novels that women like: Kate Morton is one of those authors that found a successful niche in literature and has been reaping the rewards from writing novels that women like: smart family dramas involving generations of women,  a mystery from the past that needs to be solved all set in picturesque England. Really, I don't know why I have only finished two of her novels and not all of them.I thoroughly enjoyed The Secret Keeper.  Dorothy Nicolson is dying and her daughter, famous actress Laurel Nicholson, is determined to finally face the horrible violent act she witnessed between her beloved mother and a stranger on a warm summer day in 1961 when she was 16 years old. The book is organized into three main sections: Laurel, Dolly and Viven.  These three women are the main characters of the book but the narration mainly focuses and fluctuates between Laurel as a young woman still living at home and her as a 70 year old woman and Dorothy, or Dolly, as a young women living during the buildup and breakout of World War II as well as a dying 90 year old. Viven is mentioned regularly in the first two sections of the book but only as a mysterious periphery character who changes depending on when she appears in the timeline. We finally get to know Vivien, as a young girl and woman, in the final section of the book when all the previous development starts to make sense. There are also shadings of a man named Jimmy, Dolly's love interest as a young woman, and a few other interesting secondary characters whose relationships with the three main women cast them all in different lights.What I find fascinating about books like these is how well timed and in control the author lays out her plot. Because it isn't chronological at all, and certain scenes repeat and change as they are viewed from the perspectives of different characters, there is so much false foreshadowing. Perhaps false isn't the right adjective but definitely incomplete. There is one scene in particular that happens early on in the book that kept anchoring my ending guessing. I couldn't stray too far from my original hypothesis because I knew this certain conversation had to eventually take place. Then, when it took place again but through different eyes, nothing had changed in conversation but everything had in point of view and tone. I believe most mystery readers enjoy trying to piece clues together and finish the puzzle before the author gives it all away but unlike some authors, Morton neither makes it too easy nor impossible. Each time I was fairly certain I had figured out the mystery of Dorothy Nicolson, Morton would make me doubt myself with new information. I was pleased when I shut the book and could say, "I knew it!" but, the reality is, I knew it, then thought I must be wrong, then wondered, then changed my mind, then knew it again. Morton really knows how to take her readers on a ride.While there are a few meaningful ideas that would be nice to discuss, such as that prejudice that all young people seem to have against becoming their parents as well as the impetus or chain of grief, I think this kind of story is best read in the spirit of entertainment rather than in pursuit of historic or familial understanding. Upon finishing this novel, I consider myself entertained....more

review: Four stars is generous for a book whose characters more resemble those belonging in a Disney film than literary fiction but I'm feeling generous. ThisFour stars is generous for a book whose characters more resemble those belonging in a Disney film than literary fiction but I'm feeling generous. This was a heartwarming story about love, the American dream and what it means to be a family - all things that are high on my list of virtues. Could the novel earn more respect and weight if its two protagonists, Ciro and Enza, had more than their one hardworking but happy mood throughout their ardulous life journey? I think so. The two of them had some pretty hard knocks at very young ages and it was difficult for me to believe that neither was more complicated or obnoxious as a result. Instead, they were very, very likable. And beautiful. And courageous. And stoic. And meant to be together. Like I said...Disney-esque. Pleasant. I enjoyed the Italian setting in the early 20th century more than pre and post war American but it might be because I'm less familiar with the mountainous northern villages of Italy than I am with old New York City or Minnesota and their immigrant eras. I also enjoyed the author's inclusion of both faithful and disenfranchised Roman Catholics. All in all, there was much more to enjoy than object to in The Shoemaker's Wife. title: Tenth of December
author: Saunders, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I hadn't heard of this book until I went into our local bookshop and it was prominently displayed with a "Best Read of 2013!" bookmark sticking out ofI hadn't heard of this book until I went into our local bookshop and it was prominently displayed with a "Best Read of 2013!" bookmark sticking out of it. I didn't buy it, because I was in there to buy another book and I'm pretty stingy with hardcovers, but when I saw it on the shelf of new releases at the library, I snatched it up.Best read of 2013 it is not, for me, but this collection of short stories by George Saunders, who currently teaches creative writing at Syracuse University, is certainly fascinating. I liked the first person, journal entry style narration that he used throughout the book, although it was so casual at times that I wondered how he would grade a student's paper written this way. Every time the thought, "I don't know why anyone would think this is extraordinary,"came to my mind, which it did while reading nearly every short story, a plot trick or his unexpected use of science fiction would immediately elevate the writing to a "wow" level. If he intended to showcase the difference between great language and mediocre language in a small space then he succeeded. It's like looking at a Jaguar and a Kia side by side. He really can be impressive with his words when he wants to be.But I don't think that was his point. I think the unpolished and rough writing was done purposely to match the various unsavory or rough characters featured in each story. I wish I had a favorite story of the ten included in this work, or one that I just couldn't stop thinking about days later to elevate my opinion of this book. It's not that I need cute and cuddly characters to root for. Believe me, there are no cute and cuddly characters. The book begins with a story about a hapless teenager forced to decide whether to be brave or safe, which was interesting until the end. There is a horrific story about two women involved in the sale of a puppy who think they are being the best parent and spouse possible. There are stories that feature a sleazy salesman, a financial idiot, a soldier, a long-winded boss, a dying cancer patient and a socially unaware overweight boy. These stories are rather depressing although each is written with a sharp, uncomfortable humor that doesn't make if funny but also doesn't make it dreary. More like scary dark.So, whoever wrote, "Best read of 2013!" must like scary dark with a side of twisted humor.  I don't know if I would have liked his style better if I could have become attached to these characters in a longer format or if someone explained to me why all these stories were thrown together into one book or if I hadn't started reading with really high expectations but I finished The Tenth of December feeling disappointed. I appreciate that there were many flashes of brilliance but, overall, other than being a bit shocked at times, nothing made me feel more aware of those unknown lives surrounding me or the all-encompassing human experience. Just that his view of that experience is that most people, in whatever class of life, are rather pathetic....more

author: Condie, Ally*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think when a book is one in a series, it's hard to judge it on its individual merits.  Reached, number three in Ally Condie's Matched triology, is aI think when a book is one in a series, it's hard to judge it on its individual merits.  Reached, number three in Ally Condie's Matched triology, is about Cassia, Ky and Xander's realization that along with the power to choose, a freedom not previously experienced in their young adult lifetime, there is often pain. Loss. Heartbreak. Guilt. And, of course, love. This is a young adult series with two guys wanting the same girl, after all. Although this is not an LDS book and should appeal to readers anywhere of any faith (or none) the theme of agency and accountability is one that is familiar and pivotal to members of our church.  For this reason, perhaps, I didn't find the characters' journeys all that startling or even very interesting.  I loved the first book.  I thought Condie's choice to portray a futuristic, dystopian society featuring happy, productive people instead of the more familiar scary and looming forced conformity was smart.  Because I've always been a believer that it is better to have good and bad so that we can know the difference and more fully appreciate the good, I found myself really thinking about a place where the things we seek after - good health, happy families, satisfying work and hobbies - are all but guaranteed. Sure, it was obvious that something was missing but because I felt those good things through Cassia's and Xander's experience,  in a way, I didn't want it to go away.  They were likable and good. Ky was used to illustrate what happens to the imperfections.  To achieve perfect health, the risks (foods, vices, idleness) against it were taken away.  Likewise, to achieve perfect societies, those who disobeyed rules or were even born to those who disobeyed rules, were taken away.  As Ky, classified as an Abberation or an outcast because his parents were part of the Rising, was also a character to root for, the conundrum was established.  Who or what should go?  Those threats to perfection or perfection itself? I suppose I needed to set that all up to explain that I did get the point.  I liked the point.  I just didn't like the story anymore.  As much as I enjoyed Matched, the first book in the series, I equally disliked Crossed, the second book.  Take that as a lesson in opposition! I had no idea where Reached would fall in the spectrum and due to its length, grueling repetitiveness (Cassia loves poetry and is thinking, hiding, trading, or writing poems to express how she feels about any topic.  Xander is learning about the nature of viruses while he thinks about Cassia.  Ky flies a plane while thinks about Cassia. Who is the Pilot? Who is the Pilot? Who is the Pilot?) and predictability, it falls closer to Crossed than Matched.  Everything felt so tedious to me.  From finding a cure (twice!) to waiting for something, anything to make the love triangle more interesting (everyone liked and respected each other an awful lot) I just kept waiting for the action to happen.  Either the conflict was too long in development or simply not overwhelming enough to notice, but I felt like there was no climax.  At least no page-turning one.  I also got tired of the Capitilizations.  Pilot.  Society.  Rising.  Otherlands.  Plague.  I felt irked each time one of those words popped up in a sentence.  If you've read the book, you have an idea about the frequency of the emotion.  What I did enjoy was Xander's growth as his eyes were open to both his limitations as well as his innate talents.  I know he had alternating chapters but I wish there would have been even more about Xander. So, I liked it but I didn't love it and because I wanted this book to redeem the series for me, I feel disappointed. ...more

title: The End of Your Life Book Club
author: Schwalbe, Will*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A nice book about a mother and son who both enjoy reading and how their interest in books strengthened their bond during the mother's treatment and prA nice book about a mother and son who both enjoy reading and how their interest in books strengthened their bond during the mother's treatment and progression of pancreatic cancer.  Definitely a book readers will appreciate as it reaffirms what I have always found to be true: that reading is a gateway to understanding the world and each other. As horrible as this sounds, at times I wish the author had decided to write a fictionalized novel instead of a memoir/biography.  I know! Horrible!  It's not that the book isn't well written.  It is.  It's not that the book's arc doesn't develop well.  It does.  It's not even that the characters aren't interesting.  They are.  My only explanation is that I stay focused better when I'm reading a story that can stay with the story and not leave it to explain this, that and the other facts surrounding both his and his mother's life and background.  But that is my own weakness with non-fiction...the flow. My favorite part of the book, by far, was the weight Will Schwalbe gave books.  Bookclubs get a bad rap and Schwalbe himself lightly mocks them by admitting that the bookclub his mother and he forms breaks all the rules as there is no food served and it only has two members.  As frustrating as book clubs can be, and they often are, I love that a book has the power to gather and join minds.  Even when I disagree with someone about something we've read, I am still delighted that we have that commonality of experience.  Will proves the worth of not only reading, but reading with the anticipation of discussion by the way he lovingly tributes the thoughts and beliefs of his mother with each book discussed.  It sounds like a country song, but I like this quote from the book: "Reading isn't the opposite of doing; it's the opposite of dying."If you like to read and want some affirmation that you're spending your time wisely, this book is for you. ...more

title: The Sense of an Ending
author: Barnes, Julian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't know if Julian Barnes meant his title to be ironic but his ending for this book made no sense to me.  Again, maybe that was on purpose.  As a I don't know if Julian Barnes meant his title to be ironic but his ending for this book made no sense to me.  Again, maybe that was on purpose.  As a literary tool, endings can lift, resolve, change and ruin the story that precedes it.  And, as authors must both find a relief and burden, all books must end.  What's the best way to do that? At first, I thought Barnes's The Sense of An Ending would have an ending as philosophically self evident as its narrator, Tony, repeatedly declared and quoted was the only realistic possibility of any history, that is "the certainty produced at the point where the imperfections of memory meet the inadequacies of documentation."  As Tony discovered throughout his attempts at nostalgia and navel gazing, memories of which he was certain changed with additional witnesses.  Moreover, memories long since forgotten were remembered with new cues and triggers never before considered. As an unapologetic gazer myself, I found the idea that our histories - whether it is our personal, national, or worlds' -  can't possibly be unbiased or thoroughly remembered both profound and accurate. Then came the ending.  What I thought was philosophy was actually a semi-detective novel in disguise and its ta-da revelation finale ruined everything.  As The Sense of An Ending won the Man Booker Prize, I have no doubt that many more educated than I can explain how this blind sided and frustrating reveal not only needed to happen but was actually developed and obvious the entire time, only obstructed by Tony's own need for redemption, but I really wish it simply had a different ending.  I honestly would have been more satisfied with his old girlfriend, Veronica, saying, "You really don't get it.  You never have and you never will," one more time (although twice seemed like enough) and it just... ending.  With us not getting it.  I thought that would have been perfectly poetic and fitting with his painstaking defense of the weakness of memory.  But that was not Julian Barnes's sense of an ending.  See? Is it a play on the title after all?This kind of book leaves me at a loss for rating or recommendation because while I ultimately found it unsatisfying and quite ruined by the ending, the writing was eye candy there were so many lovely quotes to enjoy.  Those discoveries are worth the reading effort, I believe.  Here are some of my favorites:“How often do we tell our own life story? How often do we adjust, embellish, make sly cuts? And the longer life goes on, the fewer are those around to challenge our account, to remind us that our life is not our life, merely the story we have told about our life. Told to others, but—mainly—to ourselves.” “We live in time - it holds us and molds us - but I never felt I understood it very well. And I'm not referring to theories about how it bends and doubles back, or may exist elsewhere in parallel versions. No, I mean ordinary, everyday time, which clocks and watches assure us passes regularly: tick-tock, click-clock. Is there anything more plausible than a second hand? And yet it takes only the smallest pleasure or pain to teach us time's malleability. Some emotions speed it up, others slow it down; occasionally, it seems to go missing - until the eventual point when it really does go missing, never to return.” “This was another of our fears: that Life wouldn't turn out to be like Literature.”“What you end up remembering isn't always the same as what you have witnessed.”“Also, when you are young, you think you can predict the likely pains and bleaknesses that age might bring. You imagine yourself being lonely, divorced, widowed; children growing away from you, friends dying. You imagine the loss of status, the loss of desire – and desirability. You may go further and consider your own approaching death, which, despite what company you may muster, can only be faced alone. But all this is looking ahead. What you fail to do is look ahead, and then imagine yourself looking back from the future point. Learning the new emotions that time brings. Discovering, for example, that as the witnesses to your life diminish, there is less corroboration, and therefore less certainty, as to what you are or have been. Even if you have assiduously kept records – in words, sound, pictures – you may find that you have attended to the wrong kind of record-keeping. What was the line Adrian used to quote? 'History is that certainty produced at the point where the imperfections of memory meet the inadequacies of documentation.” “Does character develop over time? In novels, of course it does: otherwise there wouldn't be much of a story. But in life? I sometimes wonder. Our attitudes and opinions change, we develop new habits and eccentricities; but that's something different, more like decoration. Perhaps character resembles intelligence, except that character peaks a little later: between twenty and thirty, say. And after that, we're just stuck with what we've got. We're on our own. If so, that would explain a lot of lives, wouldn't it? And also - if this isn't too grand a word - our tragedy.” “Yes, of course we were pretentious -- what else is youth for?” “That's one of the central problems of history, isn't it, sir? The question of subjective versus objective interpretation, the fact that we need to know the history of the historian in order to understand the version that is being put in front of us.” “But I’ve been turning over in my mind the question of nostalgia, and whether I suffer from it. I certainly don’t get soggy at the memory of some childhood knickknack; nor do I want to deceive myself sentimentally about something that wasn’t even true at the time—love of the old school, and so on. But if nostalgia means the powerful recollection of strong emotions—and a regret that such feelings are no longer present in our lives—then I plead guilty.”“What did I know of life, I who had lived so carefully? Who had neither won nor lost, but just let life happen to him? Who had the usual ambitions and settled all too quickly for them not being realised? Who avoided being hurt and called it a capacity for survival? Who paid his bills, stayed on good terms with everyone as far as possible, for whom ecstasy and despair soon became just words once read in novels? One whose self-rebukes never really inflicted pain? Well, there was all this to reflect upon, while I endured a special kind of remorse: a hurt inflicted at long last on one who always thought he knew how to avoid being hurt - and inflicted for precisely that reason.” “You can put it another way, of course; you always can.”  I adore that last one.  Actually, I do want you to read this book and tell me if I'm crazy about the ending.  Because how can those incredible quotes come from a book that I do not love????...more

title: The Flight of Gemma Hardy
author: Livesey, Margot*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Unlike some fellow anglophile romantics, I never really enjoyed the love story in the novel Jane Eyre.  Oh, I liked Jane well enough.  Her scrappinessUnlike some fellow anglophile romantics, I never really enjoyed the love story in the novel Jane Eyre.  Oh, I liked Jane well enough.  Her scrappiness, morality and can-do attitude made her an obvious protagonist to root for but Mr. Rochester always seemed kind of unlikable, a tad scary, and, tragic as his situation was, an unlikely love interest for such a young woman (notice I didn't say suitable marriage candidate as men were often quite a bit older than their young brides but I think it was rare that the romance between such couples was spontaneous).  It's probably because I first read Jane Eyre when I was about Jane's age and when she falls in love with Mr. Rochester and I remember thinking, "Ewwww." Like this modern day re-telling of Jane Eyre (it can hardly be called an original story), I liked Gemma Hardy well enough.  Gemma follows the same trajectory as Jane: being an orphan, living with a cruel and abusive aunt and cousins, surviving at a cold and unloving boarding school and eventually gaining the position as au pair (updated from governess) when she has nowhere else to go.  I think because Margot Livesey followed Charlotte Bronte's story so closely, I had a very hard time putting this story in a more modern setting.  Words like, "minivan" and "radio" jolted me from my comfortable victorian imagery and tried to place my thoughts into the author's 20th century.  Sometimes it worked but the farm setting, cold attic bedrooms and stern matrons combined with my memories of a classic made it hard to stay in the 1960s. As much as the author borrowed from the original, she didn't choose to copy the best part: the mad wife  blocking the heroine's path to long-denied happiness as well as the strict moral code that keeps the heroine on her straight path when the temptation to veer of course seems most fair.  In my opinion, Gemma's story is weakened when her guiding light becomes her - her lineage, her opportunity for education, her narrow view of truth - rather than a belief in right and wrong. The redemption she finds is ultimately less satisfying because I never felt like she sacrificed for her prizes.  Suffered, yes.  But there is a different lesson between snatching happiness when available and deserved and trusting it will come from a loving God.  Some would consider that difference archaic and naive, but I noted and missed its absence. Still, the story is interesting and I enjoyed reading it.  Gemma is a fantastic character and the setting in northern Scotland and Iceland, including the unusual names and inclusion of these remote countries' histories, was well done.  The secondary characters faltered, as did the inclusion of more modern issues,  but I kept turning pages to discover the outcomes.  Overall, a decent homage to a better book. ...more

title: Flight Behavior
author: Kingsolver, Barbara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Barbara Kingsolver meshes Monarch butterflies and the threat climate changes poses to their survival with a melancholy marriage set in rural AppalachiBarbara Kingsolver meshes Monarch butterflies and the threat climate changes poses to their survival with a melancholy marriage set in rural Appalachia in her novel, Flight Behavior. Without any doubt, Kingsolver is a magnificent writer able to challenge and question perceived tradition and morality with her metaphorical and graceful writing. Unfortunately, she seems to stumble over her own agenda in Flight Behavior  and the effect is a somewhat disjointed and frequently boring story.Dellarobia, who, sadly, is never offered a better nickname, discovers a forest full of Monarch butterflies while walking towards an abandoned mountain dwelling to begin an extramarital affair. The sighting stops her and the remainder of the book deals with the butterflies - why they are in Tennessee and not Mexico where they belong - as well as why she initially wanted to escape from her marriage and if the butterfly discovery, with its subsequent impact on her relationships and family life, changes that fact.I wish Kingsolver had chosen to be more subtle. Her feelings towards climate change as well as ignorant red-necks is unapologetic and judgmental. She developed some interesting characters but only ever allowed Dellarobia (again...that name is so painful to my brain) to change or grow. But her change was so orchestrated and predictable, I felt, that even it wasn't satisfying or helpful.I believe in climate change. I think there is plenty of data and evidence to support those that say the world is warming and, with that warming, uncomfortable changes to all life is inevitable.  What bothered me in this book was her tone used through characters like Ovid that humans and the media and how our sloppy, selfish ways are all to blame. It is more interesting because she takes quite a bit of time explaining the difference between correlation and causation to explain the uncertainty of the butterfly migration but doesn't seem to see its application with climate change itself.The entire book would feel obnoxious in the hands of a less talented author but Kingsolver does manage some excellent story telling in between her preaching. Her descriptions and settings are vivid and intimate and I could see the forest of butterflies as well as stains on her two-year olds clothes. While not from Appalachia, I could see the trucks and the cigarettes and the isolation and the beauty. Like all places, there is a struggle between the old and the new, tradition versus change and stereotypes threatening sincerity. I'm sure a dyed-in-the-wool (that cliche was used on purpose in honor of the wool dying done in the book) environmentalist will love this book. It is their truth. But, in terms of the future of butterflies and certainly the purpose of marriage - it is not mine. ...more

author: Semple, Maria
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I saw this in paperback at Sam's Club the other day and realized it must have become an "it" book. I remembered that I loved it and that, so far, almoI saw this in paperback at Sam's Club the other day and realized it must have become an "it" book. I remembered that I loved it and that, so far, almost no one that I know that has read it since has liked it nearly as well as I did and so I wanted to come back and defend or at least explain my "it was amazing" rating. I think every once in a while, a book comes a long that just resonates with certain readers. Maybe it's the message that rings true or a character that helps us understand ourselves or someone else a little better. Whatever it is, there was a connection between myself and this book and an almost electric current ran between my hands and its pages while I read. I think it likely due to the fact that this woman, Bernadette, saw the ridiculous all around her. Sure, a cheery person will see Bernadette's point of view as critical and unhelpful, but I felt myself nodding and laughing when she described the overzealousness and competitiveness of school mom volunteers, the futility of cooking and shopping, the absurdity of living in Seattle - from its weather, streets, architecture, hair care, language, diet, style and recreation , the prejudice of loving your own child above all the rest and the simultaneously hilarious and depressing awareness of knowing you are the biggest problem of all. As far as plots go...whatever. I didn't read this to find out what happened to Bernadette the day her husband staged an intervention to commit her to a mental hospital and she disappeared. The plausibility of sneaking onto ships in Antarctica and a fifteen year old solving it all isn't very likely. As far as uplifting material goes...I get that it's dark. Bernadette really is suffering and it's undoubtedly unfair to laugh at/with a woman who on good days hides dirty dishes in drawers and on bad days causes full on mudslides which result in the destruction of her annoying neighbor's house. In spite of my awareness that this book won't be everybody's cup of delicious hot cocoa, I found the satire, writing, pacing, moral, and, above all, character of Bernadette to be the most fun I've read in a while. Maria Semple - I think you get me. I'm glad I'm not nearly as crazy as Bernadette but I'm so glad I got to vent a little bit through her. No worries though, if this isn't your thing. Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha.k...more

review: Love, then a bit of a disgust, then interest, then disappointment, then admiration. That was my emotions running the gauntlet while reading this book.Love, then a bit of a disgust, then interest, then disappointment, then admiration. That was my emotions running the gauntlet while reading this book. Honestly, there isn't an overall opinion from me about this book. Parts of it are really brilliant. Lots of parts. So...I guess I'm saying it's mostly brilliant except for the parts that aren't and those were rather horrible except now that I'm finished, I wonder if they were purposely horrible. Or something like that. This is not your typical spy book. From its uncomfortable title (at least for me it is) to its female protagonist, none of Sweet Tooth seemed to fit the successful formula that is often used when writing about lies, espionage, The Cold War or the British secret service. I mean, the mission "Sweet Tooth" is about the government finding authors who hopefully have a right of center slant about the whole capitalism vs. communism ideology and then secretly funding them so that they can hopefully write a book that persuades the masses. Duh-duh-dum. What? You didn't gasp? O.K. So there wasn't a lot of life and death on the line here but there was a lot of interesting human drama. From its look at the world from a woman's perspective in 1970 to the realization that Big Brother could be just about everywhere, McEwan manages to salvage what I feared was becoming a sappy and poorly done woman's take on spying with some fantastic McEwan-ing at the end. It was different. I liked it. Quite a bit. ...more

title: The Language of Flowers
author: Diffenbaugh, Vanessa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I realize no book can do all things but I also think a book can do more than one thing. The Language of Flowers is a beautiful book. With its imagery I realize no book can do all things but I also think a book can do more than one thing. The Language of Flowers is a beautiful book. With its imagery and description of beautiful flowers, not to mention the inclusion of every noted flower's victorian definition, it's easy to believe in the power of roses,jonquils and even thistles. It's easy to enjoy this story about a broken, abandoned girl who communicates with flowers and begins to discover her own worth and strength by using her talents to help others. Most of me wanted to believe in all of the blossoming magic. But, I didn't. Maybe that's unfair. Victoria is a victim of abandonment, never knowing who her biological parents were or why they left her to the care of the government but her journey through foster families reveals the sometime ugly realities of the system. At times starved, emotionally manipulated, and continually rejected by family after family, Victoria seems a textbook case of someone suffering from attachment disorder. When she is finally placed in the care of a loving woman who wants her and suffers through all of Victoria's attempts at sabotage, her future seems to finally have the possibility of a happy ending. From the very beginning of the story, however, we know something didn't work out. The novel uncovers the unhappy story, chapter by chapter, weaving between her newly independent adult life and the flashbacks through her childhood, mostly during her time with a woman named Elizabeth who teaches her about flowers and wine grapes and life. There is enough realism in the narration that the unrealistic parts of the book distracted me. Who are these secondary characters in Victoria's life that seem too good to be true? Is it possible that someone with as severe emotional problems as Victoria can really function at a job? Or have a relationship with a man? I'm not implying that the author made it easy for Victoria. On the contrary, the author repeatedly highlighted Victoria's difficulty in each of these life developments. Some of the details her moments of despair made my stomach church with sympathy and pain. What was missing was the difficulty of the other characters. Weren't they outraged by her behavior? Weren't they turned off by her appearance, her deception, her almost feral behavior around food? I want to believe that there are people who are blessed with patience in abundance and who are ambassadors to help rehabilitate these poor, love-starved souls and I do believe that they exist. I just want to know about them too. I was disappointed by getting a little bit of Elizabeth's story and motives but never really getting to know her. I never understood her connection to Victoria, a connection that was vital to believing the story. Ultimately, I think the author became a bit too focused on sharing the language of flowers and left out some critical development to the more interesting human story. I just wanted...more. ...more

title: Tell the Wolves I'm Home
author: Brunt, Carol Rifka*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Tell The Wolves I'm Home surprised me.  When a book is listed as young adult fiction and the blurb from Goodreads begins with,  "In this striking liteTell The Wolves I'm Home surprised me.  When a book is listed as young adult fiction and the blurb from Goodreads begins with,  "In this striking literary debut, Carol Rifka Brunt unfolds a moving story of love, grief, and renewal as two lonely people become the unlikeliest of friends and find that sometimes you don’t know you’ve lost someone until you’ve found them,"    I expected something a little more Hallmark-esque.  A little more feel-goody.  But this is about AIDS during the 80s when nobody was sure how it was spread and if you could catch it by sharing Chapstick or not.  This is about prejudice and jealousy and revenge and deception and death.  And just like the title implies, this is about facing down something that could easily destroy a person. The title is beautiful.  It's nuanced and unique and has both symbolic meaning as well as being referenced several times in the story.  The book centers around a fourteen year-old misfit, June, who by any teenage standard is considered weird and whose only after school activity involves donning gunnie-sax dresses and lace-up suede boots while walking around the school woods pretending she lives in medieval times.  Her older sister, Greta, is a golden child.  So smart she skipped a grade.  So talented she's being offered Broadway roles.  June is consistently labeled "average" by both teachers and her parents so she revels in the adoration and attention from her uncle Finn and is left devastated by his AIDS related death.  After she discovers that important facts about Finn's life were kept from her, including his boyfriend,Toby, who is blamed by her entire family for Finn's death, she chooses to step out of her comfortable fantasy world and with much confusion and ignorance, begins to see a complicated but not awful reality. There are several toe-the-line YA rules that are followed.  June's parents are absent throughout the book (they are both accountants and most of the story takes place between January and April - tax time) as well as clueless, condescending and wrong.  That is not my favorite thing in a book.  Also, at 14, June seems entirely too free to engage in extremely high risk behavior including meeting a stranger by train, frequently hanging out without permission or notice in New York City, smoking cigarettes and consuming alcohol.  But it all sounds worse than it is.  I feel bad writing that, as if those things aren't big deals, but in this particular story, they aren't the main deal.  They are byproducts of her grief and not a glamorous portrayal of teenagehood. In actuality, this is a story of naivety and innocence and grief and friendship and love. The author makes a point to differentiate between ways of being romantic.  Through her character, Finn, she defends the romantics by defining them as optimists and I like that.  I'm not sure how believable the story is at times.  Lots of times, I thought it was weird, independent of June's own weirdness.  Greta seems contradictory as a character and the pacing is often irritating in its repetitiveness but by the book's end, I felt Brunt justified her writing.  With art and symbolism framing its message of beauty and acceptance, in spite of everything else,Tell The Wolves I'm Home isn't a perfect book but it's a good one. ...more

review: Tisha was a Goodreads recommendation based on my adoration of the book, Mrs. Mike.  I've stated it before and I'll say it again, I love Mrs. Mike.  OfTisha was a Goodreads recommendation based on my adoration of the book, Mrs. Mike.  I've stated it before and I'll say it again, I love Mrs. Mike.  Of course, I was interested in reading a book that might be similar to it in both style and message.  After reading it I can only say, "Well....kind of." Their mass-market cover art is similar.  There are dogs that pull sleds.  There is reference to "Indians" doing things deemed foolish or wrong by white person standards.  But, that's about it.Really, Tisha is about a young woman without ties who chooses to go teach in the bush of Alaska.  Without experience or training, Anne Hobbs, called Teacher or "Tisha" with native accents, fumbles quite a bit in trying to fit in her tiny community in Chicken, Alaska.  A quarter Native American herself and partially raised by her indian grandmother, Anne escapes what most Alaskans living the hard life cannot: prejudice.  She is willing and desirous to teach all the children in her area, much to the dismay of the local whites.  As she stands her ground by accepting all into her classroom, falling in love with a "half-breed" and eventually adopting two orphaned indian children, I understood how much times have changed as well as the universal tendency towards labeling different as bad and the dangers of pack mentality. Still...this was no Mrs. Mike.  Not even close. ...more

review: Unlike Ann Patchett's Bel Canto, which felt tragically unrooted in reality, State of Wonder is worth its hype and then some.  Fascinating in its descrUnlike Ann Patchett's Bel Canto, which felt tragically unrooted in reality, State of Wonder is worth its hype and then some.  Fascinating in its description of the Amazon, original in its mix of science and plausible fantasy, incredible in its characterization of both indigenous people and a colorful team of researchers, I was beguiled from the beginning of this entertaining tale.  Patchett does an incredible job of drifiting in and out of various settings, from a cold Minnesota spring, the dirt and chaos of urban Menaus, Brazil, and up the claustrophobic rainforest around the Rio Negra, so that I, the reader, never really noticed if time was passing.  While her technique does have the side effect of being occasionally slow, especially when filled with meticulous detail, it produces the very thing the title promises - a state of absolute wonder.   Smart, imaginative, ambitious and perfectly ended, I really enjoyed this. ...more

review: The Magnificent Ambersons is the 1919 Pulitzer Prizer winner. That sentence reveals two things: it has merit - especially as a cautionary tale of wealThe Magnificent Ambersons is the 1919 Pulitzer Prizer winner. That sentence reveals two things: it has merit - especially as a cautionary tale of wealth, accountability and pride - but it is also old. The writing style felt really old to me, not quite vaudville-esque but almost.It's an interesting window of history to look through. Aristocratic wealth and the gentleman's lifestyle makes way for the Industrial Revolution and a new wealth's ideals rooted in work and invention. The two ways of life are not romanticized, though the tone and characterization throughout the entire book is lighthearted to the point of caricature, and both arrogance and waste of the old life ideal along with the pollution and risk of progress are exposed.The style kept me separated from the story. I felt too modern to be reading it. Like silent films where actors relied on melodrama to compensate for a lack of sound , I felt like the writing here was from a bygone era when authors stuck to polite ways of description, as if certain language couldn't be used yet. Interesting as both a look at history and once-upon-a-time style, and certainly as a classic of American literature, I'm glad I read it but I didn't love it. I need more intimacy between author and reader in a novel....more

title: The Chaperone
author: Moriarty, Laura*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'd never even heard of this book until it was selected for October bookclub.  The book is an interesting mix of fiction and history.  The protagonistI'd never even heard of this book until it was selected for October bookclub.  The book is an interesting mix of fiction and history.  The protagonist, Cora Carlisle, is an invented portrayal of some actual chaperone who accompanied the real life Louise Brooks, silent film star of the 1920s, from Witchita, Kansas, to New York City.  And while you might be saying, "I don't know who Louise Brooks is," you probably have seen an image of her somewhere.  She is an iconic figure of the jazz age.  Did you watch So You Think You Can Dance this past season?  You know Amelia?  She was trying to copy Louise and her blunt bob with bangs, pale skin, and doe eyes. Laura Moriarty highlights the tension between generations of women by pairing Cora with Louise for five weeks one summer.  Cora is twenty years older than Louise, wears a corset and skirts that come to her ankle and is in constant bewilderment, awe and worry over Louise's disregard for societal rules. She is of the generation that believes that a young woman traveling to New York on her own needs a chaperone to guard both the reputation and actual virtue of the vulnerable weaker sex. Louise could care less and resents Cora, who is neither a relation nor a friend, and openly mocks Cora when reminded about the rules that have never applied to her.  She freely talks to strange men.  Her clothes don't cover much and, worse, she seems to enjoy all the scandalous attention.  I thought the idea of unveiling the evolution of womens' rights, including the right to vote, birth control and having careers of their own, was interesting but Moriarty lost points, in my view, with her execution.In order to develop her characters, she rightfully weaves in a lot of backstory to both Cora and Louise's views on life.  Through Cora, she tells the history of the orphan trains and how sad, dangerous and incredible it was.  Through Cora's friends and family, she also brings up the taboo gay lifestyle, the Klu Klux Klan, the use of Lysol as a feminine hygiene product/birth control (for real) and sex as a means of intimacy and not solely procreation.  Through Louise's actual history, she includes the heavy topics of alcoholism and drug abuse, pedophilia, promiscuity and mental illness. If it all sounds like too much, you're absolutely right.  These were/are important issues.  Most were, I'm sure, relevant to women of all ages in the 1920s.  But, Moriarty's ambition to deal with all of them in one novel didn't work for me.  To make it all plausible, she had to make both her main characters live on the polar ends of the cultural spectrum.  I thought the story would have played in a more interesting fashion had Cora not been quite so naive or unhappy.  Likewise, although I know Louise had a real history that shouldn't be changed, I felt the question of which lifestyle was more dangerous to women could have been better addressed had she fictionalized a young and ambitious flapper instead.  That way, the side to root for wouldn't have been nearly so obvious, as it rarely is in real life. In spite of the overwhelming amount of propaganda to trudge through, I still thought The Chaperone was a well-written novel and worthy of a book club choice until the last hundred or so pages.  The book should have been about those five weeks Cora and Louise spent together in New York.  Had the author ended her story with the train ride back to Witchita, I would have applauded the way she left Cora's feminist awakening uncertain.  But, she just couldn't leave well enough alone.  Because Louise Brook's history continued, Moriarity decided Cora Carlisle's parallel history needed to be included.  She whizzed through years...decades at a time until both were old and gray.  The abrupt change in both style and pacing was disconcerting.  It ruined the whole book for me.   I thought including what was, in essence, a hundred page epilogue was the wrong choice.  We still managed to have a lively discussion on the range of women's included but we pretty much all agreed that the book ended poorly. ...more
