review: Definitely one of the funnier books I've read in a long while.  But while I enjoyed the humor and the wake-up call the author sounds to take care of yDefinitely one of the funnier books I've read in a long while.  But while I enjoyed the humor and the wake-up call the author sounds to take care of your marriage, especially if it has become stagnant with middle-age responsibilities, I didn't really believe this story. Life is strumming along for Alice and William and their two children, Zoe, fifteen and Peter, twelve.  Except they all seem so unfriendly, unhelpful and bored.  After a particularly lackluster night out with her husband, Alice decides to take part in an apparent random marriage survey she discovers in her junk email.  She is assigned the identity, "Wife 22," and while giving her written responses, she wakes up her dormant memory of better times, evaluates her values and attitude, dusts off her old playwright writing skills and remembers she is a person worthy of interest.  The question she now faces is does she invest her rekindled  energy towards her twenty year marriage or pursue the researcher who seems so besotted with her. Like I said, parts were tremendously enjoyable.  There is this memory Alice writes about the time her William, who she wasn't yet dating, and her old boyfriend met in line at Au Bon Pain and the situation with her embarrassment over her boyfriend's blue bandana was laugh out loud funny.  But, unfortunately, funny parts can't seem to carry a story and if I remove the humor-filtered glasses, I see a book with many flaws.  Alice is a very weak protagonist.  She is actually hard to root for.  Her husband is not a complete character.  He is whoever the author decides she wants him to be in whichever chapter.  There was never any consistency in how he was written.  Her family life is appalling in both what she expects from people and what she gives.  Her poor kids. The writing switches between traditional narration, survey responses, emails and facebook chats.  I worry for the books longevity as it is so interwoven with Facebook terminology and technology that it will really date itself quickly.  I know this book isn't really meant to be a critical essay on modern marriage or social media so if you read it with the light-heartedness with which, I believe, the author intended, it should serve its purpose as enjoyable, anecdotal middle-aged chick-lit. ...more

title: The Time Keeper
author: Albom, Mitch*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I struggle with the kinds of books whose objective is to moralize a topic or instruct. Non-fiction sorts such as Self-help, parenting, dieting and howI struggle with the kinds of books whose objective is to moralize a topic or instruct. Non-fiction sorts such as Self-help, parenting, dieting and how-tos are the obvious sources of trouble but Mitch Albom's type of fiction fits in this category too. This type of book, which promises a better life for me if I only read and agree, always seem more attractive until I am sitting down with the book open in my hands and then I am either bored or bothered. I have thought a lot about it and have concluded that the reason for my prejudice is I don't want a book to think for me (how's that for circular logic?) I think my favorite hobby, even more beloved than reading, is thinking. I love to think. I am perfectly happy to sit in a quiet car or room and ponder. I think that's why I love fiction and literature so much is because while the author may be moralizing or instructing, I have to do my part...thinking...in order to figure it out. Mitch Albom doesn't seem to trust me enough to let me do that. I haven't read much of his work but after finishing The Time Keeper, I felt cajoled into thinking what HE wanted me to think. Time is precious! Moments matter! Um...yeah. I sort of already thought that. But, then I got kind of confused. Because he used a fable to make his point, I got lost at times in which was more important. Was it better to not pay attention to time? Or did paying attention to time make life more precious because time is finite? I may be thinking too hard about it. Then, when all preaching was said and done, I disagree with him. I do not believe man is the inventor of keeping time. My own beliefs state that God separated the light from the darkness and called His work a day. I also disagree with the idea that that man must die in order to enjoy memories or moments as if the finite quality of earth time is a superior experience over eternity. That just does not make sense. I'm probably over thinking it all. See, if you give it all away, then someone like me will try to ruin things by adding to or digging deeper to the already generously donated thoughts. A nice idea of a book though. ...more

title: Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail
author: Strayed, Cheryl*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The premise is fascinating. A woman with no real hiking experiences decides to hike the Pacific Crest Trail, from southern California to the WashingtoThe premise is fascinating. A woman with no real hiking experiences decides to hike the Pacific Crest Trail, from southern California to the Washington/Oregon border...1100 miles in all, to cope with her unraveling life. I admit that I would love to do this. I'm always a bit jealous of people who give in to their self-absorbed motives. I'm never sure what gene is necessary to buck the responsible adult, responsible wife, responsible parent out of the way and succumb to that desire to escape from real life and do something outrageous or extraordinary but memoirs and biographies seems to be limited to those who have it. I'm not saying it's always a bad thing. Heroes, presidents, adventurers, artists all seem to be guided by a magnet that leads them away from the dull and expected. For their stories, I'm always amazed by their courage to be different. To lead. To dare. But, for someone like Cheryl Strayed, who I didn't at all like when getting to know her through her memoir, I think much less magnanimous thoughts. They are more like, "Get over yourself!" I'm not sure what the point of Wild is. Strayed admits herself at the beginning of her trek that she had no real business being on the trail with so little experience and preparation. She makes the claim that hiking is really just putting one foot in front of the other over and over again. So, I thought it might be a sort of cautionary tale that warns other would-be novice hikers that hiking the PCT is about much more than moving your feet. But, she ends up ok. Oh, she has lots of side trips that include shelter, new boots, hamburgers and even a date to a nightclub but her adventure also includes rattlesnake scares, snow, water rationing and equipment failure. And so, even though her hike didn't really resemble what I imagine a pure PCT adventure would or should, perhaps the point is that we tend to over think things and, really, anyone at all can hike the PCT with success. Seriously, after reading the book, you have to think, "Well...if she did it, so could I." She's kind of an idiot. Memoirs are hard for me to  because it's not just about the writing. Without a doubt, Wild is an interesting tale. A single woman hiking alone in perilous conditions is just not the kind of thing most of us know anything about. Of course I want to know what happens next. For the most part, the details she included about the trail - it's scenery and topography - were the best part of the book. I wanted to be on the trail myself. But, memoirs always come with baggage. Why is this person writing this? Are they famous or wise? Did they have an extraordinary life or at least an extraordinary experience? I suppose Cheryl Strayed's motive would be an extraordinary experience but she includes enough of her life, as one writing a memoir must do, to taint the take-away message. Cheryl lost her mother when she was in her early twenties. Her mother was only 45. Her loss influences everything else throughout the book. In essence, this is a book about her grief and I acknowledge that there is no proper way to grieve. If someone deals with it all by abusing a loving husband with frequent adultery, shooting up heroin and escaping from a former life by leaving it all behind to go hiking....it is what it is. That's their way. But, there were times when her way of writing about it was so ripe with self-indulgence that her my-mother-died carte blanche got all used up. For instance, there was this sentence early on in the book that just left me reeling. She wrote, "I got an abortion and learned how to make dehydrated tuna flakes and turkey jerky and took a refresher course on basic first aid and practiced using my water purifier in my kitchen sink." Just like that. She had gotten pregnant from a heroin-fueled affair and I'm not saying she should have been a mother. I'm not even saying that she owed her readers some kind of explanation about how ending her pregnancy made her feel. She didn't need to reveal her abortion to us at all. What I am saying is that if you are going to mention getting an abortion in your memoir, it'd be best if you didn't include making tuna and turkey jerky in the same sentence. I think the topic of abortion deserves, at the very, very least, its own period. It is not the kind of topic most readers treat lightly. I had a very hard time garnering up sympathy for her after that thoughtless inclusion. Especially upon later discovery about her own mother's unexpected and unwed pregnancy. There was no connecting of the dots. Just Cheryl, Cheryl, Cheryl. I'm glad she learned something. Or found peace. Or forgave herself. Or whatever. She's just another person who doesn't have any bigger troubles than the rest of us and yet the likes of me and Oprah buy her book anyway. She is lining her pockets with our chump change. That is wild. ...more

title: The House at Tyneford
author: Solomons, Natasha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have been on a chick-lit reading extravaganza!  This was a wander-through-and-pick-up-at-the-library choice made solely on the aesthetics of the covI have been on a chick-lit reading extravaganza!  This was a wander-through-and-pick-up-at-the-library choice made solely on the aesthetics of the cover and the words, "Fans of Downton Abbey will absolutely adore The House at Tyneford!"  Sold! Although there is the expected romance and descriptions of how the wealthy live, this is a much grittier novel than I expected.  It is mostly set in pre-war Europe during Hitler's rise to power, when Jews were losing more and more of their rights and the question of their safety was becoming a major concern.  Jews who could afford the exit taxes got visas to leave their homes and countries and some sent their  daughters to work in various jobs in a friendlier England.  In this novel by Natasha Solomons, Elise Landau, an 18 year-old girl born to a famous opera singer and a successful author, who grew up attending fancy parties and servants of her own, leaves her comfortable life to work as a house maid at a large English estate.  Not only does she lack the skills and experience to do well at her new job, but the pride in serving a noble family, not to mention the required humility, are absent too. I think had this really been about the transition between her two very different lifestyles, I would have enjoyed it more.  Instead, in the name of romance, the author focused on her relationship with the rich heir to Tyneford, Kit. The relationship is not completely out of the question as she once was a part of the circle she now serves, but I did not believe it.  She is a jew.  She barely speaks English.  She describes herself as pudgy and plain (don't they all in these books?  And yet, men are always falling in love with them?  I think the rich and noble tend to get the thin and rich, don't you?) The author attempts to paint Elise as rebellious and headstrong and I suppose that could be part of her allure, but because so much of the story depends upon the authenticity of the relationship between her and Kit, the story starts to collapse from the added weight of the war. Still, it is a book I think fans of Downton Abbey will enjoy.  I am a fan of the show and I liked it.  I could imagine very well the small attic room where she slept and the fussy butler not to mention all the rules about serving on the left while simultaneously appearing invisible.  I enjoyed the bit when Elise complains about the rule of never being seen cleaning.  She wonders if the masters of the house are supposed to imagine magic elves doing the work. No ringing endorsements as its neither very fun, very romantic or very important, but it is an interesting look at a time of great change in all the classes of Europe. ...more

title: Beautiful Ruins
author: Walter, Jess
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't know quite what to say. I should probably write about why I enjoyed it so much. I guess because it is romantic. Or because it is colorful. PerI don't know quite what to say. I should probably write about why I enjoyed it so much. I guess because it is romantic. Or because it is colorful. Perhaps, because it has freakishly fantastic characters who portray human motives with so much variety and truth. Mostly, because it's unlike anything I've ever read. This has a really big scope. It's a dozen different stories and yet one human story. I could say it's about an Italian man who meets a Hollywood actress in 1962 and goes to America to look for her fifty years later. I could also say it's about a young idealist who comes to realize that nothing in Hollywood is real. At times, it's about a man who was part of The Greatest Generation who never was great. Other times, it's what must be salacious gossip about two dead stars: Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, and their infamous affair. It's about drug addiction and death and loss of identity and indifference and infidelity and, in spite of all that seriousness, has real humor and love added in. How does a book about so many thing end up being so great? Jess Walters pulls all those sad violins together at the end and like a contemporary symphony, something beautiful emerges from all the dismal ruins. Something I've never heard before. And I loved it....more

title: The Art of Fielding
author: Harbach, Chad*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Fifty pages in, I thought, "Yes! This is what I like to read! It is already so good!"With such a strong start, it had four-hundred and fifty pages to Fifty pages in, I thought, "Yes! This is what I like to read! It is already so good!"With such a strong start, it had four-hundred and fifty pages to go downhill and, boy, oh boy, did it ever skid on down. Henry Skrimshander is the real deal at shortstop. Unfortunately, because of his scrawny build and small-town Wisconsin isolation, no one notices. Until Mike Schwartz, Westish College's team captain and catcher steps in sets Henry on the path to baseball stardom. The Art of Fielding is mostly about the relationship and motives of these two college baseball players but Chad Harbach decides to go for what he must have considered a grand slam and ruin a sweet home run by throwing Guert Affenlight, Westish College's Dean, and his depressed daughter, Pella into the character lineup. It's been awhile since I've read something that disappointed me so much. Books often have stronger beginnings than ends but Harbach's early plot development and delightfully nuanced characters fell short more than most. What I thought was going to be a subtle metaphor between baseball and life turned into a nauseating, immoral and overwrought drama. Characters who had flaws suddenly become one giant flaw. Everything was overdone. And then he tries to resolve the whole mess at once! Bah!It had so much potential. This book about fielding baseballs-both literal and metaphorical, was such a nice masculine book and after my somewhat heavy-on-the-chick-lit summer, I felt some balance return reading about muscle building protein shakes and road trips via bus. As a woman, I've been told that men don't like to analyze problems, they like to fix them and if that is true, then Harbach needs to fix this book. First problem: too much book incest. These people need to get out of themselves more. You have Henry and Mike and Owen and Guert and Pella and they are all sleeping with each other! It is icky. I know it's a small college and all but it's a fatal flaw.The first problem directly leads to the second problem. Because these five peoples are impossibly up in each others business, all of their problems reach a ridiculous climax at the same time. Really? How convenient for your story. The last problem is the most annoying. The end. It is so bad. You are seriously going to end your story by a feel-good group grave digging? Oh. My. Word. I'm trying to  the book for what it was and not for what it could have been but it's hard to do. It could have been so, so good. But, it wasn't....more

title: The Dovekeepers
author: Hoffman, Alice*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is my first Alice Hoffman book.  Truthfully, I'd never heard of the author Alice Hoffman until I read a few s comparing The Dovekeepers to This is my first Alice Hoffman book.  Truthfully, I'd never heard of the author Alice Hoffman until I read a few s comparing The Dovekeepers to her many, many other works.  I'm not exaggerating when I write many twice.  She's written nearly fifty books.  I should have heard of her.Some of her other titles ring a bell but they aren't the kinds of stories I'm drawn to.  I'm not sure what made me select and stick with The Dovekeepers either, as it isn't even the kind of story I usually go for.  Four women living in 70 CE (which is the secular dating system meaning Common Era vs. the more familiar Christian friendly AD nomenclenture), share their backstories and journeys to their arrival and stay at the famed Masada, a massive rock fortress built by King Herod near Jerusalem, and their work in the community dovecote when the Roman armies fell upon them and close to one-thousand Jews committed mass suicide. It's an odd book.  Maybe it's Hoffman's style but the narration is unusually distant.  It reads as if ghosts are retelling their doomed story but that's not wholly accurate.  There is a methodical, almost hypnotizing rhythm to it.  It's filled with foreshadowing as whichever of the four narrators clearly already knows both the outcome and the reason for sharing any particular detail, and that sense of foreboding kind of feels ghoulish.  But, not scary.  It's not even that suspenseful as the outcome is pretty obvious if you know the history at all, which was first recorded by Josephus who claims that only two women and five children survived.  Hoffman sticks with that accounting but obviously fictionalizes the details. Apart from being a story about Masada, it is also a story about ancient feminism.  I don't know how true this is.  History has been mostly written and kept by men so the motivations, fears and desires of women can only be applied from general truths.  They must have loved.  They must have felt passion.  They must have shown great courage and strength and protection for those they nurtured when necessary.  As a woman, I know these traits could not have come only from more recent freedoms.   Freedom helps but it is who we are. The narrations start to weave and intersect more and more towards the end of the book until the four women's stories become one heroic and tragic end. ...more

title: Home
author: Morrison, Toni
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are so many qualities of a book that determine its quality and how it is received.  Toni Morrison is a difficult author for me to  becauseThere are so many qualities of a book that determine its quality and how it is received.  Toni Morrison is a difficult author for me to  because I understand, as a middle-class, caucasian reader, I lack the experience, history and perspective that would allow me to truly love and appreciate her books.  However, having read four of her novels including her latest, Home, I can recognize the beauty of her craft by merely comparing a paragraph she writes to a paragraph in another book and, more often than not, declaring hers the winner.  She writes very well.  She writes with depth and truth and exposes a part of American and black history that is usually harrowing and shameful.I never want to pretend to like a book more than I actually did in an attempt to seem more analytical or astute than I really am.  It is tempting while writing a  for a book written by a Nobel laureate to nod my head and say, "This is incredible!" but the main thought going through my head while reading Home was, "Why doesn't Morrison ever include the good things that happen to her characters?" I'm not insinuating that anyone who gushes over this book isn't being sincere but I know if I gushed, I wouldn't be. Home is the story of Frank Money's post Korean war life.  There are plenty of flashbacks to his childhood which are all just as disturbing as his psychologically damaged adult life.  Although Frank seems to have had some decent times in his life, such as close friendships throughout his youth, a  somewhat understanding girlfriend after the war and a sister he raised who idolizes him, any positives are quickly glossed over to get straight to the dysfunction of each relationship and experience: (view spoiler)[his friends gruesome deaths in the war, his girlfriend's relief when he leaves and his poor sister's abuse at the hands of a medical doctor. (hide spoiler)] It's all very believable and I'm sure there are plenty of real life Frank Moneys who have suffered what he suffered and saw what he saw and were tormented every bit as much as he was tormented but it's all so...depressing.   I have never and will never think that a book needs a happy ending to be good but it should have a purpose.  I'm not sure what this book's purpose is. The book jacket actually led me to believe that this would be a book about a broken man finding hope and courage and his "home" but I saw no hope or courage here.  Not curling up into a ball and dying: yes.  It just seems like an awfully low standard to write about.   ...more

title: The Good Dream
author: VanLiere, Donna*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So, I went and saw the movie Looper this weekend. I don't watch many movies and even fewer R rated movies but it was the kind of weekend where I reallSo, I went and saw the movie Looper this weekend. I don't watch many movies and even fewer R rated movies but it was the kind of weekend where I really, really wanted to have movie theater popcorn and diet-coke and so I looked at Rotten Tomatoes website and it was either the 12% stinky trash Taken 2 or the 95% good looking tomato Looper. Looper sounded like an interesting premise - mobs murdering their hits by sending them 30 years in the past through time travel - and somebody from the Tony Kornheiser show recommended it, securing Jay's vote, so we went hoping the R rated parts weren't going to be too awful. Turns out, they were. I hated all of the blood and guts. And the drugs. And the promiscuity (This wasn't The King's Speech kind of R-rating). Gross. And although the story WAS interesting, it wasn't nearly worthy of its 95% ripe and red tomatoes.. The time-traveling moral of the story is if you can personally change the future for the better, you should do it. I'm not sure it's the cloud parting, angel singing epiphany the movie critics seem to think it is but I think that's where the good ratings are coming from. Then, two days ago, I pick up The Good Dream and read about a single thirty year-old woman named Ivorie, in a small Tennessee farming community who causes a stir in her sleepy town when she rescues and cares for an abused 8 year-old boy and changes his future. I thought, "This is Looper without the mob and strip clubs and drugs!" It's a PG, 1950s, small-town non-time-traveling Looper!Ivorie's brother, Henry, says this to his wife in reference to his sister, "It doesn't matter what sort of hate that boy's daddy was eaten up with. All that was broken the moment Sarah (he is the only person that calls her Sarah. Her name is Sarah Ivorie) went up in those hills with God Almighty filling her chest and she brought him down out of there....Love's in that boy's bloodline now. For a thousand generations....Not bad for a day's work." He even goes on to say that he's not chasing rainbows and knows about the rough rows to hoe up ahead. Some readers take issue with the boy not being more emotionally damaged than the author portrays him to be in this story. I don't know. I'm not an expert. I certainly image anyone who is subjected to the kind of physical, emotional and sexual abuse this boy is described as enduring would face many life challenges in his future but I don't think the book ties a bow around these two characters and declares them finished. I think the author is saying in a more-palatable-to-me-than-Looper-way, "Do the right thing." Even when it's hard. Especially when it's hard. Recommended!...more

title: Between Shades of Gray
author: Sepetys, Ruta*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm sure I've mentioned this before but I am a big fan, huge, of well titled books.  I love it when there are layered meanings or a play on words or iI'm sure I've mentioned this before but I am a big fan, huge, of well titled books.  I love it when there are layered meanings or a play on words or it contains a reference to something traditional, familiar or reverent.  Possibly because this title is so unfortunately similar to another currently popular but less chaste book, I was very motivated to learn the meaning of its title, Between Shades of Gray.  Until the very end of the book, and I mean very end (like author's notes), I still hadn't gotten it.  The protagonist, a fifteen year old opinionated and perceptive girl named Lina, is an artist and the book is filled with abundant references to her drawing, sketching, and tracing the events of her and her family's struggle to survive as declared enemies to the Soviet Union.  As part of the book takes place in Siberia in the snow, I thought it must have something to do with the mixture of pencil lead or charcoal and the snow.  You know...gray art.  Clues, perhaps, that led to their deliverance or a description of their lost testament of a brutal and forgotten history.  The cover picture with snow on an eyelash supported that theory. As the story progressed and their conditions became more severe, I grimly thought that the author was  making a morbid reference to the characters' skin tones as they became sicker and sicker from malnutrition, exhaustion and disease.  Or, less grotesque, there was an early description of Lina wearing a pretty grey dress during a happier time that brought out the color of her eyes that I reasoned might have been mentioned to foreshadow another shade of gray later on creating a contrast of the two time periods.  Between Shades of Gray is a book about what happened to the Lithuanians, Latvians, Estonians and Finns during Stalin's rule.  As the author, Ruta Sepetys, predicted, I had little knowledge of the specific sufferings felt by these exiled people.  Caught between Hitler advancing armies in 1941 and the Soviet Union's own expanding empire, the citizens of these small countries were without allies or voice and their stories were left largely untold until their re-independence in the 1990s.  Sepetys was correct in assuming that their stories of survival, heartache, despair and love need to be told.  I'm grateful she has given a voice to these histories and glad that her book is doing well, even better because of a similarly titled book. I did have my disappointments.  By far the largest disappointment was needing to be told the point of the title.  I'm not going to give it away here, but should any of my above theories as to the meaning of the title show up on some kind of multiple choice exam in the future, choose D: none of the above. When the author revealed what she meant by "Between Shades of Gray," I wasn't wowed.  In fact, I was a little more like, "Well...obviously."  That is true of all history and every story.  It bugged me that she felt like she was making this breakthrough announcement.   I also have to mention that the writing is quite juvenile with short simple sentences and a lot of guiding and telling how the characters felt. While her characters do feel genuine and there is a satisfying variety in their responses to depravity, they are mostly boxed into one identifying emotion.  A few of the main characters were allowed more than one but the additional responses were often related. Lina was angry but determined.  Her mother was kind and  generous.  The bald man was mean and scared.Nevertheless, this is a good book.  It exposes important morality that forces thought and judgment.  How do some survive the very worst kinds of suffering?  How would I choose to be in a situation like this?  Why is the world so cruel sometimes? Knowing that most of the situations throughout her novel are based on memories of real life survivors, any writing flaw or deficiency easily takes a back seat to its truth.  More than that, the take away message of love and hope overpowering despair and darkness is a message I hope all will be motivated to read.  Recommended!...more

title: Ready Player One        (Ready Player One, #1)
author: Cline, Ernest*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ready Player One has an element I normally find lacking when reading dystopian novels with an emphasis in science-fiction: plausibility. Oh, sure, I'mReady Player One has an element I normally find lacking when reading dystopian novels with an emphasis in science-fiction: plausibility. Oh, sure, I'm usually scared right out of my pants about the possibility of living in many of the worlds many authors describe, but, at the end of it all, I rarely have the thought, "This could happen. Soon." Ernest Cline and his thorough description of a virtual world not only influencing but actually taking over our flesh and blood reality in 2044 seemed not only possible but...well...likely.That doesn't mean that I subscribe to his doomsday forecast completely. Cline creates a world so depleted of natural resources and innovation that the only progress made since our current 2012 existence happens online. That world, with individual visors and hepatic clothing designed for full virtual immersion as well as altered online personas doing everything from working lame jobs and going to school to battling demons and traveling via some majorly souped up space ships, is so preferable to anyone's real life that no one bothers with "actual" relationships anymore. Heck, no one bothers with actual furniture anymore. All anyone really needs is a room with a bathroom, someway to heat pre-packaged food up and, of course, a strong connection to the web. For what seems to be pure entertainment value, or perhaps his own personal satisfaction, Cline chooses to include a lot of 1980s references. There were times I really enjoyed his mentioning of a band, TV show, clothing trend or, more likely, video game that was popular during my youth. It successfully induced nostalgia and gave the book some legitimate cool retro vibes. However, much more often, I was distracted by the tangent a description of a game or character or quote took me on and eventually annoyed by the extra work it took to keep my focus on what was really happening in the novel: a pure good versus evil/little guy up against a giant/rebel army fighting a Darth Vader empowered empire fight for the future of mankind. If you're into that sort of thing, you'll like this book. But you might be surprised by the hero.Wade Watts is the ultimate loser. Overweight, poor and acne prone, he has no advantages in life and everything going against him including living with a meth addicted aunt who charges him rent to live in the laundry room of her decrepit trailer. He is, however, very good at video games. When James Halliday (think Steve Jobs-esque), the person who created the virtual world called "Oasis," dies, he announces via video that he is leaving everything - all his money and all his rights and control to Oasis - to whomever can find his hidden "egg" in the virtual world that consists of multiple planets and universes. Every geek with online access is searching for clues but Wade, who has spent most of his life in Oasis, sees his avatar name, Parzival, as the top scorer when he solves the riddle, gaming challenge and test of 80s knowledge (he has to recite Matthew Broderick's entire dialogue from the movie "War Games") to open the first of three gates. Overnight, Wade is thrown into a dangerous spotlight with very real-life consequences. Besides the bigger issues Cline presents, such as energy abuse and impotent governments, not to mention a free to the masses World Wide Web, there are lots of juicy ideas to reflect upon. As someone who has not only made but enjoyed many online friendships throughout the years, I especially appreciated the debate between Wade and his love-interest, Artemis, about whether these count as real relationships or not. Really thought provoking book with great characters, anxiety causing action sequences, satisfying principles and, more often than not, entertaining 80s humor. Recommended!...more

title: Broken Harbour        (Dublin Murder Squad, #4)
author: French, Tana*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ultimately, this book was too far fetched for me to enjoy. I really admire much of French's style of writing. I've read all of her Dublin murder squadUltimately, this book was too far fetched for me to enjoy. I really admire much of French's style of writing. I've read all of her Dublin murder squad books and liked the first one, Into the Woods, best because the formula wasn't obvious yet. Now, I know something mental is going to happen to the lead detective's investigation and, this time, it seemed unnecessary. Besides that, all of the insanity or characters that experienced mental breakdowns (I counted 9) was overkill. What was the point? That it was caused by the location of Broken Harbor? That the recession and lack of work produces hallucinations and a personality switch? That you didn't have a chance at a normal life if you had a mental illness in your family history or heredity? The resolution didn't work for me either...all of those lengthy, lengthy monologues and confessionals. Too neat and convenient. Throw in WAY too much information on rodent and animal life, cops reneging on their own character development and too much sympathy all around for the eventual guilty party and I don't even know why I'm giving this three stars. Probably, they were earned during the first half of the book, which was really good. I fear the next story will be Richie's and his dopey end annoyed me. This id probably the end of the line for Tana French and me. ...more

title: Heaven Is Here: An Incredible Story of Hope, Triumph, and Everyday Joy
author: Nielson, Stephanie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There is a scene in Stephanie Nielson's memoir, Heaven Is Here, that has stayed with me these past few months since I read it. It is found in the firsThere is a scene in Stephanie Nielson's memoir, Heaven Is Here, that has stayed with me these past few months since I read it. It is found in the first third of the book, where Nielson, or Nie Nie, as she is commonly known, writes about how much she loved to clean her family house while growing up. She recalls her tendency to routinely fluff the pillows on the chairs and sofa to make everything look nice. She then describes, and this is what fascinated me, how, afterward, she went outside and pretended to be someone walking along the sidewalk in front of her home. She looked through the window and thought, "A nice family must live here." It's both charming and creepy all at once but the inclusion of this seemingly insignificant anecdote felt like the big "Ah-ha!" for me. For the rest of the book, I realized I was on the sidewalk looking through the windows of her living room. You see, I never understood the appeal of her blog. Even before Stephanie and her husband's airplane crash, I found her colorful blog with its courier font and middle alignment hard to digest. I loved her sister's blog with her wit and irreverent but soul-baring posts and occasionally clicked over to Stephanie's blog from it but I wasn't interested in drinking distilled water or eating a vegetarian diet so while I applauded her happy marriage and love of motherhood, I never felt inspired by the life she presented on her blog. Moreover, she isn't a great writer. I'm not saying that to be critical of her life but because a blog is based on the written word and a book even more so, I think the ability to write well matters. If I'm going to look through into someone's home, I have always been more interested in the conversation between the people sitting on the sofa than the sofa's design or the colors and patterns of its accent pillows.Thankfully, she had help writing her book. Gone are the frequent grammatical errors from her blog and she and her family are presented in a fluid and accessible way. As she developed her personal story in the first third of the book, I understood her candid and unapologetic aspirations to be a wife and mother. I think she was right in laying out her case that way because her youthful goals were so different from mine and it helped me understand an additional layer of devastation that came after the crash. The middle section, about the crash is almost detailed enough. I'm not sure if it's morbid fascination with her survival of something so nightmarish but I wanted to know everything she knew about the crash and that was not to be. She shared a little bit about being in the plane before it went down, about being aware of her husband and his instructor's apparent stress but it wasn't until the end of the book that I realized I still didn't know how the crash actually happened. Something in the plane malfunctioned but what? Why? How? As much as I wish I knew those details, I recognize that Stephanie's book is about her personal journey and not just a chronological telling of events. Whether the crash occurred because of the plane's malfunction or pilot error isn't what Stephanie chooses to write about. I get it. I was glad she allowed the curtains on her window to stay open while the inside was uncomfortably messy. She went to a really dark place following her medically-induced coma and struggled with the will to survive. As she couldn't imagine ever being able to make her life beautiful again, she truly wondered what purpose on earth she would ever have again. I cheered for her breakthroughs and her spirit discovering the beauty she had within. It is very inspiring and life affirming. I appreciate the end of the book when she questions the title of her book. It was suggested to her by her editor and she explains how she had to be persuaded to use it and even believe it. All while reading, I wondered at the title. It was pretty clear that heaven was NOT here as Stephanie had more than one close encounter with it while she was spiritually elsewhere. Her defense and use of the title felt necessary to me. Critiquing a memoir is kind of a risky endeavor. As a book devoted to sharing parts of a life, it's hard to separate the person from the writing. In this case, I think the book is successful. It tells a unique and incredible story. As a book to read, it is fine. While I still care very little about her pretty living room, this book brought me the conversation within and I left thinking, "A nice family really does live there."...more

title: Wonder        (Wonder, #1)
author: Palacio, R.J.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am a sucker for kindness.  Sometimes, when I can't get the words out to complain to a waiter about cold food or an empty drink, I think of my fear oI am a sucker for kindness.  Sometimes, when I can't get the words out to complain to a waiter about cold food or an empty drink, I think of my fear of seeming unkind as a weakness or failing.  After reading Wonder, by R.J. Palacio, I have decided that I will always, always, always err on the side of kindness...cold food and all. You see, this is an excellent book.  It is about kindness.  It is a book I think everyone should read.  It is a book I gave to my seventh grader immediately after finishing and said, "Please read this," and hoped and wished he would and not ignore it like he does with some of my suggestions.  He did and he loved it too.  We have had some great conversations about it since and I learned some things about him when we discussed the various characters. Good books do that.  They teach and inspire and warn and rebuke.  I felt all of those things as I read about a nice young man with a facial deformity that made him an outcast at school and in life.  I read about his fears and about his courage.  I read about how people treated him.  Once, in a moment of real confusion and questioning, I asked my mom what God could possibly have intended in his plan for people who suffered from debilitating mental illness.  I will always remember her response.  She said, "I think, in large part, they suffer so he can judge how we treat them." Here is a quote from the book: “If every person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God.” There. I dare you not to love that quote. Auggie suffers so we can learn how to treat God's creations - deformed...beautiful and everything in between.  Read this book and decide which of Wonder's character's you most resemble.  They might be in middle school but I don't think any of us are too old to learn from Auggie.  Read this book!  Then have your spouse/kids/peers read it too!...more

title: The Paris Wife
author: McLain, Paula*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have read one Ernest Hemingway book: For Whom The Bell Tolls. I liked it well enough but it was hard reading. Short, curt sentences. Bleak. UnemotioI have read one Ernest Hemingway book: For Whom The Bell Tolls. I liked it well enough but it was hard reading. Short, curt sentences. Bleak. Unemotional. Plus, there was a lot of formal spanish dialogue. Reading about Hemingway was much simpler and more my cup of tea. I know novels are never as accurate as biographies or wikipedia articles (joke) but their delivery is so much more palatable, in my opinion. Novels that aren’t written by Hemingway, that is. The Paris wife is a novelized account of Ernest Hemingway’s first wife, Hadley, and the years they lived in Paris before and during his rise to literature stardom. I found Hadley and Ernest Hemingway and their relationship as depicted in The Paris Wife to be quite believable. They felt like whole people to me. Both were flawed, Ernest far more so, but as we were told the story through Hadley’s perspective, it felt right to see her as more of the victim of an ambitious and selfish man. What a time period! I admit, I watched Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris” and barely enjoyed it. Not knowing any of the legends depicted except the most famous (Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Dali, Porter), I didn’t finish that movie with a sense that life in Paris during the 20s was all that spectacular. This book both confirmed and corrected my attitude. Paris was filled with what would become the all-stars of American Literature. It was an interesting time in an interesting place. The Great War, World War I, had recently ended. Many of those living in Paris either fought in the war or witnessed its atrocities. The world was recovering from what probably nobody thought could have ever happened. So much death. So much destruction. So little reason. Thus, the free and lose values of these young and provocative artists created an atmosphere almost akin to the Renaissance. It was another rebirth. The rebirth came at a cost, however. Drugs, sexual promiscuity and an enlarged sense of lassez-faire may have created epic works of art and timeless literature, but it ripped away any kind of foundation for family life. Hadley Hemingway learned this the humiliating and painful way as her husband’s ego and success grew. What detracted from the book were the rushed histories on both ends of the main story. Hadley’s childhood, while certainly necessary to understand her character, felt one-dimensional. Her younger self barely looked like her married self. Likewise, the tidying up at the end with both her and Ernests’s later histories satisfied some curiosity but, again, didn’t match up. I ended up reading wikipedia to get more explanation. :) An interesting story of marriage, however. Fascinating really....more

title: Edenbrooke        (Edenbrooke, #1)
author: Donaldson, Julianne*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Regency romance is not my thing. Jane Austen copy cat books are not my thing. I was sure Edenbrooke, where a young lady named Marianne Daventry is invRegency romance is not my thing. Jane Austen copy cat books are not my thing. I was sure Edenbrooke, where a young lady named Marianne Daventry is invited to visit the title's namesake estate with her twin sister and become entangled in the inevitable drama of suitors and advantageous marriages, would not be my thing.I was totally wrong. I found this book to be absolutely delightful.So delightful, in fact, that I read it again the very next day. I had heard from other admirers that it reminded them of Pride and Prejudice and I knew that didn't feel right to me. Still, I loved it and wanted to know why the romantic tension felt so familiar and interesting if it wasn't for its resemblance to Austen's beloved romance between Elizabeth Bennett and Mr. Darcy.I think it has more in common with some John Hughes films like "Some Kind of Wonderful" or the relationship between Jim and Pam in the early days of "The Office" than the buttoned up courtship of actual 19th century fictional figures. Not that this has much unbuttoning. It is very PG and refreshingly clean. And I don't mean that Edenbrooke's plot follows the same storyline as either of the above fictional romances.  They evoke similar feelings.  All three involve a seemingly insurmountable obstacle in the mind of one of the characters that prevents them from being with the person they really, really want to be with.   Just like The Office was better before Jim and Pam got together, romantic tension in this form is enjoyable to me. When it releases, with declarations and understanding, I find it all very satisfying. More stories should follow this formula! It's definitely my kind of thing:)The ensuing story includes lots of flirting, a bit too many mentions of Marianne blushing for my liking but, oh well, and some predictable conflicts when her more glamorous sister is determined to have the guy Marianne wants (but will never admit wanting) as well as some surprising action involving guns and kidnapping.  There is a letter writing scene that I read over at least five times!  Swoon!  Marianne is an every-day woman's heroine.  Pretty in a non-obvious way and better known for her wit, selflessness and love of nature, she can live a more genuine life as she has no aspirations to belong to the fast and beautiful crowd, unlike her not-identical twin sister. Of course, that kind of realness only makes her become more attractive to those who get to know her and when they do, they can't help but fall in love with her,  the beautiful people included. I don't know how realistic that is, but being of average attractiveness myself, I loved the possibility.I understand the comparison to Pride and Prejudice.  Although the plot points are quite different, the author places her story in the same time and setting and includes many of the same supporting characters: snobby rivals made worse by their jealousy, a villain disguised as a gentleman and a loving but distracted and absent father.  Additionally, there are the same sorts of rules and obstacles to overcome in regard to marriage, money and titles although the characters seem a lot closer to having our 21st century sensibilities than the class and gender restricting ones they would have actually had. There are also several scenes straight out of Pride and Prejudice. There is a reversed and much more funny wet-from-the-pond scene.  There is also some passionate practice fencing to rid a certain gentleman of his romantic frustration.  And you can't forget the balls.  It wouldn't be a period romance without the descriptions of balls and smoldering glances. All of this is fine and good but what really connected me to the story was the story of friendship.  Simplified, yes, but it was so nice to read about a budding romance that was based much less on physical attraction and more on common goals and values, interest in the other person's talents and abilities and, super cheesy here, wholesome recreational activities.  I actually believed that these characters could and did fall in love.  So fun.  Probably my favorite book of the summer. ...more

title: The Kitchen House
author: Grissom, Kathleen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Kitchen House by Kathleen Grissom is what I think fits under the definition of a saga. Its timeframe spans decades and although the story unfolds The Kitchen House by Kathleen Grissom is what I think fits under the definition of a saga. Its timeframe spans decades and although the story unfolds with two alternating first person narratives, Lavinia and Belle, there are many more characters in whom the author invests and in whom the readers come to care about. Set in post-Revolutionary War colonial Virginia, Lavinia, a young, white, Irish indentured servant, is brought to work on a tobacco plantation's kitchen house among the house slaves. Lavinia has been orphaned and takes comfort in clinging to Belle, a mixed race slave who also happens to be the biological daughter of the owner of the plantation, Captain Pike, and whose light skin looks the most like hers. As the story progresses and Lavinia matures into a young woman, her role on the plantation changes and her loyalty to the only family she can remember as well as her belief that these slaves are her equals is pushed to dangerous limits. It is a compelling read, especially the first half when Lavinia is young and bonding with her adopted family. I’ll be the first to admit that the conflict, the history and the limitations of both the slaves and women in defending themselves and standing up against tyranny had me on edge and rooting for what my twenty-first century sensibilities know are worthy causes. In spite of my interest and enthusiasm to know what happened next, this novel suffers from several flaws.First, I absolutely loathed all of the misunderstanding. Things not spoken, things misinterpreted, things covered up all contribute to much grossly unfair consequences. I believe a good story can be built upon the foundation of what happens from the consquences of a misunderstanding, for instance, Ian McEwan’s Atonement. However, the author’s repeated use of her characters hearing partial conversations or the assumptions made about unexplained relationships was more along the lines of what the old sitcom, Three’s Company, did in many of its episodes except tragedy, rather than comedy, being the end result. One misunderstanding I could have handled. For example, Marshall, the eldest son of Captain Pike, hates Belle because he believes his father spends time with her and gives her gifts from his travels because she is his mistress. He does not know that Belle is, in fact, his half sister. The Captain’s wife, Mary, also believes this and an ugly need for vengeance takes hold of Marshall that fuels his many transgressions. That brings me to Marshall, my second grievance. Marshall had a bad childhood. Even with the privilege of being white and wealthy, we are allowed to witness his confusion and sorrow as he is neglected by both of his parents, abused by his tutor and saved several times by the very slaves he eventually persecutes. I think the author was trying to make him a rounded character by making us privy to his difficulties but to them make him so uniformly evil in the end felt like a mischaracterization. I wanted him to want redemption. I wanted him to find it. That was not his role to play. Likewise, Lavinia morphs into several unmatched characters throughout the book. From a scared mute to a confident, educated and compassionate girl who later becomes an eager to please teenager and eventually a weak and terrified drug addicted adult. I’m not saying that couldn’t be someone’s life story, it was just a lot of changes to a character within one book. Plus, the narration was usually told with a hindsight perspective so I did not understand why she always seemed so different. Shouldn’t the use of perspective give some continuity to her voice?I loved Mama May, George, Ben, Fanny and Beatie (not sure about the spelling of those names because I listened to rather than read this book) but...I was supposed to. These are the stereotypical “good” slaves. Of course, slaves were quite capable of being good and patient and kind and thoughtful because those qualities are human and, even though they bore the weight of the injustice of being owned and mistreated, they were and always have been human and likely to be likable. I wished we could have been trusted to know their flaws as well. Sure, we saw some fear and sadness when things got really bad but no other weakness was allowed. It frustrated me because I still would have rooted for them even had one of them been depicted as lazy or shallow or unkind or selfish. It was as if Grissom devoted the book to show us how human slaves were without letting them be human. Finally, I loved and hated all of the romantic and sexual drama. The narration often hurried up to the point of the story where people were falling in love, in love, in lust or jealous about others falling in love, in lust or being in love. In short, I think this is historical fiction for women. Even with the messiness of slavery and farm work, I can’t see a man really liking this book. I could be wrong. Maybe there are men who are drawn into the workings of a kitchen house and all the fuss between men and women but I suspect all of the childbearing, nursing, and repeated rape and attempted rape might make them squirm. Because I am a woman, I found it all fascinating and horrible. Even with the many things that irritated me, I still appreciate the scope of the book. It examines the nature of freedom and the various things that enslave us: disease, addiction, fear...even perverted forms of love. It highlights the wonders of kindness and generosity which stood in stunning contrast to the wickedness and corruption. In addition, if it makes anyone more aware of the stain of slavery in American history, then it gets points for that....more

title: Three Day Road
author: Boyden, Joseph
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of those kinds of books I appreciated more than I actually liked. The time period is set during World War I, or The Great War, which I kneThis is one of those kinds of books I appreciated more than I actually liked. The time period is set during World War I, or The Great War, which I knew very little about. I went through my goodreads book and I have read 32 books that are set during or about World War II. I have read 2 about World War I. Of course, I’ve also watched Downton Abbey but I have a sneaky suspicious watching solders convalesce on the estate of a british aristocrat isn’t the everyman’s story of the war. Three Day Road probably isn’t either but I did get an unflinching look at the brutality of living, fighting and dying in the trenches. By reading, I got a glimpse of the unrelenting snails pace of progress or defeat. I learned what kind of provisions the lowly privates of the war had provided and the kind of artillery and strategy used by those hunting down Fritz. It was all very interesting and depressing. What sets Three Day Road apart from other dreary war books is the point of view of the narrators - both Native Americans. One is young Xavier, who enlists with his childhood friend, Elijah, both given Christian names by nuns trying to unheathenize them in Eastern Canada. Xavier and Elijah are excellent soldiers due to their lifetime spent hunting. They are selected as snipers and commanded to go out on midnight attacks, hunting their new prey - Germans. Xavier struggles with the cause and the brutality. As he narrates from the first person, I could feel his reluctance, his fear as well as his confusion about wanting to do well when doing well meant killing. Elijah, on the other hand, enjoys his success and becomes lost to sanity after killing hundreds and becoming addicted to morphine. How their friendship and loyalty plays out is a major theme of the book.The other narrator is Niska, Xaviers aunt, who continues to live as her ancestors did: hunting and roaming for shelter as a nomad. She is also perceived by her tribe to have special powers and visions that come to her when she has what appears to be epileptic seizures. The chapters interchange between the two as Niska cares for Elijah upon his return home after the war. Through flashbacks on both their parts, a story of Native American folklore, the high cost of war and the element of three - past, present and future, emerge....more

title: Defending Jacob
author: William Landay*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you like reading about legalese, you will like this book.If you like reading about marriage and family drama, you will like this book.If you like rIf you like reading about legalese, you will like this book.If you like reading about marriage and family drama, you will like this book.If you like reading whodunits, you will like this book. If you like reading in the first person narrative, you will like this book. If you like tidy endings, you will hate this book. William Landay, a former prosecutor, shows off his lawyering chops in this very compelling legal drama about an first assistant district attorney, Andy Barber, assigned to prosecute a murder case only to be pulled of it when his son, Jacob, becomes the prime suspect. I know John Grisham kind of ruined the legitimacy of legal fiction with his formalistic and over-the-top plots but Landay gives the genre an authentic and gritty reality without involving the mob, the CIA, the supreme court or Washington DC. Instead, he sets his court in suburban Massachusetts where murder crimes are nonexistent and the victim and suspect are teenage boys. Moreover, he deliberately highlights the impotency, flaws and tricks of the legal system from both a prosecutor’s and defense council’s standpoint. Some are depressing, others shocking and, more often than not, rather mundane. I especially appreciated the view from the defense side of things, getting Andy’s point of view with the understanding of his extreme familial bias. Knowing the game of law, he walks us through his narration deliberately with a sometime-in-the-future-looking-back hindsight. The foreshadowing seems to give away certain outcomes but you still are forced to wonder. Things aren’t so clear to his wife and mother of the defendant, Laurie. As we only get Andy’s perspective, we only see Laurie and Jacob through his opinion and he clearly loves his wife and son. But, he does not understand her suffering or her doubts and he certainly lacks the necessary impartiality to accurately see the state’s case against his son. Andy just defends Jacob as he deems best. Two things I very much enjoyed in this book were Landay’s weaving a court transcript throughout the book and his unabashed accuracy in how teenagers speak. The court transcript felt like short but interesting intermissions from Andy’s story. It was the only time we read something that Andy Barber wasn’t controlling. It was refreshing but never long enough or distracting enough to pull you completely out of Andy’s fog. It just let me catch my breath a bit and wonder what was going on. And, so often, dialogue in books is written in a way that, while interesting to read, sounds like no one I know. Landay’s teenagers sound like teenagers. It’s not a very uplifting subject matter, thinking about murder and teenage murder at that, but Andy’s background, his discipline and his resolute determination to defend his son will make readers question how well we can really know another person, including our children, and the prejudices we undeniably have towards others....more

title: The Fault in Our Stars
author: Green, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Imagine this: You are on a date with an incredibly good looking individual. It is the first time you have met and you are bedazzled not only by your gImagine this: You are on a date with an incredibly good looking individual. It is the first time you have met and you are bedazzled not only by your good fortune to spend time with someone so fine but also because it’s been so long since you’ve had this much fun on a date. You are having a great time and want everyone to know it. And then - there’s just this teeny tiny thing. You catch your incredibly good looking date watching himself (or it could be herself) with satisfaction in a mirror. For just a bit too long. Your date is still beautiful and fun and interesting and one of the best you’ve had in a long time but....I got that feeling while reading The Fault In Our Stars by John Green. I was twitter pated through page two hundred, at least. Then, I noticed the navel gazing. By naval gazing, I mean that I became aware of the author’s probable vanity. His delightful main characters, Hazel and Augustus, are so esteemed in each others eyes. Although both teenagers suffer from cancer, they make up in wit and comeback lines from anything they suffer in terms of health. Everything they like, from authors to friends to music to food, seemed so, so smart. And they keep talking about it - how smart the other is. Their favorite fictional author, Peter Van Houten, plays a large role in the book and he is equally smart. Mean and drunk, but smart. Each of their sidekicks, though one is angrily blind and the other blissfully unaffected by life are hyper quick with fabulous diversions. Indeed, they are all very, very smart. Understand, I don’t mean book smart, though that element is there. I mean confident and thoughtful with themselves and others in that irreverent, brash, Gilmore Girl meets Ally McBeal kind of way (I realize this is a YA book and those two shows might be too old for the intended audience's to actually reference). John Green wrote them all this way. And just like witnessing the self adoration in the mirror, I thought, “I think John Green must think of himself as awfully smart and funny.” Still, I’m on this amazing date with a hottie. I don’t want to ruin it. So I pretend I didn’t see what I’m pretty sure I saw and relax and enjoy this smart and funny story about two kids whose lives are unfairly full of disease and compromise and whose lives will be ultimately be much too short. I enjoy their romance and their existentialism. I laugh. I cry. I feel angry and protective and wishful. I think. A lot. I admire my date’s ability to repeatedly return to a recurring theme without it ever feeling redundant. In fact, his pacing is poetic and artful.The world is not a wish-granting factory. Whether there is or is not a God, purpose in the stars or our own genetic mutations, Hazel and Gus are the kinds of people whose conversations about these things are ones I appreciate reading....more

title: The Snow Child
author: Ivey, Eowyn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So many things to love about the enchanting novel, The Snow Child, by Eowyn Ivey. Set in Alaska homesteading period of the 1920s, Jack and Mabel seem So many things to love about the enchanting novel, The Snow Child, by Eowyn Ivey. Set in Alaska homesteading period of the 1920s, Jack and Mabel seem a poor fit for survival in the extreme conditions that surround them. Already approaching their twilight years, Jack lacks the strength to establish a producing farm on his own and Mabel struggles with loneliness and depression from a past miscarriage and subsequent infertility. Then, on a night when the winter snow begins to fall, Jack and Mabel have their first lighthearted moment in a long time thanks to their welcoming neighbors, Esther and George, and upon returning home, spontaneously play in the snow and build a showgirl. Mabel decorates it with a coat and mittens and Jack carves a beautiful lifelike face onto the snow statue. During the night, Jack wakes and sees their snow girl destroyed and what he thinks is a real girl wearing the coat and mittens they used to decorate their snowy creation earlier frolicking about his yard. The mystery of who the girl is, if she’s real or a creation of grief and cabin fever fills out the rest of the story.What’s fun about this book is the fable within a fable. The Snow Child introduces an unknown-to-me Russian story, Snegurochka or The Snow Maiden, and it is used as both foreshadowing and as a parallel with Mabel and Jack’s snow girl. The author is very adept at subtly shifting between their harsh reality of needing food and warmth and human contact and the enigmatic existence of Faina, the snow child. For instance, whenever Jack and Mabel are talking to or about Faina, Ivey leaves out traditional punctuation. No quotation marks or commas. The words seem more like thoughts than anything spoken aloud. The other conversations throughout the book are framed with quotation marks so it is deliberate and effective. Are those conversations real? I also appreciated the author’s ability to convey depth of emotion - both lighthearted joy and gut wrenching despair. I felt proud of Mabel when she successfully planted potatoes and mad at Jack when he didn’t comfort his lonely wife. Likewise, I cheered when Jack got a bull moose and wanted to shush Mabel when she pestered Jack. So much truth about marriage here - both the committed and romantic love but also the disappointment and grudges that are hard to let go. I also loved how the author showcased the need and purpose of friends and human interaction. We need it more than we think we do. It lifts our souls to connect with others. The part of the book that failed for me was the snow child herself. I never connected to her. I think we were supposed to, much like Jack and Mabel did, but her aloofness and ambiguity prevented her from being anything more than a “thing” in their life, and I never felt concern for her outcome. This confuses me because the way the book ends, I assume we are supposed to care very much. Which brings me to the ending. I don’t think I got it. I read a library’s copy and have since returned it but I wish I could reread the last chapter or two because I think what I thought happened may never have happened at all. Perhaps that is the point, this being a near fable and all, but I’m pretty sure I should be more sure. All things considered, it is a lovely book. One I happily recommend....more

title: Faith
author: Haigh, Jennifer*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's been so long since I've had the luxury of reading an entire novel in one day so that fact alone must contribute to how much I liked this book.FaiIt's been so long since I've had the luxury of reading an entire novel in one day so that fact alone must contribute to how much I liked this book.Faith, by Jennifer Haigh, exposes the title's opposite power: doubt. Art Breen, a Catholic priest, has been accused of molesting a young boy. His family members - a devout mother, sympathetic sister and estranged brother, all react to the news quite differently. The author employs a powerful plot tool in forcing the reader to also examine our own faith or doubt, not in catholoisism, but in mankind by keeping the truth covered until the very end. The narration is also very, very interesting. It's written from the sister's point of view but she writes it as the recounted memories and an unfolding expose of those she interviews and knows so, oftentimes, each character - her mother, Mary, her accused brother, Art, and her brother, Mike, are all known much more intimately than as often depicted when seen through another's eyes. She also frequently leaves the present situation to add understanding with a backstory or memory. It's complicated and murky and I really enjoyed it. For such an icky topic, it's not an icky book. There is quite a bit of language as it is set in working class Boston and those inhabitants are fond of the F-bomb, but each character is so well developed that you are able to sympathize and celebrate with their various flaws and triumphs. Above all, you see how there is no such thing as simple faith. Our experiences and choices make us who we are and influence what we believe, even if who we are is not how we appear to others and what we believe is not how we live. Interesting and haunting, I'll be thinking about this book for days....more

title: The Night Circus
author: Morgenstern, Erin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Never having been a fan of circuses and seeming to be one of the few readers who really hated Water For Elephants, I wasn't very excited to read the fNever having been a fan of circuses and seeming to be one of the few readers who really hated Water For Elephants, I wasn't very excited to read the fantasy novel, The Night Circus.  Peer pressure and curiosity got the better of me, however.  I wanted to know what all the black and white and red fuss was about and when my sister left me her copy to read for free, I gave in. Turns out, I really enjoyed reading this.  Erin Mortgenstern writes about an elegant and magical circus; the kind of circus, should it actually exist, that I would love to attend.  The Night Circus, or Le Cirque des Reves (which actually translated means Circus of dreams but that's being nitpicky) arrives without any kind of warning in cities throughout the world.  It opens its gates at nightfall and closes at dawn.  No one knows how long it will stay or how it moves from place to place.  Its exhibits, which range from tranquil ice gardens that never melt to carousels featuring painted animals that breathe, would certainly be fascinating to visit.  I identified with the fictitious Reveurs, an enthusiastic fan club whose members follow the circus from city to city and don black and white garb as well as some kind of red accessory, to identify themselves to each other.  In addition to the bewitching description, an odd cast of characters are introduced from contortionists and clock makers to an orphan boy and temperamental girl bound to each in their youth with magical rings that burn and scar their fingers.  All this mystique and curiosity cast its magical spell upon me while reading but by the book's end, my "ooh"s and "ahh"s were replaced with a great big,"huh?"There is a part of the story where a young boy named Bailey is dared by his sister and her friends to sneak into the night circus during the day and return with some kind of proof of his success.  He manages to slip through the gate and get close to the black and white tents, but as he passes through, he notes how drab and tired the fabric looks under the glare of day.  That is exactly how I felt when I snapped out of my reading reverie. Although Mortgenstern did a beautiful job of entrancing her readers by including a mysterious challenge with deadly consequences, shadowy characters with abnormal abilities and the promise of romance throughout, she forgot to include some critical ingredients for a great book such as relevant details about the circus acts themselves (I knew more about the scent, shape and color of the food at the circus than the performances of the main characters) and, in my opinion, an actual conflict.  The one she promised was developing went poof...like magic...at the end.  Unfortunately, I don't like that kind of magic. Even though my daylight eyes sees these unfortunate flaws, I had a lot of fun experiencing this book in the moment.  I suggest you read it at night....more
