title: Atlas Shrugged
author: Rand, Ayn
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Atlas Shrugged, by Ayn Rand, is a heavy and intimidating novel that mixes fiction with philosophy. Its main protagonist, Dagny Taggert, is a woman aheAtlas Shrugged, by Ayn Rand, is a heavy and intimidating novel that mixes fiction with philosophy. Its main protagonist, Dagny Taggert, is a woman ahead of her time who understands how to successfully run a railroad. Her brother, Jim, heads up Taggert Transcontinental in appearance only and focuses most of his limited ability making deals with Washington that essentially cripple his own railroad and other big businesses and make Dagny's job as Vice President of Operations more and more burdensome. He and others do this out of jealousy, frustration and a feeling that letting those who can, do, isn't fair to those who can't or won't. The essentials of fiction are present: characters, plot, a setting, conflict, motive and moral, but each is so narrowly defined and controlled by the author that her philosophy, Objectivism, becomes the main focus. Her characters are presented as "good" or "bad" with nobody, not even secondary characters, anywhere in between. Rand defends this style saying she doesn't use average people as her characters. O.K. I'll go along with that. Except, after awhile, none of these people seem real. None of them have personalities, only goals or agendas. The "good" guys are always rational, always decent (even if they pretend to the world that they aren't) and always, always right. The "bad" guys are always irrational, snarky, slick and shrill. All of the "bad" guys refuse to take responsibility for any action and won't until they are assured someone else will, whereas the good guys never pass the buck, and there is no room for compromise. Ever. There is right and there is wrong. Black and White. Moral and immoral. Good and Evil. Capitalism and socialism and never the twain shall meet. Moreover, in a style that seems ostentatious nowadays, Rand rarely passes over an opportunity to declare her beliefs without using a tedious monologue. I was interested, truly, in learning more about the author's controversial declaration that man must be selfish in order to be good, but to shovel it to me in sixty continuous pages via John Galt's hijack of the radio waves towards the end of a very, very long book, isn't very neatly disguised fiction. That's an essay. If she did happen to use the much easier to digest format of conversation between two characters, the majority of the time it was structured as questions and answers, with the answers short and perfunctory, creating a feeling of barely tolerable boredom. The book's overall feeling was one of repression and hopelessness. No one, not the good guys or the bad guys, were ever happy. For me, this is a seriously flawed approach to persuade anyone about anything. Man's search for happiness is...well...what life is all about, isn't it? Rand kept telling us, over and over again, how that happiness is to be achieved, but to devote eleven-hundred pages to tell the story of weary capitalists who could be happy if everyone else would just get the hell out of their way isn't exactly the way to seek out convert capitalists. Overall, I cannot subscribe to the philosophy contained with the pages of Atlas Shrugged because I don't believe it actually leads to happiness. I think it leads to a productive economy. Oh yes, I whole heartedly agree that capitalism feeds the world. As Atlas Shrugged implies, if the government didn't interfere with the copper industry's production, they would be able to produce more copper at less cost to sell to steel manufacturers who could then produce cheaper steel to sell to the automobile industry and railroad industry and airplane industry and on and on and on. As Rand states, the freedom "to make money" not to have it handed to you or taken from you or passed down to you from generation to generation is one of the things that has made America great. However, only one side of the story is told here. Rand assumes that people with great minds always have the best motives. Selfish as they may seem, they merely want to do what they do best without interference but without harm or malice to anyone else. Sadly, I don't think this is true. I think history has shown more consistently that instead of a lassez-faire economy leading to virtue, more often that economy allows those with power to become corrupt. Rand unfairly highlights that tendency only within the ranks of the evil socialists who want to take any power and ability away from their productive rivals but never addresses what happens when a producer or businessman uses pure capitalism for his or her own evil purposes. Still, it felt eerie to read about all of the laws and government positions created to control the economic market during this novel's fictional setting. Just today, I read about the financial reform bill that President Obama signed into law that will protect American consumers from the selfishness of Big Banks. The following article on the page was how the administration extended jobless benefits, in effect promising millions if not billions of dollars to those who are not working to be transferred from those who are. I'm not kidding, those articles would have fit into Atlas Shrugged with perfect context, not changing a single thing. It does make one wonder how much additional strain our humongous government, with all their agencies and bureaucracy, puts on yours and my pocketbooks. Because we pay for it all. The goods and the government making sure those goods get to us fairly. Finally, I'm not sure how to balance politics with belief. The things Rand mocks are notions of humanity, sacrifice, fairness and love. She claims to view them in any lens besides that of justice and what a person has earned is not only wrong but evil. To love someone who has not earned our love is not love. It's giving in to the looters. To have compassion for someone will less ability is to support the looters. She made those qualities laudable and easy to digest because those in her story who did not produce, or in other words, the "bad" guys, were schmucks. Mothers, brothers, wives, children -- it didn't matter. The complained and expected a free ride, every one of them. Of course it was easy to declare that they didn't deserve it. But I believe otherwise. I am that schmuck who believes that faith, hope and charity matter. Sorry, Ayn. I'm not even going to start about how retarded the love stories were. Pluh-ese. All of those men in love with the same woman but totally ok with who she eventually chooses because they love him too and who cares that they all still are sexually attracted to her and her to them. It'll all work out because their kind of love, love of industry and work, is all so pure and rational and.....no...I can't go there. It's too ridiculous.This is not a mediocre book nor is it bad or great. As a work of fiction, it is rather dull. On the other hand, as a look into the ramifications of punishing those who make our economic world spin - merely because they make money doing it - it is seriously eye opening. Its unflinching confidence about how the world does, can and should work secures its place as a classic, for both those who love it and for those who hate it....more

title: Gone with the Wind
author: Mitchell, Margaret
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Of all the classics I've read this year, this has been my favorite. Several have clocked in at over a thousand pages, such as this one, but this is thOf all the classics I've read this year, this has been my favorite. Several have clocked in at over a thousand pages, such as this one, but this is the first whose ending came too soon for me. I loved it so much I wanted more. Let me tell you why.First and foremost, Gone With The Wind has multiple levels. I adore books that successfully pull this off. For example, should you want a simple romance (although there is nothing simple about Scarlett and Ashley, Ashley and Melanie or Scarlett and Rhett's romances), it's there. Want a coming of age story? You got it. Need social commentary? Yes. Want historical and geographical insight? Chalk full of it. Isolate this story into any of these genres and you've got several versions of a good story. Combine them all and you have a classic masterpiece. In short, it's really got something for everyone: man, woman, and teen. I think that's why the movie was/is as successful as it is. It gives bits and sometimes more than bits of most of these levels that make it accessible to nearly everyone. In fact, it is more than fair to say that the movie is an excellent and accurate adaptation of the book. The skeleton and many of the muscles are left completely intact. Characters were cast pretty near perfectly to the author's description and the dialogue remains mostly unchanged. However, much like the details of our skin and features make the man, the unabridged inclusion of the area's Civil War history, deeper character development, and more realistically nuanced plot of the book make the complete package a stunning model. The fact that Mitchell wrote such a multi-layered book would have made me an ardent fan all on its own, but the fact that she drove along her story with main characters so fabulously flawed and unlikable (but not bad) undams my inner gush. I mean, she takes this absolutely shallow and conceited girl and gives her strength and determination. Which do you cheer for? Those qualities aren't supposed to be combined! Ahhh, but they are so you have to root for Scarlett O'Hara to succeed because you need something or someone to win within that collapsing society, even though you know she, on principle, deserves to fail because she cheats. She lies. She throws decency asunder. But she survives because she's willing and morally able to get her hands dirty. I still can't decide if I'm meant to like her or hate her. Then comes Ashley who is profoundly more developed in the book than the pretty gentleman character we see in the movie. Ashley is an ideal Southern gentleman. I found it interesting that even Southerners didn't appreciate his fondness for books, music and ideas. Even to them, his refinement as a man was less desirable than had he preferred to drink and hunt like the majority of his land-owning peers. For those who don't know, Ashley is the man who Scarlett becomes fixated with as a young woman and idolizes to the point of fantasy to fuel most of her motivation. Unlike Scarlett, Ashley cannot adapt either to the war or after the war. For me, he is the face of Gone With The Wind. A man with no marketable skills, he loves his wife but lusts after Scarlett, a distinction the very surprisingly sexually naive Scarlett does not understand (I say surprising because she was so quick to pick up on other areas of...er......business matters). I really did enjoy Mitchell using their frustrating relationship to highlight the contrast between Scarlett and Ashley, in both their motivation and understanding. With Ashley comes Melanie, his sweet wife, who is a good soul. Melanie IS the kind of character you love to root for because she is smart and good and kind. But with her good qualities comes a noticeable lack of strength. Not moral strength, for the author gave her plenty of that, but her physical weakness kept her from becoming an idealized caricature instead keeping her withing the realm of possible. At times, Melanie seemed...well...too good to be true but then the author would have her help bury a burglar Scarlett murdered or lie to the police about the KKK (which seems so sympathetic in this story) or ultimately confide that she knows her husband can't take care of himself. Finally, there is Rhett Butler who, in my opinion, is the most faceted character but least understood. Rhett, who regularly behaves badly, but for seemingly different reasons than Scarlett, mocks the values of his fellow Southerners. He admires the scruples of Scarlett, who beguiles him with her temper tantrums and spoiled nature and continuously encourages her to be her worst self. Unlike Ashley, he freely admits his lust for Scarlett but her naivety again plays a role in that she never acknowledges those feelings within herself and consistently rebuffs his advances in favor of her childlike affection for Ashley. Rhett woos and woos, and in turn becomes the one person Scarlett can turn to for help, but it's never without strings attached which makes liking him complicated. Was he just one of those men who only likes the chase or is there a deeper, kinder, more misunderstood person beneath his devil-may-care surface? Mitchell certainly hints at this and Rhett is often portrayed as one deserving sympathy, but this side of him is never quite exposed so I don't think the reader can ever be entirely sure who Rhett Butler is. I shouldn't have written "finally" because there are many, many more interesting and wonderful characters to flesh out this story. The slaves, the neighbors, the other husbands, the relatives. Even the settings become characters as I became acquainted with Atlanta and rural Georgia in a way I never have before. All of their stories make Gone With The Wind what it is: a fully developed voice for the side of history that usually doesn't get one - the side who lost. There you have it. A losing side, characters behaving badly in an era and part of the country I have no ties to and I loved it all. I felt it all. I saw it all. That's good fiction, folks. ...more

title: Les Misérables
author: Hugo, Victor
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: With almost fifteen hundred pages at Victor Hugo's disposal, I expected to discover a lot more insight and depth into the lives of Jean Valjean, JaverWith almost fifteen hundred pages at Victor Hugo's disposal, I expected to discover a lot more insight and depth into the lives of Jean Valjean, Javert, Fantine, Cosette, Marius, Eponine and the Thenardiers, whose heroics, misery, greed, goodness and determination make up the complex story of France in transition after Napoleon's empire fell than what is allowed in the much beloved three and a half-hour musical production. Of course, this is the case, but I was surprised by how well the musical captures the essence of this amazing book. Unlike a lot of screen adaptations, most of the essential elements of the book remain intact for the play. Because I was already so familiar with the plot (I have seen the musical five times, maybe more), I felt my attention gravitate towards the familiar parts of the story and, in turn, felt almost impatient when the narration turned towards the unfamiliar. As a result, I can't decide if I'm glad I knew the story as well as I did, for I felt my spirits rise each time I recognized a favorite scene and could sing along in my head (and sometimes out loud), or if my repeated exposure to the musical hampered my ability to fully enjoy the added dimensions of Hugo's complete masterpiece. I had been warned and was therefore prepared for the famous tangents concerning Waterloo, the description of the streets of Paris and the essay on the benefits and drawbacks of modern sewage systems. Perhaps because I was anticipating these sections, they seemed... separate, somehow from the rest of the novel. It's not just these three sections, but I felt Hugo used two styles and two different voices to write Les Miserables. There were the character sections of the books, where conversation, description and conflict moved the plot along and then there were the essay sections when the author seems to say, "Hold up, I want to explain something first before moving on." And then he would. For pages and pages and pages. He explained what he thought about capitalism and socialism, crime and punishment, religion, monasteries, war, forgiveness, mercy, death and more. I think i could turn to any page in the book and immediately tell if Hugo was in explanation mode or story-telling mode. In my eyes, they didn't blend. Both were interesting, although I admit to preferring the storyline, but I didn't always feel like I was reading one complete story. It took me a month to finish reading and I can't say, like my husband and many others, that this is the best book I have ever read. Without a doubt, it is one of the best stories about morality, justice and mercy ever conceived and written. But I don't feel like I got more of what makes Les Miserables so great, with all of the extra stuff. More information, more depth, more characters, more background, even more story - yes. But more feeling? I don't think so. At least I didn't feel it. But, that may be the result of a long month talking.It feels weird to write as if the book disappointed me. It didn't. I loved it. I just don't love it anymore than I already did, and I suppose that may be considered a disappointment. If only all of life's disappointments were this good....more

title: The Count of Monte Cristo
author: Dumas, Alexandre
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, of course I loved it. Have you read it? It's fabulous.My problem in writing a  is wondering what, if anything, matters. Did Dumas write thWell, of course I loved it. Have you read it? It's fabulous.My problem in writing a  is wondering what, if anything, matters. Did Dumas write this for pure entertainment? If that is the case, then the novel is an out of the ballpark success. Drama, intrigue, suspense, revenge and subterfuge all craftily woven together that make every one of its twelve-hundred plus pages worth it.However.If this is supposed to be some great lesson in morality, particularly about the existence of God, the effects of vengeance or revenge, or even the great balance between justice and mercy, I think there could be some bones to pick.Before I pick, I must admit to wondering if reading the book was even necessary. I am a fan of the James Caviezal as Edmond Dantes movie version and for the first couple hundred pages, felt the few differences between the movie and book were inconsequential. Of course, as is always the case, there were more details, more depth to the characters, but the set up was the same. Edmond was a stand-up guy, engaged to his beautiful Mercedes and happy and lucky in love and life. Then, jealous rivals and a situation of unfortunate coincidence remove him from his simple bliss and he spends the next fourteen years locked up for made-up crimes without any possibility of recourse or explanation. It nearly drives him insane, until he meets a fellow prisoner who, mistakenly thinking he was digging a tunnel to escape, digs a tunnel between their own two cells. As the passageway enables them to enjoy each other's company, the elder prisoner spends years passing on his vast knowledge to his eager student, eventually including information about a mammoth undiscovered treasure. All that is left is for Edmond to find a way to escape, collect his treasure and decide what he wants to do with his freedom and fortune.All of that happens as the movie explained it to me. It is clever in the movie and just as clever in the book. At this point of the story, however, the book becomes a maze of plot development compared to the movie's much simplified stroll-down-a-lighted-main-street approach. I liked the maze. I appreciated Dumas thinking I could handle the maze. Because, let me tell you, it gets a little disorientating throughout the last eight-hundred pages, or so.Now for the picking - I have heard that this is a great story about revenge. Certainly, that is true. It is a great story. And it is about revenge. What is unclear to me is if the revenge is great. I don't think so. I'm not sure we're supposed to think so.Something that always bugged me about the movie was how Edmond, or The Count of Monte Cristo, got all of his revenge and then, when everyone was dead or ruined, he had a change of heart and could get back to the business of being a good guy. Well......yeah! When everything is going your way, being forgiving and kind and compassionate is not a very hard thing to be.The book doesn't go quite as far in making everything hunky dory for Edmond in the end, as there are a few unforeseen consequences he didn't count on bothering him when he set out to ruin those who ruined him, but neither book nor movie bothers to really ask the question if Edmond had the right or responsibility to become the Count of Monte Cristo; if he could have received the peace he deserved without spending over a decade playing a covert, and, might I add, one-sided, game of chess. Of course, had he taken his large fortune and settled into the quiet life of a fisherman, there wouldn't be much of a story:)The other thing that make the story even more unlikely is that all of the original characters still seem to be connected. Sons are marrying daughters, everyone lives in the same town, and everyone associates in the same class-level, which happens to correspond nicely with The Count's own unlimited wealth. Again, I concede that without this set-up, the revenge would have taken even longer to enact. Having everyone's story interact made the fall-out go down like an intricate design of dominoes. It took a long time to set-up but once the initial push was made, everything came crashing down.I'm so glad I read the book. Instead of scratching my head about whether or not anyone, even someone grossly wronged by evildoers, has the right to seek vengeance, I will simply enjoy the time I spent learning about the unstable french government surrounding Napoleon's reign, the dazzling style that The Count of Monte Cristo infused into everything he did and, yes, some head scratching about who was who....more

title: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn
author: Twain, Mark
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Part of earning some kind of achievement for a bear scout (I don't remember which one. I am not fluent in Cub Scout-ese) is retelling a folk or tall tPart of earning some kind of achievement for a bear scout (I don't remember which one. I am not fluent in Cub Scout-ese) is retelling a folk or tall tale that is part of our American heritage. The examples given are Paul Bunyan, Pecos Bill etc. but my nine year-old is on a reading whirlwind and wants to earn as many AR points (earned from taking tests about books he reads) as he can by the end of his trimester. I had the grand idea of him reading The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn with me and killing two birds with one stone (is there a less violent idiom that means the same thing? Can't think of it right now so the brutal imagery will remain). I checked out an extra copy at the library, fully intending to give him the copy I bought for my classics challenge but after reading the first few chapters, I decided to hold off giving him the book until I finished reading. Even early on, it seemed inappropriate for someone his age.I understand the controversy. I do. Mark Twain wrote a brilliant novel considered by many to be THE Great American Novel, in its strength of characters, use of dialect, plot, social impact and overall theme: racial injustice. His work deserves every accolade it has received and probably every criticism. How can you tell someone who is offended by the use of the N-word not to be offended? Especially when Twain uses the word as frequently as he does, well over two hundred times throughout the novel.Does it make a difference that most of the utterances are made by Huck, a boy who is racist only because he is ignorant, and not out of hatred? Does it make a difference that he uses this word because...well...it is the only noun he knows to use in regards to a black man? Does it make a difference that he continues to use this insulting word even after he decides to help Jim, a black man, escape to freedom? For some readers, like myself, it does make a difference. While I find the word loathsome, I have no history that makes it personally offensive. Others, however, see any use of the word as unacceptable regardless of the story, history or lesson. Similar to other heated debates, I doubt either side will be able to convince the other. The extraordinary power of Twain's novel is that he creates a protagonist, Huck, that is simultaneously extremely naive and wonderfully thoughtful. His naivety allows most of the adventures of the story to take place. Huck, though thirteen and more world wise than most, believes and does what most people tell him to do: Miss Watson and her Baptist beliefs, his mean drunk father and his litany of verbal abuse, Tom Sawyer and all of his playful foolishness, and the frauds who call themselves the Duke and the King when they force Huck to play a role in their schemes and scams.Huck's thoughtfulness, however, is what gives The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn the moral weight which makes it so great. When Huck decides to help Jim, a black man, gain his freedom, he does not make his decision because he thinks it's the morally right thing to do. On the contrary, Huck knows from all his upbringing that it's wrong. He accepts what Miss Watson declares will be his fate in Hell, a fate earned by breaking the law and stealing someone's rightful property (Jim) as well as simply deciding he'd probably rather be there because it sounds like more fun, because he unwillingly and inadvertently loves Jim, a runaway slave who over and over again risks more than his illegal freedom by sticking with Huck Finn through adventure after adventure. It is Jim who eventually teaches Huck, a young boy who has every single reason in the world to put himself first because no one else is going to, what love really means. It is also Jim, a black man not even considered to BE a man, who shows Huck what it means to be human. I loved this book. I hope my son will read it....someday. But not right now. He needs time and experience in the world to have the necessary frame of reference, not to mention the patience for all of the written vernacular, Twain requires his readers to have. Because as important and moving and fun as this book is, it is obviously not for everyone, especially my own naive and thoughtful fourth grader. Not yet. We'll read about Pecos Bill instead....more

title: Mere Christianity
author: Lewis, C.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't know how to begin this book . I've probably typed and deleted a dozen sentences already. Why should this be so difficult?Because, I likeI don't know how to begin this book . I've probably typed and deleted a dozen sentences already. Why should this be so difficult?Because, I liked it.I did.Except. No. Even that part, the part he got wrong, I liked.Which made me wonder.Who is this book for?Christians?Obviously. We love this stuff. Having a smart guy give smart reasons to explain why Christianity makes perfect sense feels...smart. It sits well, if you will. Many, if not most, of his arguments were things I had not previously thought about in terms of why I believe there is a God and why I believe that Christ was our Savior, and to have them explained to me with both his brilliant circular logic and then the helpful and much-easier-to-follow analogy, filled my believer's bucket.But I don't think Lewis prepared these addresses (Mere Christianity is actually a compilation of radio addresses he delivered on the BBC during the Second World War) in order to simply preach to the choir.Because Lewis was a former atheist, I believe he felt strongly, especially during such a major conflict as the war which included in its causes a fight against evil, that the world needed to understand where our morality comes from. I think he was motivated to convince the masses that goodness isn't something we choose because it makes the world a better place or because our parents taught us the golden rule but rather, we choose it because God is real. Christ is real. And the possibility to become like them is real. So, what about the others? How would a non-Christian respond to Lewis? It's hard for me to say, because, while I think he's very convincing and right quite a lot of the time, there are times throughout the book where I think he's wrong. I think he's wrong because I have been taught something different and I believe that to be truth instead. It's difficult for me to not take that one step further and assume that others who have been taught something else might thing he's wrong in even more places.This inability for me to claim the book as all right is a stumbling block. I want to be able to say, "Read this. He makes the case for Christianity." But I'd have to add, "However, I think he's a little off about the Godhead." Lewis, himself, frequently cites his own reasoning as guesswork. I admire his ability to say, "I can't be sure but this is how I think it works." If he had done that with the Godhead, I'd probably be a lot more at ease with my reaction to the book but he doesn't. He's pretty firm about how God begat Christ, which makes him his "Son" although they are the same being, just as a cube can be made up of more than one squares but they are not separate from the cube. They are the cube. God is God. All of Him. I'd continue to explain the Holy Ghost but it gets a little confusing. My belief that they are three different beings is so much more clear to me. Still, it is what it is. A fascinating and articulate justification forChristianity. And read with a proper British voice narrating in my head, it was a delightful and enlightening read....more

title: Green Mansions
author: Hudson, William Henry
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you have never heard of the book Green Mansions and didn't know it was a classic, you're not alone. Neither did I before I saw it on my library's "If you have never heard of the book Green Mansions and didn't know it was a classic, you're not alone. Neither did I before I saw it on my library's "We Recommend" table. It certainly looked old and, on a whim, I checked it out. After looking up the title on Amazon.com and Goodreads, I realized it was, indeed, a classic and thought I'd add a lesser known, or forgotten title to my list of twenty. You know, step outside the box. Maybe help shed some light on a great old book. Well, classics are classics for a reason and there is a reason this book has been forgotten. It's not very good. In fact, I may as well say it. It's bad. Abel, a member of the aristocratic class of Venezuela, flees to the uncivilized jungles after a failed coup. Because he is able to pick up languages easily, he learns to communicate and eventually live among several different indigenous tribes. Just like any great guest, he spends his time wowing them with his guitar, waits for his meals while he hangs out in his hammock and laughs at their silly traditions. Eventually, driven by boredom, he explores a cursed part of the forest where he eventually meets an unusual girl unlike any one he's ever seen. She seems able to talk to birds and snakes, climbs trees and appears to live all alone in her "green mansion." Most interesting to Abel is the paleness of her white skin, noticeably different from the savages (his words) that inhabit this area. Rima, as she is called by a spanish speaking man who raised her, is the last surviving member of an extinct tribe. How she came to live with him is more complicated than I care to explain, as William Henry Hudson unravels her origins in an excruciatingly slow discovery, but suffice it to say that when Rima and Abel fall in love, it spells doom for both of them. While there is the romance, which is actually unsatisfying because it follows that melodramatic pattern of 19th century romanticism where there seems to be no passion accompanied with the unexplained devotion, this book is really more about the forest than the girl. Hudson uses most of his words to describe every tree, every vine, and every undergrowth. It becomes ridiculous to think that he is really including these mind-numbing descriptive details in his explanation of his tragic past to his friend. In addition to the superfluous language, the book is unforgivably racist and outdated. I kept wondering why I was being less forgiving than I was with, say, A Town Like Alice, which also exposes its age with its no longer acceptable prejudices. All I can say is that Alice at least redeems itself with its other, better qualities. Green Mansions doesn't. Its attitude towards the aboriginals of Venezuela, as described by a superior white man, is blatantly offensive. Uncomfortably so. Skip it. There's really no reason to read this book....more

Her characters and plot felt secondary to the famous falls and sometimes her working in facts and bits or real history felt forced.I also felt a bit duped after reading the book jacket and realizing that the description only covered the first half of the story. title: A Tale of Two Cities
author: Dickens, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Surprisingly, considering its fame, I knew very little about this classic book. I knew it had a great opening line and an oft quoted last sentence. BuSurprisingly, considering its fame, I knew very little about this classic book. I knew it had a great opening line and an oft quoted last sentence. But the stuff in between? Nothing. I didn't know the two cities were London and Paris. I didn't know it was about the french revolution and class warfare and sacrifice. All of that intellectual blindness came in handy as I was able to read and react to this novel without its fame interfering with my opinion. If I take the dazzling name "Dickens" away and judge it on its own merits, I'd say I liked this book very much but with reservations. Characters who do interesting, noble or even bad things aren't great characters if you don't know or care why they do them. None of the players in Tale felt like real people to me. Charles Darnay, while good and true, was too good to be true. Same with Dr. Mannette. His unjust incarceration only felt unjust because Dickens told me it was so. Not knowing anything of his nature, until very close to the end, made it hard to cheer for his recovery when he was so dramatically "recalled to life." In fact, most of the character's motivations, including Sydney Carton's ultimate act of love, were given too late. I don't know if the slow character development (if any) was part of some great Dickensian strategy, but his flat characters did little to embellish the peaks and valleys of his very thoughtful story.Characterization flaws aside, I can't deny the timelessness of A Tale of Two Cities. While very obviously about the french revolution, including colorful references to tri-colored sashes (I had a Les Mis song or two in my head), red caps and blood soaked guillotines, I felt Dickens knew then that the themes of retribution, injustice and class distinction were applicable for any group, family, or country at war with itself. Even more than the memories of my own country's more familiar (to me) Revolutionary War, or even its Civil War, Tale invoked images of Town Hall discontent over health care and the angry chatter found in comment sections online. Hate, in any form, is never flattering. Dickens seemed to agree with this, and I felt it was fair of him to portray both sides, the aristocracy and peasants, as part of the problem. The book's tone at the beginning makes it clear that Dickens sympathizes with the powerless and poor. He exposes and ridicules the flaws of both France's and England's legal systems and both's inability to adequately administer appropriate justice. However, he doesn't stay in the working class's corner for long, as he's soon disapproving of their blood lust and anarchy.Amazingly, anger, fear, and injustice are not really what this book is about. Instead, each negative is counterbalanced with love, friendship and selflessness. It was, in fact, the best of times AND the worst of times. Pretty much like today. Or, any period of time, if you think about it. Because light always pushes away darkness.Dickens ends his famous tale by focusing on the better part - the positive. In Carton's own dying words, "It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done; it is a far, far better rest that I go to, than I have ever known."You can't end a story much better than that....more

title: I Capture the Castle
author: Smith, Dodie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: From its first paragraph, I was completely enchanted with Dodie Smith's precocious narrator. An eighteen year-old aspiring writer sits in her dilapidaFrom its first paragraph, I was completely enchanted with Dodie Smith's precocious narrator. An eighteen year-old aspiring writer sits in her dilapidated castle kitchen, and writes by candlelight with her feet in the sink (or at least what I pictured as a sink) and begins what she calls and experiment in speed writing. She is mindful to include all sorts of details so you can imagine the determination she applied when describing her mood, her environment, and herself. I was so excited to continue reading.While she, Cassandra Mortmain, remained charming, I will admit that I finished a little disappointed with the overall scope of the novel, only because everything did not turn out the way I wanted it to. I'm not sure what I expected as the novel reveals early on that it's not your run-of-the-mill coming of age story. The characters are all so, so beautifully flawed and eccentric. All are capable of good and bad behavior and all are enjoyed all the more for it. Rose, Cassandra's older sister, is beyond inept and at 21 solely relies on her beauty to step away from her family's poverty that she loathes. Her father, a famous author of a one-hit wonder now suffering from a severe case of writer's block, cloisters himself away in a part of the castle where he spends his days doing crosswords or reading mystery novels, but absolutely nothing to provide income, food, or clothing to his wife and three children. This is done without malice, mind you. The children aren't prisoners or locked away in an attic a la a V.C. Andrew novel, but rather, they seem to somewhat accept their fall from grace (they were once quite wealthy after the success of their father's novel)in fine form. His wife, the exotically beautiful Topaz, is not the children's mother but rather their step-mother, and frequently communes with nature in nothing but tall black boots and earned fame earlier in her life as a portrait model. Even stiff Stephen, their handsome servant who works for nothing, is utterly believable as a devoted, but not very interesting beautiful person. I loved all of them.When two brothers from America inherit the estate and become the Mortmains new landlords, the escapades begins. All events are captured by Cassandra in her journal and her voice somehow combines the genteel English sensibility of a Jane Austen romance with the comic misunderstandings of the TV sitcom Three's Company. Together, the reader is provided with surprising twists, laugh out loud moments and plenty of fodder for frustration. I'm not sure it counts as important, or groundbreaking, as some classics do, but I Capture the Castle is full of characters who deserve to stick around for years and years. I'm glad I read it....more

review: This book is great. Except that I can't recommend it to anyone.The language is so foul, the conversations so...inappropriate, that I think it might ofThis book is great. Except that I can't recommend it to anyone.The language is so foul, the conversations so...inappropriate, that I think it might offend most people I know. I've tried to think if the book would be as effective without all the reference to sex. Maybe. But, the author, Benioff, would have had to create a different character than Koyla, the totally charming, reckless, and brave deserter who accompanies the narrator, Lev, on a mission to find a dozen eggs for a colonel's daughter's wedding cake. Koyla, as offensive as he is, needs to be there. His levity, during situations where no levity should be possible, push a hard story into its heartwarming category. Because, crazily enough, this rough, distasteful, harsh book that is filled with starvation, winter, war, cruelty, death, murder...almost everything bad that you can think of, ends up being...well...touching. I shouldn't have liked it. But I did. Even Koyla. Especially Koyla....more

title: The Forgotten Garden
author: Morton, Kate*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After hearing many glowing comments about Kate Morton's The Forgotten Garden, I decided to forgo the long reserve line at the library and buy myself aAfter hearing many glowing comments about Kate Morton's The Forgotten Garden, I decided to forgo the long reserve line at the library and buy myself a copy. Even with its respectable five-hundred and forty-eight page heft, I didn't want to put this book down. The Forgotten Garden begins with an unnamed girl playing a hiding game on a ship. A few pages later, a girl named Nell is turning twenty-one and her father reveals to her a devastating truth: she is not their daughter. He discovered her standing alone holding a small suitcase which contains a book of fairy tales and an extra dress on the wharf where he worked when she was only four years-old. While it's not exactly a mystery, because the reader is never quite sure if a crime has ever been committed, wanting to learn who Nell is, who she was before she arrived on a different continent, alone, and without knowing her name is a strong motivator to keep reading. Morton doesn't hand over her clues upfront, however. Instead, she weaves the story of Eliza Makepeace, the author of little Nell's book of fairy tales, and Nell's own granddaughter's, Cassandra, story into Nell's quest to rediscover her lost identity. Most of the time, I enjoyed the weaving. It's done so subtly, like coming in and out of dream sequences, that, unlike some other books that use this technique, I didn't find myself wishing to be back in one story and out of another. I will say, though, that hindsight has made me wish certain plot holes were filled and left wondering why other information, that now seems superfluous, was included. Also, I was a little bit disappointed with the character development. Instead of really getting to know Nell, whose story this might have been, Morton instead chooses to use Nell's sense of loss to pose the question: what influences our sense of identity? How do we become who we are? Is it our name? Who our parents are? Is it who we marry or the status of our socioeconomic level? Is it our talents, or fame or careers? Is it our tragedies? Yes. All of them or none of them depending on what we decide matters most. If you enjoy stories that transport you into Victorian England, have a touch of romance, the pull of mystery, the weight of history as well as a few revealing fairy tales, you'll probably love The Forgotten Garden....more

title: Still Alice
author: Genova, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Like Flowers For Algernon and The Bell Jar, I found Still Alice to not only be an interesting novel about mental illness, but felt that its scope pushLike Flowers For Algernon and The Bell Jar, I found Still Alice to not only be an interesting novel about mental illness, but felt that its scope pushed it beyond entertainment, even beyond its own story and into the realm of important fiction. Lisa Genova’s Still Alice is not my first exposure to Alzheimer’s disease. I noticed with sadness the withdrawal of President Ronald Regan's visibility. I’ve read and watched Nicholas Spark's The Notebook (which probably doesn't count). And while I’ve thankfully been spared watching any members of my immediate family suffer, I have watched a beloved former neighbor and friend forget and withdraw from our shared memories. It’s horrible. And this book doesn’t pretend otherwise, for the person afflicted or for the witnesses to the affliction.Alzheimer’s, which deceptively rhymes with “old timers”, is the most familiar face of dementia but, like probably most, I didn’t really understand the beginning, the progression or the variety of this cruel disease. Genova, with her very heavyweight Harvard Ph.D. in neuroscience, is a reassuring author as I felt like she had the capability and authority to write about early onset Alzheimer’s in such a personal and informative way. It wasn’t until about halfway through the book that I realized that Still Alice was not a first person narrative. It felt like it because I knew what Alice was thinking, how she was feeling and wasn’t given that view into any of the other characters. But, suddenly, the “she’s” and "hers" appeared heavy and often and I realized that I wasn't inside Alice's head but, instead, was hovering around Alice with the benefit of someone telling me exactly what her dark-curly haired fifty year-old self was experiencing. As I’m not an author, I don’t know what goes into the decision about who the narrator will be. So many books these days seem to pass the narrative baton from character to character, each one getting to express their own voice with their personal “I”s and “me’s, instantly creating intimacy. While I think it would have been interesting to glimpse into Lydia’s motivation, Anna’s drive and John’s inner conflict, I was glad that our time was spent with Alice. There is only one brief departure from Alice to John and I’m not sure why. Except for that one irregularity, I appreciated the continuity of Alice’s experience.  I don’t know if I’ve ever seen a character change so much throughout a book but still seem grounded to the original character. While the author provided straightforward visual samples of Alice’s decline with her less and less detailed (and eventually wrong) answers to a series of five recurring questions throughout the book, I believe the evolution of the relationship between Alice and her youngest daughter, Lydia, was the better barometer. Even as she lost more of her intellect and memories with each subsequent page turn, Alice didn’t stop being Alice. Ahhh….there’s the title. She’s Still Alice. In her impassioned speech at an Alzheimer’s conference, Alice asks, “When will I no longer be me? Is the part of my brain that’s responsible for my unique ‘me-ness’ vulnerable to this disease? Or is my identity something that transcends neurons, proteins, and defective molecules of DNA? Is my soul and spirit immune to the ravages of Alzheimer’s? I believe it is.” While certainly less obvious, Alice is there at the end. Not in her office at Harvard University. Not at the lectern, confidently guiding students with her professional expertise, and not as an opinionated mother and wife voicing her unfulfilled expectations, but there. No one is tiptoeing through daisies, and everyone is forced to sacrifice, but this novel showed how one family coped and adjusted to loving someone with Alzheimer’s. More importantly, it showed with candor and tenderness how one brilliant woman/wife/mother/daughter/sister/professor/friend/researcher/mentor/author/reader/person fought an unwinnable fight. ...more

title: Cutting for Stone
author: Verghese, Abraham*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Cutting For Stone is definitely at the top of my summer "books I've read" list. Epic in nature like Steinbeck and Stegner, Verghese creates a truly meCutting For Stone is definitely at the top of my summer "books I've read" list. Epic in nature like Steinbeck and Stegner, Verghese creates a truly memorable saga about forgiveness, family and death. While not the merriest subjects, Verghese treats them with such depth and variety that at the end of the hefty 560 pages, you have been treated to an uplifting story - the kind you can sigh about when finished.Sister Mary Joseph Praise, while traveling with a fellow nun by ship on their way from India to an African mission where they are told they are needed most, becomes the ship's nurse after most of the passengers, including Dr. Thomas Stone, become ill with typhoid. While she successfully revives Stone, her companion does not survive, making Sister Praise's future uncertain. Both Stone and Praise leave an impression on each other as Sister Praise's trajectory eventually lands her next to Stone as his assistant at Missing Hospital in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. It is the setting of Missing Hospital (really Mission Hospital, but it soon becomes its commonly mispronounced name) that allows the book's many wonderful characters to develop.Foremost of all these characters is Marion, one of the twin brothers born from a secret love affair between Thomas Stone and Mary Joseph Praise. Praise dies during childbirth and Stone, tormented by his loss and confusion, disappears. Marion, and his brother, Shiva, are raised by two fellow physicians at Missing - Hema, an Indian OB/GYN and Ghosh, an internist turned surgeon after Stone flees (he's literally "cutting for Stone", which is just one, and probably the most obvious, of the title's many meanings) raise the boys as their own until one brother betrays the other and Marion leaves Africa for New York to be trained in America's very different world of medicine.The story can be complicated, with heavy doses of medical jargon that make it seem less accessible than it actually is, but plowing through all of the surgical details, even the sometimes uncomfortable female anatomical references (there is a lot of OB/GYN talk so if the words vulva, labia or vagina make you squirm, this might not be the book for you) is worth it. Like all great epics, the middle section can be heavy and slow-going, but the development is necessary to make the end as great as it is.Highly recommended....more

title: We Need to Talk About Kevin
author: Shriver, Lionel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have such mixed feelings about We Need To Talk About Kevin, a fictional story about a teenage boy who commits mass murder at his high school only daI have such mixed feelings about We Need To Talk About Kevin, a fictional story about a teenage boy who commits mass murder at his high school only days before the well known and real life tragedy at Columbine High School in 1999. Written in the form letters the boy's mother writes to her husband after their son's crime, the unwritten question posed throughout the novel isn't what happened but why it happened. As the mother re-examines her own behavior towards her husband, her pregnancy and her son, we readers are allowed to weigh our own opinions about whether it was nature or nurture that turned Kevin into a sociopath. On one hand, I felt like the author, Lionel Shriver, did an incredible job in allowing her protagonist, Eva Katchadourian, to be the kind of flawed but not evil mother who you want to blame but aren't quite sure if you should. She is so obnoxious with her love of the world but not of her own country, the good old US of A. Really, she's a snob but not one void of sympathy. Her own mother suffers from agoraphobia and can't leave her apartment, which might explain Eva's need to travel. When she discovers an aversion to pregnancy and how little natural affection she has for her son, her nurturing, or lack thereof, seems the obvious reason for Kevin's issues. Except that Kevin is hard to like, let alone love. Even as a baby, his personality was harsh and irritating. Of course, we only know Kevin through Eva's eyes, but his behavior and lack of sensitivity certainly lend credence to the side that Kevin was simply wrong in the head. Always was. On the other hand, I felt like this entire story, idea, and presentation was incredibly manipulative not to mention insensitive. Sure, we are all wondering how something like mass murder in a high school by a high school student can happen. Who are these kids and how do they become so evil? I'm not sure creating a fictional character and having him reference to actual events and actual people, like Eric Harris and Dylan Kelbold with disdain and mockery is tasteful. I felt uncomfortable. Besides that, some of the scenes are downright squirmworthy. What made me most uncomfortable, however, was something Kevin told his mother on one of her monthly visits to his juvenile prison. During one visit, he defended his behavior by stating that not only do we need people like him to do things like he did, but we want him to as well. After all, the rest of us just sit around, doing nothing but watching and reading about what other people actually do. In other words, he considered himself a do-er and the rest of us simply spectators. As I was doing just that, lying in bed and reading about a horrific event instead of living it, I wondered if he was right. By reading books like this, was I, in actuality, encouraging horrible behavior? I've since decided that that isn't true. My friend, Amy, helped put words to my thoughts when she defended a book about rape. She wrote, "We read about awful things because by reading about them we can understand them without having to experience them. Or we read about them because we experienced them and are searching for commonality, for someone else's experience to erase the loneliness of our own. We read about the ugly, dark things in the world so as to understand how people overcome them, so we can see courage in the face of trouble and hope set against despair. We read so our empathy may be doubled. Ignoring the awful things that happen doesn't make them go away. Ignorance make them more awful. Keeping the dark things in the dark gives them more power. Shining a light on them takes it away. Choosing to read brings that needed light."Yeah. What she said. Although I don't think We Need To Talk About Kevin is even close to a "must-read" it is an interesting, non-scientific look at what creates a sociopath....more

author: Ruiz Zafón, Carlos
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: From the author of The Shadow of the Wind, The Angel's Game is another gothic suspense/thriller that revolves around the power of books and authors. IFrom the author of The Shadow of the Wind, The Angel's Game is another gothic suspense/thriller that revolves around the power of books and authors. I know, who knew authors could lead such dangerous lives?This is extremely fun to read. Just the right mix of creepy and funny and romantic. It all flows together so fantastically. Mind you, I'm commenting on what is actually the translation, so I can only imagine how good the original spanish text is. Or maybe it isn't. Maybe the translator is a better author than Zafon. I doubt it but you never know. I enjoyed reading every word and found myself turning page after page after page to see what happened next.That pursuit of discovery turned into a problem, however, as I'm still not exactly sure what happened in the end. Or what mattered. Or who. By the time all the revelations were being made, my zeal as a reader had been replaced with cynicism. Did any of that development matter? I just wanted things to make sense, to come together, and a lot of it didn't. I'd recommend Angel's Game if I felt like I knew what this book was about. Maybe religion? Maybe the price of fame? Maybe people that never die? I'm not sure. So, read with caution. And if you figure out what it's about, let me know....more

title: Out Stealing Horses
author: Petterson, Per
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You know when books have a flavor? This had a European flavor. The author is Norwegian whose very Scandinavian characters, Trond and Lars, create a feYou know when books have a flavor? This had a European flavor. The author is Norwegian whose very Scandinavian characters, Trond and Lars, create a feeling akin to those I had watching films at the International Cinema during college, only in book form. The book doesn't happen in black and white, at least not quite, but there was a definite filter on my mind's lens. Subdued. Cold. Detached. Serious. Unexplained. Unemotional. Unhappy.What more could you ask for in a book, right? As dreary as I am making it sound, there are a lot of really good things that happen in this novel. First of all, I love the title. It's more complicated than it seems after the first chapter, and I love it when titles are layered. Secondly, I think melancholy books about fathers and sons totally works. Men are such an unemotional lot, and the contained longing this older man has for the last summer he spent with his father is poignant. Finally, there is an excellent quote. Many a book is supported by a few good quotes. I don't know if this will pass the test of time, but it should:"You decide for yourself when it will hurt." Can you feel the testosterone? They may be driving Volvos instead of trucks, but this is a book about men. And because I like men, and am curious by just how much they are not like me, I really enjoyed this book....more

title: Tomboy Bride: A Woman's Personal Account of Life in Mining Camps of the West
author: Backus, Harriet Fish
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read Tomboy Bride as part of a church bookgroup that I decided to crash (it wasn't my ward) with the hopes of being taken up to the Tomboy Mine nearI read Tomboy Bride as part of a church bookgroup that I decided to crash (it wasn't my ward) with the hopes of being taken up to the Tomboy Mine near Telluride as part of the book's discussion.The tour of the mine and mountain ghost settlement never happened, but a really fun discussion with a member of a Victorian society present made the entire experience of reading this book a lot more fun than I expected.As far as the book goes, I was enchanted with Harriet Fish Backus living as a new bride at 11,000 feet elevation in the winter. Her descriptions of an area I can well picture, because it's part of the mountain system where I live, were delightful. Delightful, you say? Yes, because she is a Victorian bride and this was no expose. It was an extremely optimistic, positive view about an unusual, and without a doubt, difficult situation. The book doesn't stay in Colorado, however, and as the couple moved to British Colombia, Idaho and even back to Colorado, my interest waned. Her positive spin lost a bit of its charm as I more and more wanted to know what it was really like. Still, I loved the Telluride/Tomboy bit....more

review: For a book that is all about suspense and finding out what happens on the next page, I sure have forgotten a lot of details about the plot.Basically, For a book that is all about suspense and finding out what happens on the next page, I sure have forgotten a lot of details about the plot.Basically, a woman kills her husband and is on the run from his two brothers who have an uncanny ability to find her in spite of the river she crossed, the home she found shelter in, the horse she stole, the mountains she climbs, the rain, the escaped convict she eventually hooks up with, the Indian who brings her down the mountain or the landslide that buries the town where she eventually resides. This all happens amid present tense descriptions of her starvation (although food always manages to arrive in some kind of edible form just in the nick of time) and flashbacks about what lead to the murder of her husband. It's all very interesting, if not very likely, and I enjoyed the story. It's just not the kind of book that...sticks...with you. The motive and resolution are lackluster and the ending, while clever, is disappointing because I'm not sure it's the ending she deserved.For me, it was the perfect break from some heavier reading. So, if you're looking for a kind of mystery/love story/historical fiction about the wild, wild west - you might give The Outlander a try....more

title: The Secret Journal of Brett Colton
author: Mangum, Kay Lynn
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am not a kind judge to YA literature. I am especially unkind to LDS YA literature. After being told that I would cry, which I heavily suspected was I am not a kind judge to YA literature. I am especially unkind to LDS YA literature. After being told that I would cry, which I heavily suspected was untrue, I read this sweet book about a brother who dies and leaves his journal for his much younger sister to read when she's in high school.There were things I liked. I loved how the mean girl character, you know, the popular, cute cheerleader who everyone is really afraid of, was LDS. I appreciated the author allowing an LDS character to be flawed, and not just because they've sinned. I also liked how the narrator, who is not LDS, has parents who are very wary of mormons for their missionary efforts. We're always told not to worry about coming off as crusaders wanting to baptize all our friends if we talk about the gospel with our friends, but this girl's parents see her LDS boyfriends as doing exactly that. Those bits of realism aside, both Brett Colton (dead brother) and star quarterback and all around perfect guy, Jason West, are most definitely not real. At least, they didn't feel real. I certainly didn't know any male in high school that was THAT sensitive, THAT open, THAT thoughtful, THAT well rounded. I'm not being sexist. I didn't know any female that had all of those qualities either. Jason West, and his perfection, ruined this sweet story for me. That's me, 34 year-old book snob, talking, though. I'm sure I'd be excited if my own boys liked this book when they become teenagers. It's clean, uplifting, and touching. It's just not very well written. So...that's a toss up....more

title: Sarah's Key
author: Rosnay, Tatiana de*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this a few months ago and this  has been sitting in the to-do pile for months. Then, it arrived via package as part of this mail exchangeI read this a few months ago and this  has been sitting in the to-do pile for months. Then, it arrived via package as part of this mail exchange book club and I just finished re-reading it today.I can't say it improved the second time around, but I did gain an appreciation for the importance of remembering this lost story now told that I didn't really grasp the first time.Sarah's Key takes place in Europe, France in particular, during World War II. I know there are probably hundreds of details about this war I still have no knowledge of, but I was surprised to have never heard of the Vel d'Hiv, or Velodrome d'Hiver, a round-up of French Jews by the French police in July of 1942. Thousands of men, women, but mostly children, even those born in France, were taken out of their homes, sent to the Vel d'Hiv, which was an arena used for biking events, separated from their parents, then sent to French concentration camps before most were sent on to the Polish concentration camp, Auschwitz.Sarah's Key is really two stories. This first is Sarah's historical one, with a thoughtful third person narrative following her nightmare as she loses her brother, her parents and her childhood in a heart wrenching nightmare. The second is a misused melodrama involving an American journalist, Julia Jaramond, living in France with her French husband and daughter, reporting on the 60th anniversary of this lesser known event in French history. All of these chapters are written in a tiring first-person and ultimately consume the historical story once the character's lives cross.For me, it's hard to separate my appreciation of what I believe the morale of the story to be: to never forget past horrors so that we'll be less likely to repeat them, from the journalist's I-don't-love-my-husband-anymore banality, especially when Sarah's story all but ended with 100 pages left. The author forced me to wade through her modern mama drama to get Sarah's experience, and by so doing, completely overshadowed the more important story.If you enjoy different angles concerning the Holocaust and historical fiction about this time period, you might like this. If it had really been about Sarah, I might have, but as this is actually Julia's story, I didn't....more
